title: Managerial Accounting
description: The course provides an introduction to managerial accounting concepts, budgeting, incremental cost and profit analysis, breakeven analysis, responsibility reporting, and the use of financial analysis for managerial decision-making. May not be taken concurrently with ACCT 204 . Prerequisite(s): sophomore or higher standing, or permission of instructor.

title: Financial Accounting
description: After considering the importance of generally accepted accounting principles and the study of the accounting cycle, the course emphasizes asset valuation, classification, and measurement of liabilities, and income determination. This course may be taken before, but not concurrently with, ACCT 203 . Prerequisite(s): DATA 102 .

title: Computerized Accounting
description: Alternate years. Small businesses are the backbone of the US economy and a primary source of jobs for Americans. This course will evaluate various accounting solutions that have been developed to assist small business. Students will evaluate current accounting theory relevant to small- to medium-size enterprises (SMEs) and apply it to practice by utilizing current software. This course may fulfill an elective in the accounting minor and, with department chair approval, the business minor. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 204 . Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Intermediate Accounting I
description: A study of financial accounting theory and generally accepted accounting principles as applied to the measurement and valuation of assets and liabilities. Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in ACCT 203 (may be taken concurrently with permission of instructor) and ACCT 204.

title: Intermediate Accounting II
description: Continuation of Intermediate Accounting I. A study of financial accounting theory and generally accepted accounting principles as applied to the measurement and valuation assets, liabilities, shareholders’ equity, issues related to income determination, and preparation and analysis of corporate financial statements. Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in ACCT 301 or permission of instructor.

title: Cost Accounting
description: A continuation of costing systems and methods. Special emphasis is given to cost concepts, classification and measurement techniques in production planning and control under job order and process. Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in ACCT 203 and ACCT 204 .

title: Income Tax
description: A study of federal income tax law to provide a basis for an understanding and evaluation of that law. Examines the implications of income taxation for economic decision-making. Emphasis on taxation of individuals, with coverage of corporations, partnerships, estates, and trusts as they relate to individuals. Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in ACCT 203 and ACCT 204 .

title: Accounting Information Systems
description: A study of accounting systems, which provides information for decision-making. The course examines business structures, information needed for decision-making, internal controls in manual and computerized systems, systems development, systems controls, and ethical aspects of the computer environment. Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in ACCT 203 and ACCT 204 .

title: Principles of Auditing
description: An introduction of practices and procedures of assurance services, including planning, assessing risk, testing controls, and obtaining and documenting evidence in accordance with authoritative standards including the AICPA Statements on Auditing Standards. Analyses of business processes and decisions (both financial and nonfinancial) and analytical skills needed to evaluate audit evidence, develop recommendations, and communicate findings. Emphasizes auditing from the perspective of a public accountant. Attention is also given to the roles and responsibilities of internal auditors. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 302 ; additionally, ACCT 315 (may be taken concurrently).

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Advanced Accounting
description: This course is a study of accounting for business combinations and consolidated financial statements. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 302 or permission of instructor.

title: Business Analytics
description: This course prepares students to plan, execute, write and present descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive quantitative analyses of financial and operational data, in order to inform management decision-making. It familiarizes students with relevant software tools and techniques for preparing, analyzing, and presenting data and does so in the context of analyzing pertinent financial information. Finally, it enables students to recognize and produce high quality quantitative analyses as well as critique deceptive and manipulative abuses of quantitative analyses from a Reformed perspective. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 302 or permission of instructor.

title: Forensic Accounting and Fraud Examination
description: This course addresses the study of business risk as viewed from the context of fraud examination. This course is designed to develop a theoretical foundation of crime causation related to fraud and white-collar crime. This course is also designed to develop forensic accounting and fraud examination skills that can be applied to prevent and detect fraud risk. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 302 and admission to the MAcc program.

title: Taxation
description: This course is an introduction to the fundamental principles of taxation related to the formation, operation, and termination of corporations and partnerships. Included are entity-related tax implications for shareholders and partners. Additional topics include multi-state taxation, international taxation, the taxation of not-for-profit entities and sales/use/value added tax. Prerequisite(s): admission to the Master of Accounting program.

title: for-Profit Accounting
description: 1. This course is an examination of accounting and financial reporting for not-for-profit entities. Focus areas will include the recording, reporting, and evaluation of financial information prepared in accordance with accounting standards as promulgated by the Financial Accounting Board Standards (FASB) as applied to not-for-profit entities. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 302 or equivalent, and admission to the MAcc program.

title: Government Accounting and Reporting
description: 2. An introduction to accounting, financial reporting, and budgeting for state and local government entities. Emphasizes accounting requirements for state and local government entities as issued by the Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB). Prerequisite(s): ACCT 302 or equivalent, and admission to the MAcc program.

title: Advanced Auditing
description: This course emphasizes the application of professional auditing standards, completing the audit process, employing advanced auditing techniques, and identifying the auditor’s role in determining whether publicly issued financial statements are fairly presented. Includes conducting audit procedures using specialized data analysis software. It builds on the knowledge base from an introductory auditing course. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 315 and ACCT 320 or equivalent, and admission to the MAcc program.

title: Professional Communication
description: Prepares students to communicate information, both within the accounting profession and to other stakeholders. Emphasizes developing a business style of writing that includes planning, critical thinking about accounting problems to be solved, organizing ideas, and producing documents or other products designed to accomplish the communicative and archival purposes pertinent to the business situation. Enables students to consider the impact of electronic communication technology on communications and writing in the accounting profession. Prerequisite(s): admission to the MAcc program. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Ethics in Accounting
description: This course examines the moral responsibilities pertinent to membership in the accounting profession, both for individual contributors and for managers of other accounting professionals and businesspeople. Emphasis is placed upon the current ethical standards of the institutions of the accounting profession, the nature of professionalism, and the particular ethical challenges and expectations that pertain to auditing, managerial accounting, and tax accounting. Philosophical and Reformed theological normative frameworks are studied, with a focus on grounding and justifying ethical standards and expectations. Written assignments and class discussion will rehearse students’ capacity for analyzing ethical issues, and for proposing solutions that will be convincing to others. Discussions and readings will explore personal and structural impediments to diversity in the workplace, and highlight best practices in inclusive leadership. Prerequisite(s): admission to the MAcc program.

title: Internship in Accounting
description: Students explore their calling and develop a deeper understanding of their chosen field. Students work an internship, keep a reflective journal, and write a reflection paper. Students must complete at least 50 hours at an internship. This course may be taken up to three times (fall, spring, summer), after admission to the MAcc program. This course is crosslisted as FIN 583 . Prerequisite(s): admission to the MAcc program, a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or better, and approval from both the MAcc Program Director and the organization offering the internship.

title: Accounting Independent Study
description: Independent study of topics of interest to particular students under supervision of a member of the department staff. Open to qualified students with permission of the department chair.

title: Visual Culture
description: This course focuses on how meaning is made through our visual environment. Students study a wide range of visual forms from contexts including architecture, art history, popular culture and advertising, in order to gain a better understanding of how our contemporary experiences and identities are informed and shaped by images. This course will introduce students to visual images and critically examine their various uses in contemporary culture. Class time is a combination of image analysis, image production, lectures, screenings, field trips, and student presentations. Intended for first- and second-year students. Course fee: $50.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Honors Visual Art
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will address works of visual art with the goal of developing two skills as tied to problem solving: effective observation of artistic production and explanation of how specific works of art shape one’s place within a larger community. From year to year, the visual material will vary by media and historical periods and may include studio production. Appropriate methodological tools will be used to explore visual expression as an encounter between makers and viewers. The interdisciplinary component will attend to that expression as structured by conversations in other disciplines.

title: Elementary Art Education
description: Alternate years. This course is an introduction to the field of art education in general as well as art education methods specifically for the elementary school level. This course includes lectures, studio experiences, and collaborative assignments as well as assignments to create art lesson plans, units, and a personal philosophy of art education. Partnership opportunities to work with area school children through service-learning hours are included. Course fee: $50.

title: Secondary Art Education
description: Alternate years. This course introduces students to various methods of teaching art in the secondary school and to professional standards in art education. It will also guide prospective teachers in developing a responsible pedagogical approach that they can call their own. This course includes lectures, studio projects, demonstrations, and art teaching experiences with students from area schools. This final component will be met through service learning hours. Course fee: $75.

title: Exhibition
description: Group exhibition of student work, required of senior art education majors for graduation.

Alternate years. This course introduces students to some of the most notable objects, images, and buildings produced in Europe, Asia, and Africa from around 1250 to 1400. About two-thirds of the course will address Europe, with a third given to Asia and Africa. Religion and its cultural expressions anchor the content, though the course also considers court cultures, luxury goods, and international exchange. Not offered in 2025-26.

Alternate years. This course introduces some of the most notable paintings, prints, and sculpture produced in Europe from the Renaissance to 1700. The course considers how artistic styles and genres served societal and cultural priorities. Artists include the very famous and the less famous. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: and 19th-Century European Art
description: Alternate years. ARTH 133 introduces some of the most notable paintings, prints, and decorative arts produced in Europe from 1700 to 1900. The rise of new public audiences for art, alongside traditional court structures, is a central concern. Gender and the status of women artists are also important themes.

Alternate years. This course introduces key artistic developments in European and American art from 1900 to the 1960s. Questions of modernity—both modern art and modern life—anchor the course, from Post-impressionism to the Harlem Renaissance to Pop Art.

Alternate years. This course provides students with a framework for understanding the Contemporary art scene. Structured around questions and themes, the course explores how artists of the past sixty years have understood the relationship of the visual arts to wider societal conversations. Issues of materiality, concept, point of view, audience, and venue will play a prominent role in the exploration of what it means to be a maker today.

title: History of Design
description: As needed. How do visual conventions developed during the last five hundred years inform what is possible to communicate with an image today? As part of the curriculum of the graphic design major, this course provides a foundation for engaging contemporary visual design in relation to the past five centuries of artistic production. The course attends particularly to the history of printmaking, typography, and compositional conventions, paying special attention to the emergence of consumer cultures and public engagements with print culture, from seventeenth-century broadsides to twentieth-century mass media). Prerequisite(s): ARTH 141 . Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Chinese Art History
description: Alternate years. This course provides an introduction to the visual arts of China. Arranged chronologically, the course focuses on the production of pictures, objects, gardens, and buildings in China. Particular attention will be paid to the role of religion, ritual, and erudition. The course ends with an extended exploration of contemporary Chinese art. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Japanese Art History
description: Alternate years. This course provides an introduction to the visual arts of Japan. The course focuses on the production of pictures, objects, gardens, and buildings in Japan, with an emphasis on aesthetic categories and sensibilities. The course ends with an extended exploration of contemporary Japanese art.

title: Classical Architecture from Antiquity to Now
description: Alternate years. In what style shall we build, and how might classical architecture inform this question? This course traces ancient Greek and Roman architecture from antiquity to its revival in the fifteenth century, its foundational role in the creation of professional schools of architecture in the nineteenth century, and its influence on new construction today. Attending to questions of cultural meaning, including the racial significance of classicism’s troubling histories—whether on American plantations or in Nazi Germany—the course asks how the classical tradition might still productively inform contemporary architecture.

title: Art and Fashion
description: Alternate years. What do people wear, and why? This course explores the past five centuries of fashion history with an eye toward understanding today’s sartorial conventions. The course starts from a commitment to the simple proposition that clothing matters a lot. Attending to ethical questions of production as well as consumption, the course addresses five major themes: the mediation of the body, gender representations, style, modernist constructions of consumer culture, and performance. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: ARTS 255
description: Introducing design as an artistic practice that requires both physical making and digital exploration, Graphic Design 1 takes students into the initial steps of typographic experimentation with an emphasis on the processes that anchor graphic design. Typographic form—the use of letters, words, and phrases for compositional effects—is introduced through analysis and manipulation, using established methods, rules, conventions, and procedures. Students will build visual narratives that combine words and images. They also will begin to develop verbal aptitude through regular group critiques. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 254 or permission of the instructor, based on a portfolio review. Course fee: $50.

title: Introduction to Drawing
description: This course focuses on observational drawing to develop working methods based in seeing. Students will use a variety of materials and techniques to pursue growth through process, practice and critical reflection. Contemporary art and art theory are addressed through images and readings, so students will gain an understanding of various practices in drawing and investigate its conceptual possibilities for their own development. Intended for first- and second-year students. Course fee: $200.

title: Introduction to Painting
description: This course introduces students to painting techniques and concepts with an emphasis on the formal language of the medium within a fine art context. Plein-air landscape painting in oil will anchor the course, along with still life and figuratives assignments. Color theory, linear perspective, compositional structure, figure/ground relationships, visual perception, spatial concepts, and critical thinking skills are all central concerns. As an introduction, the course emphasizes painting as the art of recording observations and experiences rather than the creation of highly finished products. The course will also address visual, technical, and conceptual concerns through readings, discussions, demonstrations, and critiques. Course fee: $275.

title: Introduction to Printmaking
description: This course introduces students to the methodologies and concepts of intaglio printmaking as a foundation for understanding the significance of print strategies within contemporary art. Students will learn how to prepare and manipulate metal plates, print multiple images from a matrix, and curate editions. Processes covered are monotype, drypoint, hard and soft ground etching, and aquatint. In addition, students learn about the properties of handmade and industrially produced paper. The course emphasizes conceptual implications of print, non-toxic techniques, and how to work in the environment of a print shop. Course fee: $100.

title: Introduction to Graphic Design
description: Students are introduced to the basics of design principles and vocabulary, and to the Adobe Creative Suite (including Illustrator, InDesign, and Photoshop) as a tool for handling a range of visual images aimed at communicative effects. In addition to the development of foundational technical skills, the course introduces conceptual approaches to design strategies with both practical and theoretical applications. Course fee: $50.

title: Graphic Design 1: Process
description: Introducing design as an artistic practice that requires both physical making and digital exploration, Graphic Design 1 takes students into the initial steps of typographic experimentation with an emphasis on the processes that anchor graphic design. Typographic form—the use of letters, words, and phrases for compositional effects—is introduced through analysis and manipulation, using established methods, rules, conventions, and procedures. Students will build visual narratives that combine words and images. They also will begin to develop verbal aptitude through regular group critiques. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 254 or permission of the instructor, based on a portfolio review. Course fee: $50.

title: Introduction to Photography
description: An introduction to basic photographic techniques and the process of black and white photography including camera operation, film processing, printing, and presentation. Course work emphasizes visual problems and solutions specific to photography, such as flatness, frame, time, and focus. The ability to produce photographic images with visual effectiveness through control and execution of the media is stressed. Visual and technical abilities will be reinforced through readings, discussions, demonstrations, critiques, and lectures. The history of photography and critical approaches to the media will be introduced and inform the context of study. Course fee: $250.

title: Introduction to Sculpture
description: This class introduces the medium of sculpture through a variety of materials and techniques, building skill sets as well as developing problem solving and decision making. The sculpture process is concerned with form, space, presence, objecthood, the body, time, and place. Students will learn to critically examine the medium of sculpture through discussions and critiques. We will discuss contemporary work and theory within the art historical context, and attempt to achieve a relevant definition of sculpture. Through theory, practice, and discussion we will understand how to use and develop our gifts in order to glorify God and seek shalom. Course fee: $200.

title: Introduction to Ceramics
description: This course introduces students to the basic components of ceramics, including the construction of three-dimensional forms and the organization of space. Students will learn traditional and contemporary methods of working with clay and glazes. Course work addresses visual problems and solutions specific to ceramics, the texture of materials, and the manipulation of space. Visual acuity and technical abilities will be reinforced through readings, discussions, demonstrations, critiques, and lectures. The history of ceramics and critical approaches to the media will lead to an understanding of how three-dimensional forms give shape to ideas and beliefs. Course fee: $275.

title: Intermediate Drawing
description: A further exploration of the activity of drawing. This course emphasizes the critical engagement of visual problems and solutions through the development of a drawing portfolio. The primary source material for this course is the human figure, utilized for visual and technical investigation of pictorial space, as well as for contemporary critical issues surrounding the representation of the self and others. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 250 . Course fee: $200.

title: Intermediate Painting
description: A further exploration of painting ideas and media. This course emphasizes the critical engagement of visual problems and solutions through the development of a painting portfolio. Students will be expected to participate in ongoing group and individual critiques, discussions of assigned readings, and contribute to the dialogue in a bi-weekly painting seminar. Through critical engagement of contemporary painting practices, this course initiates patterns of individual research in the production of a painting portfolio. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 251 . Course fee: $50.

title: Graphic Design 2: Structures
description: Equipped with a basic typographic proficiency, students in this course will hone their technical and conceptual skills through close examination of the structural elements of design. Hierarchy, grid systems, and organizational strategies are central concerns. Complex communication problems are addressed, incorporating formal and expressive typography, pictorial imagery, and personal narratives. Conceptually, distinctions between the analysis of form and the meanings of form are explored. Assignments range from the production of a multi-page publication using InDesign to the development of a design project using found materials. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 255 . Course fee: $50.

title: Analogue Photography
description: A further exploration of the visual and technical aspects of the photographic medium, with study of critical theory specific to analogue photography. A variety of professional equipment, processes and advanced techniques will also be introduced. Course work includes readings, demonstrations, and lectures through the production of effective photographic images. Photographic criticism is addressed through readings, lectures, studio assignments, critiques, and a final project. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 256 . Course fee: $250.

title: Intermediate Sculpture
description: A further investigation of the visual and technical aspects of sculptural media and organization of space. This course will require the production of a portfolio of sculptural objects. Special attention will be given to the use of particular production methods, issues of presentation, and the relationship between concept and process. Critical theory specific to sculpture is addressed through readings, lectures, and class projects. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 257 . Course fee: $200.

title: Intermediate Ceramics
description: A further investigation of the visual and technical aspects of clay, glazes, and other media. This course will require the production of a portfolio of ceramic objects. Special attention will be given to the use of particular production methods, issues of presentation, and the relationship between concept and process. Critical theory specific to ceramics is addressed through readings, lectures, and class projects. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 258 . Course fee: $275.

title: Digital Photography
description: An exploration of the visual and technical aspects of photography with an emphasis on digital media. A study of critical theory specific to digital photography will be addressed. Topics covered will include digital image acquisition, manipulation, storage, and display. Course work includes readings, demonstrations, and lecture through intensive production of digital images. Criticism is addressed through readings, lectures, studio assignments, critiques, and a final project. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 256 . Course fee: $250.

title: Advanced Drawing
description: This course addresses individual research and conceptual problem solving through the production of a cohesive portfolio of drawings. Students will be encouraged to experiment with the use of new technologies and non-traditional drawing media. In addition to discussions of assigned readings, students will participate in ongoing group and individual critiques that will focus on the individual development and critical understanding of drawn images and ideas. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 300 . Course fee: $100.

title: Advanced Painting
description: A further investigation of painting ideas and media. This course emphasizes individual research and conceptual problem solving through the production of a portfolio of paintings. In addition to helping lead the bi-weekly seminar on contemporary issues in painting, students will participate in ongoing group and individual critiques focused on the development of images and ideas toward a cohesive painting portfolio. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 301 . Course fee: $50.

title: Graphic Design 3: Systems
description: Building upon processes and structures, students in this course will develop an integrated branding campaign that requires them to work in terms of systems. Students will explore individual methods and techniques for manipulating typography, symbols, illustrations, and photographs. Emphasis is placed on honing graphic design research skills with an eye toward solving practical and conceptual problems. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 305 . Course fee: $50.

title: Advanced Photography
description: An emphasis on individual research and conceptual problem solving in the production of a coherent body of analogue and/or digital photographic work. Class time will consist of critiques on the quality of concept and presentation of idea in student images, in addition to discussions of critical readings. Students will be evaluated on a photography production and a class presentation. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 306 or ARTS 316 . Course fee: $250.

title: Advanced Sculpture
description: This course directs individual research in the production of a cohesive body of sculptural work. Requirements include regular critiques of works in progress and discussions of techniques and critical readings. Student portfolios will be evaluated on the basis of craft, concept, and presentation. Students will examine possible ways in which they can make contributions to the field of sculpture and visual culture. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 307 . Course fee: $200.

title: Advanced Ceramics
description: This course directs individual research in the production of a cohesive body of ceramic work. Requirements include regular critiques of works in progress, discussions of techniques, and critical readings. Student portfolios will be evaluated on the basis of craft, concept, and presentation. Students will examine possible ways in which they can make contributions to the field of ceramics and visual culture. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 308 . Course fee: $275.

title: Graphic Design 4: Portfolio
description: Students will develop new pieces and refine existing pieces from their body of work and prepare a professional portfolio for graduation. Presentation tactics, identity systems, and professional preparation will be central concerns. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 355 or permission of the instructor.

title: Graphic Design 5: Thesis / Special Topics
description: Students will engage in a semester-long, directed, research-based project culminating in a group exhibition. Students are encouraged to pursue methods, techniques, and processes that are of particular interest for them. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 355 or permission of the instructor.

title: Internship in Graphic Design
description: Tutorial. Internships involve a minimum of eight hours of work a week for eight weeks (or equivalent) in a professional setting with an approved employer-supervisor in a business or nonprofit organization. At a minimum, students will meet three times with the instructor overseeing the internship, complete a self-assessment assignment, and produce a significant portfolio addition. This course may be taken for one or three credits, depending upon the scope of the work involved. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 255 .

title: Internship in Visual Studies
description: Tutorial. A practicum in which students work a minimum of ten hours per week for one semester in an art-related field under the supervision of a studio artist, professional designer, or gallery director. Students will also meet regularly with an instructor on campus to address lessons learned. To enroll in this course, students must submit a written proposal to the chair for approval. This course is not intended for students concentrating in communication design. Prerequisite(s): five Art Studio courses and departmental approval.

title: Global Perspectives in Graphic Design
description: WI. This international study course will immerse students in the world of graphic design through a lens of cultural exploration, artistic intervention, and collaborative engagement. Participants will explore the theme of embeddedness—how graphic design interacts with culture, space, and history—while also engaging in creative artistic interventions that transform or challenge these environments. Through exploration, research, and collaboration with local artists, designers, educators, and communities, students will develop a deep understanding of global context for design. This course will allow students to not only hone their individual design skills but also collaborate in a cross-cultural environment to push the boundaries of graphic design as an art form. The subsequent spring course, ARTS 387 , will produce a final exhibition showcasing the collective works of the student participants. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 355 or approval of the instructor. Course fee: varies.

title: Global Perspectives in Graphic Design: Exhibition
description: Alternate years. This course introduces students to the principles and practices of exhibition design with an emphasis on the role of graphic design. It integrates theoretical and practical components, focusing on the creation of immersive, visually compelling experiences within physical spaces. Students will engage in collaborative design processes and explore the potential for artistic intervention with a multidisciplinary approach. This spring course will produce a final exhibition showcasing the collective works of the student participants in the winter intensive course, ARTS 386 . Prerequisite(s): ARTS 386 . Course fee: varies.

title: Independent Study in Studio Art
description: An advanced course providing opportunities for investigating the use of new techniques or new materials, including mixed-media. To enroll in this course, students must submit a written proposal to the chair for approval. Prerequisite(s): five Art Studio courses and departmental approval. Course fee may apply, depending on the project.

title: Senior Seminar in Studio Art
description: This capstone seminar course for all seniors majoring in studio art examines the integral relationship between the production of visual images and issues of faith. Students will investigate contemporary theories and practices in art production and criticism, while refining their own faith-centered studio practice. In addition, students will address ethical issues related to art making as they prepare for professional careers in art-related fields. Presentations, selected readings and class discussions; completion of a professional art portfolio and artist statement is required.

title: Exhibition
description: Group exhibition of student work, required of senior studio art majors and BFA candidates. Art education students exhibit in the fall semester. All other majors in the spring. Prerequisite(s): ARTS 395 .

title: Planets, Stars, and Galaxies
description: A survey of the major astronomical objects, including planets, stars, and galaxies, a study of their characteristics and their organization into a dynamic, structured universe, an investigation of the processes now occurring in the universe and the methods used to study them, a presentation of the history and development of the universe. The course examines scientific perspectives on the natural world, various relationships between science and culture, the role of Christianity in the development of science, and relationships between Christianity and current scientific findings. Not open to students who have taken, or expect to take, ASTR 111 or ASTR 112 . Students who meet the prerequisites of ASTR 201 or ASTR 211 are encouraged to take one of those courses instead.

title: The Solar System
description: This course is similar to ASTR 110 in providing an introduction to astronomy from a Christian perspective, but emphasizes the contents of our solar system (ranging from planets and satellites down to meteorites and dust), their interrelatedness, and their development over time. Not open to students who have taken ASTR 110 , but open to students who have taken or plan to take ASTR 112 . Students who meet the prerequisites of ASTR 201 or ASTR 211 are encouraged to take one of those courses instead.

title: The Solar System Laboratory
description: Lab fee: $125.

title: Stars, Galaxies, and the Universe
description: This course is similar to ASTR 110 in providing an introduction to astronomy from a Christian perspective, but emphasizes objects beyond our solar system (including stars, black holes, and galaxies), their function and development, and how they fit into the structure and development of the universe as a whole. Not open to students who have taken ASTR 110 , but open to students who have taken or plan to take ASTR 111 . Students who meet the prerequisites of ASTR 201 or ASTR 211 are encouraged to take one of these courses instead.

title: Stars, Galaxies, and the Universe Lab
description: Lab fee: $125.

title: Astrophysical Black Holes
description: Alternate years. The study of black holes has undergone enormous progress in recent years as recognized by the Nobel physics prizes awarded in 2017 and 2020. This course will explore all aspects of astrophysical black holes: their basis in general relativity, the formation of both stellar-mass and supermassive black holes, the accretion disks and relativistic jets that form around them, and the means by which they may be observed. These topics will be supplemented by overviews of stellar and galactic astronomy that provide the settings in which black holes are found. Prerequisite(s): one course in college calculus (such as MATH 132 or MATH 171 ) and one course in high school or college physics, or permission of the instructor.

title: Astrophysical Black Holes Lab
description: Alternate years. Lab fee: $125.

title: Planetary and Stellar Astronomy
description: Alternate years. This course is an introduction to modern astronomy and astrophysics for students with some science and mathematics preparation. The first portion of the course includes a study of the planets and other objects in the solar system, including their physical processes and development and the formation of the solar system as a whole. The second portion of the course emphasizes the physical structure of stars, their origin and development, and their end results (white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes). Students may take both ASTR 211 and ASTR 212 , but one is not a prerequisite for the other. Prerequisite(s): one course in college calculus (such as MATH 132 or MATH 171 ) and one course in high school or college physics, or permission of the instructor. Corequisite(s): ASTR 211L .

title: Planetary and Stellar Astronomy Lab
description: Alternate years. Lab fee: $125.

title: Galactic Astronomy and Cosmology
description: Alternate years. This course is an introduction to modern astronomy and astrophysics for students with some science and mathematics preparation. The first portion of the course includes a study of our own Galaxy, its structure, its contents (including the interstellar medium and dark matter), and its formation and development. The second portion of the course covers other galaxies, including their classification, clustering, and development, as well as active galaxies and quasars. The final portion of the course covers physical cosmology, including expansion of the universe, its age and ultimate fate, and the formation of elements. Students may take both ASTR 211 and this course, but one is not a prerequisite for the other. Prerequisite(s): one course in college calculus (such as MATH 132 or MATH 171 ) and one course in high school or college physics, or permission of the instructor.

title: Galactic Astronomy and Cosmology Lab
description: Alternate years. Lab fee: $125.

title: Modern Observational Astronomy
description: Alternate years. Students will learn techniques of modern observational astronomy by doing observing projects in each of three wavelength regimes: optical, radio, and one other (e.g., x-ray). Optical observations will use CCD detectors to do multi-color photography, photometry, astrometry, and spectroscopy. Radio observations made with the Very Large Array will be used for interferometric imaging. NASA archival data will be used for other wavelengths. Prerequisite(s): ASTR 211 or ASTR 212 (may be taken concurrently). Lab fee: $125.

title: Independent Study
description: Independent readings and research in astronomy. Prerequisite(s): a faculty sponsor and permission of the chair.

title: Astronomy Research, Writing, and Presentation
description: Completion of an approved experimental or theoretical research with presentation of results. The research may be done entirely as part of this course or through another avenue (e.g., summer research with a faculty member). Normally, each student is required to submit a formal, written report and to present results in a department seminar and/or poster presentation. This course may be taken up to three times. Prerequisite(s): Prerequisites: A faculty sponsor and approval of the department.

title: Honors Biology
description: Alternate years. In this course, students will investigate a variety of contemporary topics and challenges within the field of biology. Students will learn foundational biological concepts, develop and appreciation for the investigatory process of science as a value-laden collaborative enterprise, explore the reliability of scientific knowledge, and consider social and ethical aspects of scientific methodologies and findings. This course is a part of the Honors Scholars Core curriculum. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Contemporary Topics in Biology
description: This course addresses a variety of advanced topics that are important in contemporary biological disciplines (e.g., detailed study of specific taxonomic groups, emerging fields of biological inquiry, and more). Lectures, discussions, readings, and laboratory/field studies provide students with advanced conceptual knowledge and practical experiences that develop important vocational skills. Course work centers around scientific literature, investigation, and communication.

title: Essentials of Human Anatomy and Physiology
description: This course is a study of the major theories of biology as applied to human beings. The student is introduced to the concepts of cell biology, genetics, ecology, and evolution through the study of anatomy, physiology, and development of the human body and health. Students apply these concepts to contemporary issues in human biology, society, and the environment. Laboratory activities utilize methods of biological investigation, with an emphasis on human anatomy and physiology. Three two-hour sessions weekly. Lab fee: $170.

title: Living Systems
description: Students construct comprehensive understandings of human interactions with living systems, interconnecting foundational biological concepts to contemporary scientific, societal, ethical, and religious issues. Topics covered include ecological and evolutionary systems (climate change, biodiversity, ecosystem health, natural selection, extinction), human health (nutrition, chronic and infectious diseases, allergies), genetics (mutation, meiosis, heredity, race), and stem cells (mitosis, gene expression). Problem-based learning approaches are employed in this course to examine complex societal challenges, with contemporary problems setting the context for readings and discussions that facilitate investigating, thinking, and applying.

title: Ecological and Evolutionary Systems
description: The basic concepts in ecological and evolutionary biology. Topics include: population ecology and genetics, community ecology, evolutionary processes and speciation, phylogenetics, adaptive biology, ecosystem dynamics, environmental degradation and environmental sustainability, and biodiversity. Students develop critical thinking skills by applying these concepts to biological challenges and problems at local, regional, and global scales. Lectures, in-class activities, and discussions. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 101 or CHEM 103 (either may be taken concurrently). Corequisite(s): BIOL 160L .

title: Ecological and Evolutionary Systems Lab
description: Laboratories make use of prevailing methodologies to address interesting questions about organisms as complex adaptive systems, thereby giving students insights into the practice of contemporary ecological, evolutionary, and organismal biology research. Corequisite(s): BIOL 160 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Cellular and Genetic Systems
description: A presentation of the basic concepts in cellular and molecular biology and genetics. Topics include: structure and function of cells and macromolecules; energy and metabolism; cell division and regulation; DNA replication, transcription and translation; genetics; control of gene expression; and cellular mechanisms of development. Students develop critical thinking skills by applying these concepts to a broad array of bioscience problems. Laboratories consist of integrative science research projects that instill scientific competencies and proficiency with the prevailing methodologies in the cellular and molecular biosciences. BIOL 161 and BIOL 161L are required courses for biology majors. Prerequisite(s): Corequisite or Prerequisite: CHEM 101 or CHEM 103 . Corequisite(s): Corequisite: BIOL 161L .

title: Cellular and Genetic Systems Lab
description: Students use prevailing methods to conduct lab experiments that test the effects of cooking on compounds with nutritional and other health benefits, thereby developing competencies for contemporary cellular and molecular biology research. Corequisite(s): Corequisite: BIOL 161 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Research Design and Methodology
description: A combination of field, greenhouse and laboratory studies designed to familiarize students with research at both the cellular and ecological levels of organization. Emphasis will be on framing research questions, experimental design and data interpretation with reference to published literature, and on the presentation and communication of scientific data. Under faculty direction student teams will develop their own research projects and present the results of their work in written and oral reports. Social, ethical, and theological implications of the results of research will be explored. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 160 ; BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 ; STAT 143 or STAT 145 (recommended). Corequisite(s): BIOL 295 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Introduction to Animal Physiology
description: An exploration of the physiological function of animals that builds upon ecological and cellular biology concepts and lays a foundation for more advanced studies in the upper-level biology courses. This course focuses on vertebrate physiology and seeks to help students understand how cells, organs, and organ systems interact to maintain homeostasis. Major topics include endocrine signaling, neuronal function, sensory systems, muscle contraction, gas exchange, circulation, and reproduction. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 161 or BIOL 141 ; CHEM 102 or CHEM 103 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 231L .

title: Introduction to Animal Physiology Lab
description: Students conduct physiological experiments with animal systems to address interesting physiological questions using prevailing research methods and interpreting their data in light of core physiological concepts. Corequisite(s): BIOL 231 . Lab fee: $85.

title: Introduction to Plant Physiology
description: An exploration of the physiological function of plants that builds upon ecological and cellular biology concepts and lays a foundation for more advanced studies in the upper-level biology courses. The course will focus on angiosperms and gymnosperms, seeking to inform students of basic plant morphology and anatomy (structure) that leads to understanding of growth requirements and physiological processes of plants (function). Understanding the processes by which plants grow and develop connects students to topics such as ecosystem function, physical transfer of solar to chemical energy, nutrition and human health. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 ; CHEM 102 , CHEM 103 , or CHEM 160 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 232L .

title: Introduction to Plant Physiology Lab
description: Students conduct physiological experiments with plant systems to address interesting physiological questions using prevailing research methods and interpreting their data in light of core physiological concepts. Corequisite(s): BIOL 232 . Lab fee: $85.

title: Advanced Human Anatomy Lab
description: This laboratory course involves a detailed study of human gross anatomy that builds on prior anatomical knowledge from other courses. Students will work in small teams to perform guided dissections of human cadavers to study tissues, organs, and organ systems. Particular attention will be paid to typical anatomical configurations, but with discussion of anatomical variants, pathological conditions, age-related changes, and clinical applications when possible. Areas of focus will include articulations, muscles, neural pathways, vasculature, and organs of the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavities. Prerequisite(s): a grade of B- or better in either BIOL 205 or BIOL 323 . Lab fee: $300.

title: Advanced Human Physiology and Pathophysiology
description: Alternate years. Physiology is the study of normal body function and pathophysiology is the study of how a body’s function changes when disease occurs. Students in this course will be introduced to the biochemical or cellular mechanisms by which the human body normally functions, the structural and functional changes that occur in diseased states, and the impact of these changes on overall health. Normal function and diseases of the cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, hormonal, muscular, neural, renal, reproductive, and respiratory systems will be investigated using a classic organ system approach and case studies. Current research literature will be emphasized. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 206 or BIOL 231 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 306L .

title: Advanced Human Physiology and Pathophysiology Lab
description: Alternate years. Students will investigate physiological processes of healthy and diseased systems, considering outcomes at the cellular, tissue, and organism levels. Methods employed will include simulations, microscopic analysis of prepared tissue samples and evaluation of case studies. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 206 or BIOL 231 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 306 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Paleontology
description: Even years. Paleontology is the study of the organisms that once lived on Earth. This course includes an examination of structure, habitat and relationships of those organisms, as well as a review of their distribution and life history. Processes of preservation are also examined. A broad spectrum of organisms is studied with emphasis on invertebrate animals. Also listed as GEO 313 . Prerequisite(s): GEO 152 or BIOL 160 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 313L .

title: Paleontology Lab
description: Even years. Students learn from close observation, examination, and drawing many fossil specimens over the semester. Labs focus on the characteristics of approximately 20 phyla of macroscopic plants and animals, as well as others that are traditionally classified as “microfossils.” Crosslisted as GEO 313L . Corequisite(s): BIOL 313 or GEO 313 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Genetics and Development
description: How do we explain the vast diversity in form and function between species? How do we explain variations, including genetic diseases, observed within the human population? Neither question can be addressed effectively without an understanding of genetics and development. This course examines the nature of biological inheritance and the genetic bases of development with a particular emphasis on human genetics. Learning activities will focus on understanding the genetic material and its expression, and will include lectures, problem-solving, and class discussions of scientific papers. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 321L .

title: Songwriting Seminar
description: Alternate years. A course exploring the craft of popular song writing in a seminar context where students both study existing songs and create new songs of their own. In addition to learning techniques related to writing and analyzing lyrics, melodies, chords, and arrangements, students will learn practical skills related to the industry, such as collaboration, writing lead sheets, copywriting creative work, and using tools and technology relevant to song writing. By the end of the semester each student will create a demo of at least one song they have written. Prerequisite(s): MUSC 100 or permission of the instructor. Course fee: $50.

title: Vocal and Choral Techniques
description: Alternate years. Study of vocal and choral techniques for music education majors. Emphasis is on developing practical singing skills needed for classroom teaching and choral rehearsal leadership. Students will receive training in the techniques necessary for healthy singing together with methods for teaching age-appropriate vocal techniques to children and students in elementary, middle school, and high school choirs. Healthy vocal technique for music theatre and popular music will also be considered.

title: Teaching Choral Music
description: Alternate years. A course in the development and administration of choral programs in PK-12 schools. Choice of repertoire, rehearsal techniques, concert preparation are covered. Consideration of age-appropriate music. Strategies for effective building of inclusive choral programs that provide meaningful musical experiences for all learners. Application of Reformed Christian perspectives to all areas of the elementary, middle, and high school choral program are discussed. Prerequisite(s): MUSC 341 .

title: Teaching Instrumental Music
description: Alternate years. A course in the development and administration of instrumental programs in PK-12 schools. Choice of repertoire, rehearsal techniques, concert preparation are covered. Consideration of age-appropriate music. Strategies for effective building of inclusive instrumental programs that provide meaningful musical experiences for all learners. Application of Reformed Christian perspectives to all areas of the elementary, middle, and high school instrumental program are discussed. Prerequisite(s): MUSC 295 , MUSC 296 , MUSC 297 , and MUSC 298 . (MUSC 296 may be taken concurrently.)

title: Full Recital
description: A public performance of a minimum of 50 minutes of music. Prerequisite(s): four semesters of MUSC 260 and permission of the private-lesson instructor and area coordinator. Corequisite(s): MUSC 260 . Recital fee (only for recitals not required by degree program): $100.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in Music department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the Music department.

title: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite(s): permission of the department chair.

title: credit Private Lessons
description: Course includes twelve 30-minute sessions of private instruction in applied music. Lessons are pass/fail. Lessons fee: $435.

title: credit Private Lessons
description: Course includes twelve 60-minute sessions of private instruction in applied music. Lessons are pass/fail. Lessons fee: $820.

title: Piano Accompanying in Worship
description: Offered based on demand. Twelve 30-minute private lessons in effective leadership of congregational singing from the piano. Also includes instruction in other kinds of accompanying that occurs in worship and some study of appropriate solo repertory. Prerequisite(s): MUSC 030 , MUSC 060 , MUSC 260 , or permission of the instructor. Lessons fee: $900.

title: Composition Lessons for Credit
description: Course includes 12 hour-long sessions of private instruction in composition. In addition to preparation for weekly lessons, students will be expected to participate in studio classes with fellow composition students, write scores for their compositions using music notation software, and organize performances or recordings of their work for evaluation. Prerequisite(s): MUSC 108 and MUSC 225 , or permission of the instructor. Lessons fee: $900.

title: Private Lessons for Credit
description: Course includes 12 sixty-minute sessions of private instruction in applied music. In addition to preparation for weekly lessons, students will be expected to participate in studio classes, perform in joint student recitals, and take a jury (final performance exam) at the end of the semester. Prerequisite(s): Complete performance screening prior to first semester enrollment, or permission of instructor. Lessons fee: $900.

title: Jazz Band
description: Representative works in jazz band literature are studied and prepared for concert performance. Open to all students who meet the demands of musicianship. Course fee: $100.

title: Collaborative Musicianship
description: Study and performance of music for small ensembles. Instrumentalists, pianists, and singers may take this course. Students are expected to participate in the selection of music to be studied and to assume leadership in organizing ensembles, rehearsing, and performing, with guidance and support provided by music faculty. Open to all students who meet the demands of musicianship. Course fee: $100.

title: Campus Choir
description: Study and performance of choral literature related to the practice of Christian worship throughout the history of the church and in many cultures. Emphasis on vocal and musical development, as well as on the theological, historical, and liturgical dimensions of selected choral repertoire. Open to all students who meet the requirements of voice and musicianship. Course fee: $100.

title: Capella
description: Representative works in the field of choral literature are studied and prepared for concert performance. Membership is maintained at a set limit and is open only to those who meet the demands of voice, sight reading, and choral musicianship. Prerequisite(s): ordinarily, one year of experience in a college choir. Course fee: $100.

title: Symphonic Band
description: Representative works in the concert band literature are studied and prepared for performance. Open to all students, faculty, staff, alumni, and community musicians who have previous high school band experience and wish to participate. Prerequisite(s): high school band experience. Course fee: $100.

title: Marching Band
description: An ensemble devoted to rehearsing and performing a wide range of music for marching band and athletic band at Calvin University athletic events. Attendance at a pre-semester camp is required. Prerequisite(s): high school band experience. Course fee: $100.

title: Pep Band
description: First half. This ensemble meets two days per week. A broad range of pep-band literature is rehearsed and performed at home basketball games and other campus events. Membership is open to all instrumentalists who have previous high school band experience. Purchase of some attire and/or instrument accessories may be necessary. Prerequisite(s): high school band experience. Course fee: $100.

title: Wind Ensemble
description: Representative works in the chamber wind and concert band literature are studied and prepared for concert performance. Membership is limited to a set instrumentation and is open to all students who meet the demands of musicianship. Depending upon repertoire, some students will also be assigned to rehearse and perform with the Calvin Orchestra. Prerequisite(s): high school band experience. Instructor assignment determined by high musicianship. Course fee: $100.

title: Orchestra
description: Representative works in the field of chamber and symphony orchestra literature are studied and prepared for concert performance. Membership is open to all students who have high school or college orchestra experience and wish to participate. Prerequisite(s): high school orchestra experience. Course fee: $100.

title: Oratorio Chorus
description: The study of representative works of the great masters of choral writing with a view to public performance with orchestra. Handel’s Messiah is performed annually at Christmas. Open to all who meet the requirements of voice and musicianship. Course fee: $100.

title: Gospel Choir
description: Culty-directed vocal ensemble performing representative music in this particular genre and in preparation for concert appearances. Open to all students who meet the requirements of voice and musicianship. Course fee: $100.

title: Women's Chorale
description: A women’s honor choir open to all classes devoted to singing a wide range of challenging treble literature, both sacred and secular. Membership is maintained at a set limit and is open only to those who meet the demands of voice, sight reading, and choral musicianship. This ensemble tours, presents concerts and leads worship services. Course fee: $100.

title: Collegium Musicum
description: Offered upon sufficient demand. An ensemble for the study and performance of instrumental and vocal music of the Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque periods. Reproductions of early wind, string, percussion, and keyboard instruments are used. Open to all students who meet the demands of musicianship. Course fee: $100.

title: Nonprofit Boards and Community Leadership
description: 1. Nonprofit board of directors are integral to the process of governing and achieving effective community collaborations and public/private partnerships. This course incorporates and applies organizational behavior and theory to explore the leadership role, responsibilities, and interaction between board members and the executive director. Areas of examination include a comparison of different governing models, key questions to consider in board selection and composition, the responsibilities of advisory boards, working with committees, and the expectations of the board in the area of fundraising. Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program.

title: Nonprofit Financial Management
description: 1. Why are some nonprofit organizations more efficient and stewardly than others? This course establishes a foundation in financial management for those with minimal or no experience in accounting. Areas of emphasis include knowledge and skills needed for distributing and managing resources, and for performing and using analyses and reports to effectively steward the financial health of the organization. Topics include key accounting principles, an overview of financial statements and how they are used in the budget development process and cash flow analysis, understanding the audit report, maximizing investment policy, and the responsibilities regarding government compliance. All of these will be looked at through the lens of ethical standards. Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program.

title: Designing an Effective Nonprofit Organization
description: 1. Nonprofit organizations, whether newly developed or established, need to incorporate methods and processes to be sustainable, This course focuses on how to design a nonprofit organization capable of raising the human and financial resources to sustain the organization as well as emerging methods for effective programming and specific nonprofit evaluation methods. Learn the various aspects of resource development including fund-raising strategies, processes, trends and ethics, public and private grant writing, submission, measurement and evaluation. The course emphasizes the examination of current trends in earned-income strategies, social entrepreneurship, and maximizing available ‘corporate social responsibility’ resources. Underscoring the importance of volunteers in achieving nonprofit goals, the course also focuses on approaches to volunteer development, volunteer recruitment, training, retention/theories of motivation, and leadership and certain ethical issues associated with volunteers. Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program

title: Fundamentals of Patient Care
description: WI, SU, depending on on-campus residential arrangements.. This class reviews the basics of patient caregiving and will prepare learners to take the CNA certification test if desired. This intensive course will consist of a minimum of 75 hours of combined classroom, laboratory, and clinical hours. Relational competencies along with the clinical skills mastered will develop skilled providers of personal care in a geriatric setting. The classroom instruction taught from a Reformed perspective will be integrated with a minimum of 16 hours of direct patient care during the clinical time at Holland Home. Prerequisite(s): required immunizations, TB test, and background checks. Course fee: $120.

title: Theory: Introduction to Professional Nursing
description: This course introduces students to the profession of nursing within the Reformed Christian worldview. Students will explore holistic care, care within the context of the community, evidenced-based practice, and basic concepts of clinical judgment. Corequisite(s): NURS 205 .

title: Nursing Lab
description: In this lab, nursing students will begin to develop skills in health assessment, therapeutic communication, and foundations of clinical judgment. Corequisite(s): NURS 201 .

title: Theory: Developing Professional Nursing Practice
description: In this theory course, students continue to learn about the profession of nursing within the Reformed Christian worldview. Students will be introduced to the health care delivery system, care coordination, ethical decision making and health care technology. Students will also expand their knowledge base of holistic care, evidence-based practice, and clinical judgment. Prerequisite(s): NURS 201 and NURS 205 . Corequisite(s): NURS 302 , NURS 303 , and NURS 305 . Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Based Nursing
description: This course provides the student with an off-campus practicum experience providing community-based nursing in one of the nursing department’s partnership neighborhoods. The student will have the opportunity to promote health and wellness, prevent disease, consider principles of care coordination, and provide basic chronic disease management for persons across the lifespan and within the context of the community. Prerequisite(s): NURS 201 and NURS 205 . Corequisite(s): NURS 301 , NURS 303 , and NURS 305 . Program fee: $819.50.

title: Theory: Mental Health Nursing
description: In this theory course, students will explore the foundations of mental health nursing within the context of the community and interprofessional team. Students will learn strategies to prevent and care for acute and chronic conditions including basic principles of pharmacology and categories of psychotropic drugs. Prerequisite(s): NURS 201 , and NURS 205 . Corequisite(s): NURS 301 , NURS 304 , and NURS 305 .

title: Practicum: Mental Health Nursing
description: This course provides the student with an off-campus practicum experience in mental health nursing across the continuum of care using a variety of acute and community settings. Prerequisite(s): NURS 201 and NURS 205 . Corequisite(s): NURS 301 , NURS 303 , and NURS 305 . Program fee: $819.50.

title: Lab, Sim, and Clinical Reasoning Sem: Comm & Mental Health
description: This course weaves together lab, simulation, and a clinical reasoning seminar. Informed by the Reformed Christian worldview, students will demonstrate progress toward achieving competency in clinical judgment, collaborating with the interprofessional team, promoting care coordination, and integrating health technologies and informatics to promote safe care. Students will practice within health promotion / disease prevention and chronic disease spheres of care. Prerequisite(s): NURS 201 and NURS 205 . Corequisite(s): NURS 301 , NURS 302 , NURS 303 , and NURS 304 .

title: Transition to Nursing: Learning Strategies for Success
description: This course introduces students to thinking, learning, testing strategies, and metacognition that are required to be successful in the nursing program. Students will learn how to utilize clinical decision making strategies within patient care situations. Students will become familiar with test taking strategies used in evaluation, such as NCLEX and NexGen style questions. Prerequisite(s): admission to the nursing major. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Theory: Nursing Care of Pregnant Women and Newborns
description: In this theory course, students will explore the foundations of caring for pregnant women, newborns, and women of childbearing age within the context of the community and health care system. Students will learn pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic strategies to prevent and care for acute and chronic conditions. Prerequisite(s): NURS 301 , NURS 302 , NURS 303 , NURS 304 , and NURS 305 . Corequisite(s): NURS 322 and NURS 325 .

title: Practicum: Nursing Care of Pregnant Women and Newborns
description: This course provides the student with an off-campus practicum experience providing nursing care for pregnant women, newborns, and women of childbearing age across the continuum of care using a variety of acute and community settings. Prerequisite(s): NURS 301 , NURS 302 , NURS 303 , NURS 304 , and NURS 305 . Corequisite(s): NURS 321 and NURS 325 . Program fee: $819.50.

title: Theory: Nursing Care of Children
description: In this theory course, students will explore the foundations of caring for infants, children, and adolescents within the context of the community and the health care team. Students will learn pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic strategies to prevent and care for acute and chronic conditions. Prerequisite(s): NURS 301 , NURS 302 , NURS 303 , NURS 304 , and NURS 305 . Corequisite(s): NURS 324 and NURS 325 .

title: Practicum: Nursing Care of Children
description: This practicum course provides the student with an off-campus practicum experience providing nursing care to infants, children, and adolescents across the continuum of care using a variety of acute and community settings. Prerequisite(s): NURS 301 , NURS 302 , NURS 303 , NURS 304 , and NURS 305 . Corequisite(s): NURS 323 and NURS 325 . Program fee: $819.50.

title: Lab, Sim, and Clinical Reasoning Sem: Care of PWI & Children
description: This course, Nursing Lab, Simulation, and Clinical Reasoning Seminar for Care of Pregnant Women, Newborns, and Children, weaves together lab, simulation, and a clinical reasoning seminar. Informed by the Reformed Christian worldview, students will demonstrate progress towards achieving competency in clinical judgement, integrating informatics and healthcare technologies to promote safe care and promoting personal wellness while caring for individuals and populations. Students will practice within health promotion / disease prevention and chronic disease spheres of care. Prerequisite(s): NURS 301 , NURS 302 , NURS 303 , NURS 304 , and NURS 305 . Corequisite(s): NURS 321 , NURS 322 , NURS 323 , and NURS 324 .

title: Theory: Nursing Care of Adults
description: This course will focus on caring for adults in the context of their communities, the health care team, and health care systems. Students will learn pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic strategies to prevent and care for acute and chronic conditions, including restorative care. Prerequisite(s): NURS 321 , NURS 322 , NURS 323 , NURS 324 , and NURS 325 . Corequisite(s): NURS 352 and NURS 355 .

title: Practicum: Nursing Care of Adults
description: This practicum course provides the student with an off-campus practicum experience providing nursing care to adults across the continuum of care using a variety of acute and community settings. Prerequisite(s): NURS 321 , NURS 322 , NURS 323 , NURS 324 , and NURS 325 . Corequisite(s): NURS 351 , NURS 353 , and NURS 355 . Program fee: $1,639.

title: Theory: Nursing Care of Complex Adults
description: This course will continue to focus on caring for adults in the context of their communities, the health care team, and health care systems. Students will learn pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic strategies to prevent and care for acute and chronic conditions, including trauma, comorbidity, palliative, and end-of-life care. Prerequisite(s): NURS 351 . Corequisite(s): NURS 352 and NURS 355 .

title: Lab, Sim, and Clinical Reasoning Sem: Adults
description: This course weaves together lab, simulation, and a clinical reasoning seminar. Informed by the Reformed Christian worldview, students will demonstrate competency in implementing a holistic plan of care, communicating with the health care team, implementing quality and safety principles, and applying health care technology and informatics. Students will practice within chronic disease, restorative, hospice, and palliative spheres of care. Prerequisite(s): NURS 321 , NURS 322 , NURS 323 , NURS 324 , and NURS 325 . Corequisite(s): NURS 351 , NURS 352 , and NURS 353 .

title: Exploring Culture, Health, Faith, and Nursing
description: WI. This elective, off-campus nursing course is offered during the January winter-intensive period. The goal of the course is to explore a culture outside of West Michigan. Students will experience the intersection of culture, health, and faith in the culture of the course location. Students will visit healthcare facilities, interact with nurses, and have cultural experiences. Prerequisite(s): admission to the nursing major. Travel-related fees may apply.

title: Theory: Public Health Nursing
description: This theory course will focus on caring for the community as client. Students will learn about the role of the public health nurse and how community assessment, epidemiology, health policy, and disaster preparedness can be used to promote population health and system effectiveness. Prerequisite(s): NURS 351 , NURS 352 , NURS 353 , and NURS 355 . Corequisite(s): NURS 372 , NURS 375 , and NURS 380 .

title: Practicum: Public Health Nursing
description: This practicum course will provide students the opportunity to care for the community as client. Students will spend time in one of the nursing department’s partner neighborhoods, seeking to address health disparities through listening to community voice. Students will also learn how to use principles of community-based participatory research to promote population health. Prerequisite(s): NURS 351 , NURS 352 , NURS 353 , and NURS 355 . Corequisite(s): NURS 371 , NURS 375 , and NURS 380 . Program fee: $819.50.

title: Theory: Leadership and Management in Nursing
description: This theory course is focused on leadership/management principles used by the professional nurse and their impact on health outcomes and system effectiveness. Students will demonstrate team-based case management to deliver safe, high-quality care. Prerequisite(s): NURS 321 , NURS 322 , NURS 323 , NURS 324 , and NURS 325 . Corequisite(s): NURS 374 , NURS 375 , and NURS 380 .

title: Practicum: Leadership and Management in Nursing
description: This precepted practicum course will provide students the opportunity to assume the role of the nurse and apply principles of leadership and management to nursing practice. Prerequisite(s): NURS 351 , NURS 352 , NURS 353 , and NURS 355 . Corequisite(s): NURS 373 , NURS 375 , and NURS 380 . Program fee: $819.50.

title: Sim and Clinical Reasoning Sem: Individuals and Populations
description: This course, Final Simulation and Clinical Reasoning Seminar for Care of Individuals and Populations, provides students the opportunity to synthesize learning from prior semesters as they care for individuals and populations. Students will demonstrate competency in ethical decision making, collaborating with the interprofessional team, providing coordinated care in partnership with community, and applying quality improvement principles in care delivery. Students will practice across all four spheres of care. Prerequisite(s): NURS 351 , NURS 352 , NURS 353 , and NURS 355 . Corequisite(s): NURS 371 , NURS 372 , NURS 373 , NURS 374 , and NURS 380 .

title: Critical Reflections on Health
description: This reflective course will lead the student into inquiry about the relationship between Christian faith and the discipline of nursing. Students will examine how the Reformed Christian worldview and interdisciplinary perspectives inform understanding of a contemporary challenge or enduring question. Students will also evaluate the impact of various models of health care finance on system effectiveness. Prerequisite(s): NURS 351 , NURS 352 , NURS 353 , and NURS 355 . Corequisite(s): NURS 371 , NURS 372 , NURS 373 , NURS 374 , and NURS 375 .

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Advanced Roles in Nursing
description: This seminar will explore the various graduate school options within the discipline of nursing with a specific focus on nursing research and advanced practice. It will investigate the process of graduate education from application to the acquisition of a position following graduate school. Graduate education, national priorities for nursing research, translational research, and evidence based practice will be explored in light of health care reform. The seminar will approach graduate education as means to prepare for lifelong Christian service in God’s world.
