description: Students will be introduced to social statistics and statistical analysis software as a tool for social research. Throughout the course, students will learn theoretical statistical concepts as well as skills to perform data analysis. Students will analyze data and present findings to develop skills as a critical consumer of statistics, with an emphasis on developing virtuous practice in the ethical use of statistics. Corequisite(s): Corequisite: SOC 255L.

title: Ethnography and Qualitative Research Methods
description: This course introduces students to a sociological perspective on everyday social settings by applying methods of systematic, qualitative observation. Training includes ethnographic research methodologies designed to equip students to collect and analyze data. Topics include issues of access, rapport, participant observation, field notes, ethics, interviewing, coding, and analysis.

title: Gender and Sexuality in the United States
description: Alternate years. This course provides a sociological understanding of the concepts of gender and sexuality by focusing on how their socially constructed nature provides insight into gender and sexuality identities, roles, expression, and experiences. Students will critically and analytically consider how structural forces, cultures, and major social institutions (e.g., media, work) produce, govern, mediate, shape, and perpetuate inequalities among people based on gender and sexuality in the U.S.

title: Sociology of Sport
description: Offered as needed. A study of the social and social-psychological dynamics of sports in modern society. Areas receiving special attention are youth sports, interscholastic sports, and professional sports. Emphasis is put on describing and understanding sports participants and observers and the relationship of sport as an institution to the rest of social structure. Crosslisted as KIN 302 .

title: Criminology
description: Alternate years. This course uses sociological theories, frameworks, and methods to understand criminal behavior. It explores how crime is defined, enforced, and measured, as well as motivational and demographic trends in criminal behavior. Students will use this information to critically and analytically consider ethics, policy, and research implications and issues.

title: Religion, Society, and Culture
description: Alternate years. The course will focus on recognizing the social aspects of religion and thinking critically about what influences the ways in which people practice their faith and what role faith plays in shaping human behavior. Particular attention is paid to the North American experience of Christianity. This course will examine beliefs, practices, organizations, and cultures from a sociological perspective, looking as well at the historical and philosophical underpinnings of the perspective and what that means for our study of religion.

title: Special Topics
description: Advanced study of selected topics of current interest in sociology or anthropology. Topics vary and may be substantive, theoretical, or methodological. Consult instructor for course information. This course may be repeated for credit; the topic may not be repeated for credit.

title: Corrections and Incarceration
description: Alternate years. This course considers corrections and incarceration systems within contemporary society. Particular foci include issues of punishment, rehabilitation, prison communities, and reintegration. The course examines both historical and contemporary theories and practices of punishment, deterrence, abolition, limiting harm, and rehabilitation (mass incarceration, death penalty, treatment of vulnerable populations, solitary confinement, effected communities) and contemporary reforms. Critical issues and problems assessed will include cultures of prisons (including social roles of prisoners and correctional officers), sentencing guidelines, philosophies of punishment, deterrence, and rehabilitation, and reintegration.

title: Sociological Theory
description: An assessment of sociological theory in terms of its historical development and current role in understanding human behavior. Particular attention is given to the function of theory in the research process. Direction is given to the student in the formulation of sociological hypotheses from data. Prerequisite(s): SOC 151 .

title: Social Research
description: Students develop an understanding of quantitative and qualitative research methods in the social sciences. In collaboration with community partners, students conduct a research project by describing a social issue and developing a research question, conducting a literature review, selecting appropriate methods, collecting and analyzing data, and communicating results through a research report and presentation to a vested community audience. Students consider implications of social research findings for practice and policy. Through the course, students develop an awareness of the importance of social science research is understanding ourselves and the world around us. Crosslisted as SOWK 355 . Prerequisite(s): SOC 255 or (with permission of the instructor) STAT 143 .

title: Internship in Sociology
description: This course will provide an integrative context for sociology majors with respect to sociological practice or research in a subfield of interest to the student (e.g., cross-cultural studies, urban studies, criminology, family studies). Students will learn about an area of professional service as it relates to sociological theory, research, community characteristics and needs, professional standards, and being an effective agent of renewal. This internship will build upon previous learning in the major and provide a bridge between prior learning and graduate study and/or employment following graduation. Prerequisite(s): Prerequisites: Senior sociology major, completion of SOC 151 , SOC 255 , and completion of or concurrent registration in SOC 351 and SOC 355 .

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in Sociology department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the Sociology department.

title: Sociology Integrative Seminar
description: This course provides students with an opportunity to re-visit, at a more advanced level, the basic assumptions and concepts of the discipline of sociology, to explore the bearing of Christian faith, in particular a Reformed perspective, on the shaping of scholarly research, to consider what it means to practice sociology, and, in addition, students are challenged to synthesize, integrate, and assess what they have learned in sociology and to reflect on the role and contributions of the discipline in understanding current social issues in American culture. Prerequisite(s): for sociology majors: SOC 151 , SOC 255 , and SOC 351 . Prerequisites for criminology majors: SOC 151 and fulfillment of the Methods area of competency.

title: Elementary Spanish I
description: An introductory course in oral and written Spanish.

title: Elementary Spanish II
description: A continuation of SPAN 101 .

title: Accelerated Elementary Spanish
description: An accelerated course in oral and written introductory Spanish. Prerequisite(s): 2 years of high school Spanish; or strong organization, discipline, and high motivation.

title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Review of essential grammatical structures and further training in spoken and written Spanish. Cultural and literary readings. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 102 or equivalent.

title: Intermediate Spanish II
description: This course is a continuation of SPAN 201 . Prerequisite(s): SPAN 201 or equivalent.

title: Business Spanish
description: This intermediate Spanish course introduces basic business vocabulary and cultural skills to enable students to communicate effectively and sensitively in Spanish-speaking workplaces. Students will review grammar topics and practice written and oral skills necessary to complete a professional resume and participate in an oral employment interview. This course is designed for students who are not intending to complete a Spanish major or minor but who wish to acquire additional, specialized Spanish skills beyond what they covered in their core courses. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 201 or equivalent.

title: Advanced Grammar, Composition and Conversation I
description: This introduction and gateway to the major or minor concentration focuses on the improvement of speaking and writing skills through vocabulary acquisition and the honing of grammatical accuracy. Extensive practice in oral and written communication. A minimum grade of C (2.0) in this course is required as a prerequisite for any concentration in Spanish. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 202 or equivalent.

title: Advanced Grammar, Composition and Conversation II
description: A continuation of SPAN 301 . Prerequisite(s): SPAN 301 or equivalent.

title: Speaking World
description: As needed. This course surveys issues of culture and society with a focus on a region in the Spanish-speaking world. It situates those issues in the context of the history of the region and analyzes expressions of faith and spirituality. The course invites students to approach the study of the region with a posture of cultural and intellectual humility. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 202 or permission of the instructor.
course_number: Culture and Society in the Spanish

title: Spanish Phonology, Dialectology, and Sociolinguistics
description: An introduction to Spanish linguistics, concentrating on Spanish phonetics and phonology (with appropriate pronunciation practice and contrasts with English pronunciation), along with sociolinguistics. Included are units on the history of the Spanish language and the major dialects spoken today. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 300 , SPAN 301 , or equivalent.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in the Spanish department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the World Languages department.

title: Level Spanish Studies
description: In this course, dual-enrolled Spanish immersion students learn about pan-Latino identity and globalization and develop the skills needed to succeed in college-level studies, with an emphasis on the development of their academic writing skills. This course gives special attention given to the effects of globalization on Spanish speakers from Central and South America and Spain. A minimum grade of C (2.0) in this course is required as a prerequisite to continue in the Spanish Immersion program. Prerequisite(s): Students must be a junior or senior high school student in an approved Spanish immersion program. Students must also have achieved a score of 4 or better on the AP Spanish Language and Culture exam. Exceptions may be evaluated on a case-by-case basis by Spanish faculty. Corequisite(s): enrollment in an approved high-school Spanish immersion program.

title: Engaging Hispanic Culture in Place for Immersion Students
description: As needed. In this four-week intensive course, which is taught onsite by a Calvin professor at one of the locations of our collaborating host institutions (currently Tegucigalpa, Honduras; Mérida, Mexico; Arequipa, Peru; Oviedo, Spain), Spanish Immersion students are immersed in the life and culture of a specific Spanish-speaking country. Students live with host families and attend lectures and discussion classes focusing on aspects of local culture and history. Particular attention will be given to how history and culture inform important social systems such as the economy, political structures, education and health. Students also participate in excursions to important historical and cultural sites and attend religious and cultural events. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 300 .

title: Engaging Hispanic Culture in Place
description: WI, SU, as needed. In this course students will have the opportunity to immerse themselves in a Spanish-speaking region. They will have conversations with Spanish speakers in place and will visit a variety of sites of historical and cultural importance. Students will experience the dynamics of family life and through conversations grow in their intercultural competence and intelligence. Students will discuss a variety of issues from a posture of cultural humility and reflect on the spiritual perspectives of their own culture by looking at the expressions of Christian faith and spirituality in place. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 306 or permission of the program director.

title: Introduction to the Hispanic World I
description: This course introduces students to major developments of the Hispanic World from antiquity through the Enlightenment. Discussions center on the relationship of major literary and artistic works to economic, political, religious, and social developments in the Iberian Peninsula and the Castilian colonies in the Americas. This course, normally the first in a sequence of two, prepares students for advanced-topics courses. An oral presentation and a research paper are required. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 300 or SPAN 301 , or equivalent.

title: Introduction to the Hispanic World II
description: This course introduces students to major developments of the Hispanic World from the independence of the Spanish American colonies to the present day. Discussions center on the relationship of major literary and artistic works to economic, political, religious, and social developments in Spain and Spanish America. In addition, students develop their skills in reading and evaluating literature in a second language through representative texts, and they sharpen their skills in critical writing and analysis. This course, normally the second course in a sequence of two, prepares students for advanced-topics courses. Oral presentations and research paper are required. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 308 or permission of the instructor.

title: Hispanic Culture in the United States
description: A study of the history and culture of Hispanic groups in the United States, their political, social, and religious institutions, and their value systems. The course is designed to assist students in understanding the cultural contributions of Hispanics within the broader US culture. Reading materials include literary and nonliterary sources. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 301 .

title: Advanced Topics
description: Through varied disciplinary emphases and diverse media such as film, music, art, written text, and community contact, this course fosters a deeper understanding of a specific theme relevant to the Hispanic World. Taught in Spanish. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 308 or SPAN 309 . Students may repeat this course if the topic is different.

title: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite(s): permission of the department chair.

title: Palabra y mundo: The Word and the World
description: As the capstone in the Spanish departmental major, this integrative studies course provides an opportunity for students to revisit, at a more advanced level, the literature, cultures, history, and language studied during their time at Calvin and to explore ways in which their education has prepared them to engage with contemporary international culture. Students examine and critically reflect on the ethical, religious, and vocational implications of what they have learned. Offered based on demand; see department chair. Prerequisite(s): CORE 100 , Foundations of Christianity I and II, SPAN 308 , SPAN 309 , and junior or senior standing; or permission of the instructor.

title: Advanced Grammar, Conversation, and Composition II
description: Odd years. A continuation of SPAN 301 .

title: Introduction to the Hispanic World I
description: Odd years. This course introduces students to major developments of the Hispanic World from antiquity through the Enlightenment. Discussions center on the relationship of major literary and artistic works to economic, political, religious, and social developments in the Iberian Peninsula and the Castilian colonies in the Americas. This course, normally the first in a sequence of two, prepares students for advanced-topics courses. An oral presentation and a research paper are required. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 301 .

title: Introduction to the Hispanic World II
description: Odd years. This course introduces students to major developments of the Hispanic World from the independence of the Spanish American colonies to the present day. Discussions center on the relationship of major literary and artistic works to economic, political, religious, and social developments in Spain and Spanish America. In addition, students develop their skills in reading and evaluating literature in a second language through representative texts, and they sharpen their skills in critical writing and analysis. This course, normally the second course in a sequence of two, prepares students for advanced-topics courses. Oral presentations and research paper are required. Prerequisite(s): SPAN 308 or permission of the instructor.

title: Engaging Honduran Culture
description: Odd years. A weekly seminar in which students compare and reflect on what they have learned from readings, interviews, and daily experiences. Includes speakers and excursions. This course is taught in Spanish by the Calvin director and is required of all students.

title: Direct Enroll at the Universidad Pedagógica
description: Odd years. Direct enrollment in at least one course at the university is required of all students in this program, except those enrolled in SPAN 302 . This course counts as elective credits toward the Spanish major or minor.

title: Introduction to Speech Pathology and Audiology
description: This course provides a general introduction to speech-language pathology and audiology. These rapidly growing interdisciplinary professions are devoted to helping individuals manage or overcome communication challenges. Communication is a God-given gift that allows us to be social beings. When people have difficulty communicating, it affects almost all aspects of their lives. Students will gain a general understanding of prevention, evaluation, and rehabilitation issues for a range of diagnoses in which speech language pathologists and audiologists specialize.

title: Anatomy and Physiology of the Speech, Hearing, and Language Mechanisms
description: 1, SP, SP1, SU1. A study of the anatomic and physiologic bases for the development and use of speech, language, and hearing. The course focuses on the central and peripheral auditory mechanisms of the human body, and on the respiratory, phonatory, and articulatory mechanisms required for speech production. The course includes a laboratory section. Corequisite(s): SPAUD 210L .

title: Anatomy and Physiology of the Speech, Hearing, and Language Mechanisms Lab
description: 1, SP, SP1, SU1. Laboratory section for SPAUD 210 .

title: Speech and Hearing Science
description: 1, SP, SP1, SU1. The course provides an overview of hearing and speech science. Topics include the introduction to the nature of sound, acoustic theories of speech perception and production, recording and analysis using acoustic programs, and clinical application of these concepts.

title: Phonetics
description: 2, SP2, SU2. A study of phonetic theories and the use of International Phonetic Alphabet symbols in analyzing, categorizing, and transcribing the sounds of the world’s languages, focusing on American English. The course emphasizes understanding the processes involved in the production of specific phonemes. The laboratory section of the course focuses on developing students’ skills in broad and narrow transcription. Corequisite(s): SPAUD 216L .

title: Phonetics Lab
description: 2, SP2, SU2. Laboratory section for SPAUD 216 .

title: Child Language Development
description: 2, SP, SP2, SU2. This course provides an overview of child language development as the foundation for appropriate assessment and intervention for children with communication disorders. Students learn key concepts and examine theories in phonological, morphological, syntactic, semantic, pragmatic, and relevant cognitive development, with the consideration of diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds.

title: Principles of Communication Neuroscience
description: This course provides a thorough understanding of nervous system anatomy and physiology as it relates to speech, language, swallowing, and hearing. Students will gain a comprehensive understanding of the central and peripheral nervous systems, including the brain, spinal cord, cranial nerves, and neural pathways. Emphasis will be placed on the neuroanatomical foundations of communication disorders, with practical applications for diagnosis and treatment. Students will be given rhetorical instruction related to professional writing and the writing process in communication sciences and disorders. Prerequisite(s): SPAUD 101 , SPAUD 210 ,SPAUD 212 , and SPAUD 216 .

title: Audiology: Testing and Diagnosis
description: 1, SP1, SU1. This course provides an overview of the anatomy, physiology, and pathologies of the hearing mechanism. Students learn instrumentation and techniques for the identification and management of hearing disorders including pure-tone and speech audiometrics and screening methods. Prerequisite(s): SPAUD 210 and SPAUD 212 .

title: Foundations of Aural Rehabilitation
description: 2, SP, SP2, SU2. This course provides options available for managing communication challenges of children and adults who are deaf or hard of hearing. Topics include early intervention, communication strategies, amplification options, and psychosocial issues. Prerequisite(s): SPAUD 344 .

title: Campus Experience
description: WI, SU, as needed. This course is an elective, off-campus speech pathology and audiology course. The goal of the course is to explore a culture outside of West Michigan. Students will experience the intersection of culture, faith, education and health in the culture of the course location. Students will visit health and/or educational facilities and have cultural experiences. Course topics may change based on location, which means the course is repeatable for credit.
course_number: Exploring Culture, Faith, and Health: Off

title: Introduction to Clinical Practicum
description: This course provides a supervised clinical experience in which the student clinician observes individuals who have various speech, language, or hearing impairments under the supervision of a speech-language pathologist or audiologist. This course is required as the initial field experience for speech pathology and audiology majors and is designed to introduce students to general therapy and assessment procedures across the disciplines. Prerequisite(s): SPAUD 101 , SPAUD 210 , SPAUD 212 , and SPAUD 216 .

title: Foundations of Clinical Practice
description: 2, SP2, SU2. This course is intended to ensure that students in the Speech and Hearing Foundations, Certificate program are adequately prepared for graduate clinical coursework. Students will have opportunities to observe assessment and intervention of communication disorders, learning through simulation-based, case-based, and problem-based learning. Students will be given rhetorical instruction related to professional writing and writing process in communication sciences and disorders (CSD). Students will explore the life impact of communication disorders and the role of CSD professionals in advocating for patient-centered care. Prerequisite(s): SPAUD 210 , SPAUD 212 , SPAUD 216 , SPAUD 311 , and SPAUD 344 .

title: Speech Sound and Language Disorders across the Lifespan
description: This course provides an overview of the nature, assessment, and treatment of speech sound disorders and language disorders in childhood, adolescence, and adulthood. Students will learn about characteristics and categorizations of speech sound and language disorders, while exploring how such disorders interact with a person’s environment, personal characteristics, and life participation. Students also will be introduced to key assessment and intervention concepts through didactic and case-based learning. Prerequisite(s): SPAUD 210 , SPAUD 212 , and SPAUD 216 . Course is required for SPAUD BA program and highly recommended for the SPAUD BA-MA program.

title: Critical Reflections in Speech Pathology
description: 2. This capstone course examines the application of a Reformed worldview to understanding communication and the consequences of communicative disorders. It focuses on the ways in which speech pathologists define professional activity and on the responsibilities that Christians have to work in and through this profession. Students expand their knowledge of professional ethics through a case study approach and address issues such as evidence-based practice, reimbursement issues, and conflicts of professional interest.

title: Language Pathology
description: 1. This graduate course is intended to equip students with the essential counseling knowledge and skills appropriate for the role of speech-language pathologist. Through didactic and interactive learning experiences, students will explore the ways that SLPs empower clients and their families to manage, adjust to, and live with communication and swallowing disorders. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Child Language Disorders I: Infants, Toddlers, and Preschool Children
description: 2. This graduate-level course explores the nature, assessment, and treatment of language disorders in infants, toddlers, and preschool children. Students learn evidence-based practice for assessment and intervention, with an emphasis on improving communication between children and their communication partners. Strategies for working with families with culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds are addressed throughout the course. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Age Children
description: 1. This graduate-level course explores the nature, assessment, and treatment of language disorders in elementary, middle, and high school students. Students learn language assessment practices and treatment strategies for the school-aged population. Strength-based assessments and evidence-based practice models will be highlighted in the course along with models for collaborating with teachers and other school-based professionals. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Language Pathology
description: 1. This graduate-level course emphasizes the role of speech-language pathologists in clinical research, both as researchers and consumers of research. Common research methodologies as well as data organization and analysis techniques will be reviewed. Principles for evaluating research, ethical considerations in research, as well as application of research in evidence-based practice will be discussed. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Aphasia
description: 2. This graduate-level course provides an in-depth examination of aphasia, its life impact, and the role of the SLP. Building on undergraduate coursework in neuroanatomy and language, students will learn about the etiologies, characteristics, and classifications of aphasia. Through the lens of person-centered care, students will explore the role of the SLP in aphasia (including assessment, intervention, counseling, and public health roles) as guided by standards of evidence-based practice. Overall, this course will prepare students to provide and advocate for services that support life participation for people with aphasia. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Speech Sound Disorders
description: 2. This graduate-level course explores the nature, assessment, and treatment of speech sound disorders in children and adolescents. Building on undergraduate coursework, students will advance their knowledge in phonetics, phonetic transcription, speech sound acquisition, and phonological development. After exploring etiologies and characteristics of speech sound disorders, students will learn and apply evidence-based assessment and intervention practices, paying particular attention to the cultural, linguistic, educational, and social contexts of their clients. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Fluency Disorders
description: 1, SU1. This graduate-level course examines the etiology, diagnosis, treatment and prevention of fluency disorders in children and adults. Fluency disorders and their impact on individuals across the lifespan will be examined. Students learn methods of formal and informal assessment techniques, different theories and practices for treatment, counseling issues, and preventative strategies for fluency disorders in adults and children. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Augmentative and Alternative Communication
description: 2. This graduate-level course is a study of augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) systems and AAC use across the lifespan. Topics include functions and components of AAC systems and their implementation, understanding and assessing the characteristics and needs of different populations who might benefit from AAC, as well as evidence-based interventions strategies in AAC based on the etiology and nature of communication disorders. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Autism Spectrum Disorder
description: 2, SU2. This graduate-level course focuses on serving individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) across the lifespan. Students will examine evidenced-based assessment and intervention practices for clinical work in all settings they are likely to work. The organization of the course is designed to provide students with practical knowledge and skills for their future vocations working with individuals, families, communities, and other professionals. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Language Pathology
description: 2. This graduate-level course is an advanced seminar on topics of current interest in speech-language pathology. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Aural Rehabilitation
description: 2. This graduate course offers an in-depth exploration of the communication challenges experienced by children and adults who have hearing differences. Students will learn about auditory rehabilitation approaches, including hearing technologies (e.g., hearing aids, cochlear implants), auditory training, and communication strategies. This course emphasizes the importance of counseling and support for individuals and their families, preparing students to provide person-centered care. Differences between hearing and Deaf cultures will also be explored. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program and permission of graduate program director.

title: Motor Speech Disorders
description: 1, SP1. This graduate-level course involves the study of motor speech disorders. The neuroanatomical and physiological basis of speech production will be reviewed, which will provide the basis for comprehending the etiology and nature of motor speech disorders. Topics that will be covered include speech and motor characteristics associated with dysarthria(s) and apraxia of speech, evaluation of motor speech disorders, differential diagnosis, general considerations for management, and treatments specific to each of the motor speech disorders. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Voice and Voice Disorders
description: 2, SP2. This graduate-level course involves a theoretical and applied study of the human voice and voice disorders. Topics include theories and practices on the anatomy and physiology of normal voice production, the etiology and pathology of voice disorders, and appropriate assessment and treatment techniques for people with voice disorders. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Cognitive Communication Disorders
description: 1, SU1. This graduate-level course provides an in-depth examination of cognitive communication disorders, their life impact, and the role of the speech-language pathologist. Students will learn about the etiologies, neuropathologies, and characteristics of cog comm disorders, paying particular attention to the ways cog comm impairments impact a person’s life and relationships. Through the lens of person-centered care and collaboration, students will explore the role of the SLP in cognitive communication (including assessment, intervention, counseling, and public health roles) as guided by standards of evidence-based practice. Overall, this course will prepare students to provide and advocate for services that support life participation for people with cog comm disorders. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Dysphagia
description: 1, SU1. This graduate-level course will review the nature, etiology, assessment, and treatment of swallowing disorders across the lifespan. Topics that will be covered include the anatomy, physiology, and neurology of normal swallowing, comparative understanding of the abnormal swallow, etiologic factors related to the nature of dysphagia, dysphagia assessment and management, as well as ethical issues associated with assessment and treatment. Students will integrate evidence-based practice to apply knowledge and skills of swallowing and swallowing disorders across the lifespan in case-based and other application activities. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Cleft and Craniofacial Disorders
description: 2, SU2. This graduate-level course involves the study of craniofacial disorders and their impact on an individual’s speech, language, hearing, and swallowing. Topics reviewed include etiology, characteristics, assessment, and treatment of craniofacial disorders in individuals across the life span. Ethical issues, including a discussion of medical and social models of disability as related to persons with craniofacial differences, will also be addressed. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Clinical Practicum: Clinic 1
description: This graduate-level course engages students in direct and simulated clinical experiences with individuals with various communicative disorders, under the supervision of Calvin clinical instructors. Students also participate in a clinical seminar session to develop clinical competencies including clinical writing, ethical practice, and collaboration, all from a Christian perspective of practice. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in speech-language pathology program. Program fee: $966.

title: Clinical Practicum: Clinic 2
description: This graduate-level course engages students in direct and simulated clinical experiences with individuals with various communicative disorders, under the supervision of Calvin clinical instructors. Students also participate in a clinical seminar session to develop professional and career competencies, all from a Christian perspective of practice. Prerequisite(s): SPAUD 530 and acceptance into the MA in speech-language pathology program. Program fee: $966.

title: Clinical Practicum: Clinic 3
description: This graduate-level course engages students in direct and simulated clinical experiences with individuals with various communicative disorders, under the supervision of Calvin clinical instructors. Students also participate in a clinical seminar session to prepare for external clinical placements and build clinical and professional competencies, all from a Christian perspective of practice. Prerequisite(s): SPAUD 531 and acceptance into the MA in speech-language pathology program. Program fee: $966.

title: Clinical Practicum: Externship 1
description: This graduate-level course provides continued clinical learning experiences as students transition to off-site, community settings. Students engage in hands-on clinical experiences under the supervision of ASHA certified speech-language pathologists to further develop and refine their clinical knowledge and skills. The course includes considerations and discussions of current professional issues and evidence-based practice, as well as reformed Christian perspectives on clinical practice. Prerequisite(s): completion of the following courses with a B or better: SPAUD 502 , SPAUD 503 , SPAUD 504 , SPAUD 505 , SPAUD 506 , SPAUD 508 , SPAUD 510 , SPAUD 512 , SPAUD 514 , SPAUD 519 , SPAUD 523 , SPAUD 530 , SPAUD 531 , and SPAUD 532 . Program fee: $966.

title: Clinical Practicum: Externship 2
description: This graduate-level course provides a second off-site, community-based clinical learning experience. Students engage in hands-on clinical experiences under the supervision of ASHA certified speech-language pathologists to further develop and refine their clinical knowledge and skills. The course includes consideration and discussions of current professional issues and evidence-based practice, as well as reformed Christian perspectives on clinical practice. Prerequisite(s): completion of the following courses with a B or better: SPAUD 520 , SPAUD 521 , SPAUD 540 . Program fee: $966.

title: Thesis
description: For this course, students must successfully complete a mentored research project that results in an oral presentation and a written research thesis on a selected topic in speech-language pathology. Students must register for this course four times to complete the thesis. Prerequisite(s): acceptance into the MA in Speech-Language Pathology program.

title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics
description: An introduction to the concepts and methods of probability and statistics. The course is designed for students interested in the application of probability and statistics in business, economics, and the social and life sciences. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability theory, random variables and probability distributions, sampling distributions, point and interval estimation, hypothesis testing, analysis of variance, and correlation and regression. Students may not receive credit for both STAT 143 and STAT 145 .

title: Biostatistics
description: An introduction to the concepts and methods of probability and statistics for students in life science programs. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability theory, random variables and probability distributions, experimental design, sampling distributions, confidence intervals and hypothesis tests, analysis of variance, and correlation and regression. This course is an alternative to STAT 143 for students in certain life science programs. It is a required course for biology and public health majors and is open to others. Student may not receive credit for both STAT 143 and STAT 145.

title: Engineering Statistics
description: A course in statistics with emphasis on the collection and analysis of data in engineering contexts. Topics include descriptive statistics, experimental design, and inferential statistics. The development of probabilistic models for describing engineering phenomena is emphasized. Statistical software will be used throughout the course. Prerequisite(s): MATH 172 .

title: Statistics
description: Data analysis, data collection, random sampling, experimental design, descriptive statistics, probability, random variables and standard distributions, Central Limit Theorem, statistical inference, hypothesis tests, point and interval estimates, simple linear regression. Examples will be chosen from a variety of disciplines. Computer software will be used to display, analyze and simulate data. Prerequisite(s): MATH 171 or a grade of B- or better in MATH 132 .

title: Applied Data Analysis
description: This course takes a practical approach to the fitting, assessment, and interpretation of statistical models. Specific topics include obtaining and transforming data, data visualization, the generalized linear model framework, and specific examples of frequently used generalized linear models (multiple regression, ANOVA, logistic regression, and Poisson regression). The approach focuses on specifying appropriate models, using software to obtain model fits and to assess the quality of models, interpreting models, and preparing statistical reports. Prerequisite(s): STAT 143 , STAT 145 , PSYC 255 , SOC 255 with a grade of B- or better; STAT 241 , STAT 243 , STAT 343 , with a grade of C- or better; or a 5 on the AP Statistics Exam; or permission of instructor.

title: Computational Bayesian Statistics
description: Alternate years. An introduction to Bayesian statistical methods. Conjugate prior distributions are studied, but computational methods are emphasized and developed in the context of practical data analysis methods. Prerequisite(s): MATH 171 or a grade of B- or better in MATH 132 ; CS 106 or CS 108 ; and one from STAT 241 , STAT 243 , STAT 245 , or STAT 343 ; or permission of the instructor.

title: Probability and Statistics
description: Probability, probability density functions, binomial, Poisson, and normal distributions, Central Limit Theorem, limiting distributions, sample statistics, hypothesis tests, and estimators. Prerequisite(s): MATH 172 or a grade of B- or better in MATH 132 ; MATH 231 , MATH 251 , or MATH 255 ; or permission of the instructor.

title: Mathematical Statistics
description: Alternate years. A continuation of STAT 343 including theory of estimation, hypothesis testing, non-parametric methods, regression analysis, and analysis of variance. Prerequisite(s): STAT 343 .

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in Statistics department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the Statistics department.

title: Topics in Statistics
description: As needed. Advanced study of selected topics in statistics. Consult instructor for course information. This course may be repeated for credit provided the topic is different. Prerequisite(s): a STAT course numbered 241 or above, or permission of the instructor. Some topics courses may have additional requirements.

title: Independent Study
description: Independent study of topics of interest to particular students under supervision of a member of the department staff. Open to qualified students with permission of the department chair.

title: Foundational Mathematics
description: This course introduces students to learning theories and practices used to be successful as college learners. Students will regularly apply theories and practices to an identified paired course to aid student learning. Many of the strategies learned will have application across content areas. Concurrent registration in the paired course is required; scheduling must be arranged through the Center for Student Success. Prerequisite(s): a Core course.

title: Learning Practices: Special Topics
description: Learning Practices: Special Topics introduces students to learning theories and practices used to be successful as college learners. Students will regularly apply theories and practices to an identified paired course to aid student learning. Many of the strategies learned will have application across content areas. Course may be repeated for elective credit up to three times. Concurrent registration in the paired course is required; scheduling must be arranged through the Student Success team and the Office of the Registrar.

title: Academic Transitions
description: This course introduces students to select strategies, theories, and approaches to college learning. Students will understand and apply the concepts of motivation and behavior to learning. Course content is applicable across all academic disciplines.

title: Strategies for Academic Success
description: This course introduces students to theories of learning and motivation. Students will apply these theories to a paired course and to their broader academic studies. This course is relevant for students across all academic disciplines. Open to first-year students. Concurrent registration in a selected paired course is required; scheduling must be arranged through the registrar’s office and Student Success.

title: Generation Student Experience
description: This course introduces students to the experience of first-generation college students. It begins with an overview of demographic trends and common experiences of first-generation students. That overview is then compared to student stories and their own. Along the way, the class will engage how the hidden curriculum along with the intersectionality of race and class impact the first-generation experience. Students finish this reading- and discussion-based course by implementing a final project to aid future first-generation students.

title: Disciplinary course of the director
description: Check the off-campus website for details.

title: Studies in British Culture
description: A topical introduction to political, historical, religious, artistic, and popular aspects of the culture of Great Britain. The course engages the culture through a combination of classroom and experiential learning, including: speakers, excursions and tours.

title: Community in a Costa Rican Watershed
description: An on-site seminar that provides orientation to Costa Rican culture and introduces students to various cross-cultural issues. Furthermore, this course aims to help students engage with the local neighborhood association to help restore the vitality of the Virilla River and watershed. Students discuss and reflect on what they learn from readings, interviews, and daily experiences. Includes guest speakers and excursions. This course is required of all students who participate in the abroad program.

title: Contemporary France
description: Alternate years. An introduction to contemporary French culture through readings, discussions with guest speakers, and excursions. Begins early September with an orientation in Grenoble.

title: Introduction to the Hungarian Language
description: An introduction to the Hungarian language (pass/fail).

title: Studies in Central European Culture
description: A topical presentation of East Central Europe—politics, religion, art, music, and science—through guest speakers, readings, and excursions.

title: Italian Renaissance Art
description: Optional course.

title: Disciplinary course offered by the program director
Hungary Semester Practicum
description: Students will be placed in a Hungarian organization (e.g., NGO, social service organization, or school) to gain hands-on experience related to the work of the organization. Through the practicum experience, students will gain a better understanding of the day-to-day work of practitioners. Special attention will be placed on developing cross-cultural skills needed to function in a multicultural world.

Student discuss and reflect on what they learn from readings, interviews, and daily experiences. Includes guest speakers and excursions. This course is required of all students.

title: Direct Enroll at the Universidad Católica San Pablo
description: Direct enrollment in at least one course at the university is required of all students in this program, except those enrolled in SPAN 302. This course counts as elective credits towards the Spanish major or minor.

description: A continuation of SPAN 301 .

This course, normally the second course in a sequence of two, prepares students for advanced-topics courses. Oral presentations and research paper are required.

title: Engaging Spanish Culture
description: This course is designed to allow students to gain skills in cross-cultural communication: to understand how the world might look from the standpoint of Spanish experience, to learn how to discern and, where appropriate, adapt to Spanish cultural expectations of the other; to learn how to distinguish between the enduring principles of human morality and their Spanish-specific adaptations; to witness Spanish cultural embodiments of faith, and thus to reflect on the substance and definition of one’s own faith by comparison. This course is taught in Spanish by the Calvin director and is required of all students.

title: Direct Enroll at the Universidad de Oviedo
description: Direct enrollment in at least one course at the university is required of all students in this program, except those enrolled in SPAN 302. This course counts as elective credits toward the Spanish major if needed, and can count for Calvin Core or general graduation credits.

title: Faith and Vocation
description: This course examines integration of faith and vocation in public life, connecting students with alumni mentors to examine specific domains of public life, including politics and policy, journalism and strategic communication, law, and social work. This course will be graded as pass/fail: CR (completed as required) / NC (not completed). Prerequisite(s): STDC 342 and a departmental internship course, such as COMM 346 , POLS 380 , or SOWK 380 .

title: Special Topics in Public Life
description: This course examines topics at the intersection of faith and public life, evaluating the role different actors play political, economic, and social systems and the outcomes that result from their interaction. Corequisite(s): COMM 346 , POLS 380 , SOWK 380 , or STDC 344 .

title: Integrating Faith and Public Life
description: Individuals and institutions of many faith traditions seek to affect the climate and content of policy making. The course will stress site visits to organizations that influence, study, and/or implement public policies in a variety of areas such as health, social services, security, economic development, and trade. Students will be challenged to compare and contrast the organizations where they work as interns with the institutions visited in this course, particularly in terms of organizational objectives and the role of religion in the organization’s mission. May be credited as an elective or as a departmental credit when accepted by individual departments.

title: Internship in Washington, DC
description: An internship experience in a professional setting. Credit toward an academic major is granted at the discretion of each department. This course will be graded as pass/fail: CR (completed as required) / NC (not completed).

title: Introduction to Operations and Supply Chain Management
description: This course will engage students in a broad examination of multiple aspects of operations and supply chain management. Students will gain exposure to product and process design, program management, quality management, lean manufacturing techniques and supply chain management. Students will use a business simulation software to understand and model the impact of operational decisions on company profitability and sustainability. Course fee: $75.

title: Supply Chain
description: This course takes an integrative cross-functional approach to the study of supply chain management. Students will evaluate the challenges and opportunities involved in constructing a global network of organizations that cooperate synergistically to provide goods and services. Global business issues are discussed in the context of ethics and sustainability from a Reformed Christian perspective. Topical coverage includes cross-cultural considerations, strategy, supply chain network design, sourcing, logistics, supply chain relationship management, demand forecasting, and performance evaluation. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 203 , BUS 201 , and a grade of at least a C in SCM 201 .

title: Sustainable Operations
description: As needed. A study of the management of production and operations within a business, including planning, control, and evaluation of resources, inventory, schedules, and product or service quality. Significant time will be spent considering aspects such as statistical process control (SPC), lean manufacturing, and the financial impact of operations decisions. Special emphasis is placed on sustainability within operations. Computer applications are occasionally integrated for analysis and simulation purposes. This course may require off-site meetings to examine operations in real-time. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 203 , BUS 201 , and a grade of at least a C in SCM 201 . Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Logistics Management
description: As needed. Microanalysis of logistics and transportation services. Customer service, distribution operations, warehousing, order processing, facility design and operations, carrier selection, transportation costing, and negotiation. Prerequisite(s): SCM 201 .

title: Supply Chain Analytics
description: As needed. Decision modeling in supply chains with emphasis on forecasting, aggregate planning, material requirement planning, inventory management, quality management and sourcing decisions. Use of traditional and advanced spreadsheet modeling tools. Prerequisite(s): SCM 201 . Course fee: $75. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Supply Chain Finance
description: As needed. Decision modeling with emphasis on supply chain decisions and implications on corporate cash flow. Special emphasis is applied to understanding items such as payment terms, trade financing and INCOTERMS. Students will further consider implications of key strategies on customer and supplier service levels as well as the relationships between parties. Prerequisite(s): SCM 201 . Course fee: TBD. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Supply Chain Systems
description: As needed. Students are introduced to ERP systems in significant depth to enable understanding and hands-on engagement. Students will learn how configuration allows general-purpose ERP systems to be tailored to the needs of a specific business enterprise. Course may include an introduction to the technology underlying enterprise systems, including database design, queries, and reporting. Prerequisite(s): SCM 201 . Course fee: TBD. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Global Supply Chain Practicum I
description: The Global Supply Chain Practicum is an international travel course required for students pursuing the OSCM major. This course will focus on the impact of operations and global supply chain decisions in the context of local flourishing and economic impact. This course involves engagement with key technical aspects of manufacturing and operations management. It also allows students to engage with reflective readings and writing considering the impact of economic opportunity, development, and ethical leadership primarily focused on economic deserts. This course is offered on campus during the fall and spring semesters. Note: Students must take both SCM 310 and SCM 311 in consecutive terms. Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in SCM 201 ; or junior standing for engineering majors.

title: Global Supply Chain Practicum II
description: WI, SU1. The Global Supply Chain Practicum is an international travel course required for students pursuing the OSCM major. This course is offered during the January term and will focus on the impact of operations and global supply chain decisions in the context of local flourishing and economic impact. This course involves engagement with key technical aspects of manufacturing and operations management but also allows students to engage with reflective readings and writing considering the impact of economic opportunity, development and ethical leadership primarily focused on economic deserts. SCM 311 is an off-campus course. Note: Students must take both SCM 310 and SCM 311 in consecutive terms. Prerequisite(s): SCM 310 .

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in Business department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the Business department.

title: Calvin Theatre Company
description: Members are actively encouraged to explore the intersection of their Christian faith and the production of high-quality pieces of theatre. In the process, they receive training in the various practical aspects of theatre through participation in one production each semester. Students may participate more than one year and are encouraged to experience as many different aspects of production as possible, both onstage and backstage. No more than six semester hours may count toward the requirement for graduation. Prerequisite(s): a cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher.

title: Introduction to Performance Studies
description: Alternating years. An introduction to performance as a means of analyzing, appreciating, and celebrating life and literature. By providing training in the principles and techniques of performing before an audience, this course expands students’ understanding of the relationships between text and performance, literature and human action, and written and oral forms of discourse. Genres examined include poetry, prose, non-fiction, oral history, and biblical literature.

title: Acting
description: Alternate years. Students will gain and sharpen active listening and observational skills for use in stage and screen acting. Students will also learn the basics of script analysis. These tools and insights will be applied to scene acting, a staged monologue, a self-recorded audition, and a filmed scene in tandem with the Video Production Department and/or a New Media scene (e.g., TikTok, Instagram, Youtube, etc.). Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Independent Study
description: An advanced course providing opportunities to explore specialized topics or areas of interest, including directing, playwriting, design, stage management, administration, dramaturgy, and more. To enroll in this course, students must submit a written proposal for approval. Prerequisite(s): two semesters of THTR 120 (taken for either audit or credit) and permission of the department chair.

title: Wayfinder 1
description: As needed. An introduction to how disciplines in the humanities—art and music, history, philosophy, literature, and writing—invite us to a deeper understanding of human flourishing. The two interdisciplinary courses are taken in sequence over a full year and are unified by themes such as vocation, citizenship, diversity, and justice. This course introduces students to the features of disciplinary study in the humanities. Course themes may vary across sequences; students may take a sequence more than once but not on the same theme.

title: Wayfinder 2
description: As needed. Building upon the introduction to the humanities disciplines in the first Wayfinder course, this course applies humanistic study to the experience of identity and community in local and national contexts. The two interdisciplinary courses are taken in sequence over a full year and are unified by themes such as vocation, citizenship, diversity, and justice. Course themes may vary across sequences; students may take a sequence more than once but not on the same theme. Prerequisite(s): GCS 110 .

title: Special Topics
description: Offered as needed. This course is a platform for the Global Campus to reach out to a range of learning communities by addressing emerging issues or other specialized content not covered in the regular curriculum.

title: Career Exploration
description: This course is designed to help adult students explore their career interests, professional goals, and vocational trajectory. Throughout this course students will discover the skills, competencies, dispositions necessary for success in their career field. They will be invited to explore ethical frameworks that can be applied in their professional lives. Through completion of assessments, personal reflection, individual research, and interaction with the Career Center, students will become familiar with their unique strengths and the current hiring environment in their field of study to prepare themselves to be competitive for employment opportunities.

title: Internship for Continuing Studies
description: This course uses applied experience and academic reflection in a discipline to examine a student’s calling to meaningful work. Students work in professional settings and complete a series of assignments that connects their experience to knowledge and theories in their program of study. The course is used specifically in programs tailored for adult learners.

title: Leading through Change
description: This course explores the key challenges and opportunities of navigating change as a leader in the private or social sectors. The course draws insights from business, human services, social work, non-profit management, and ethics to equip students with a multidisciplinary understanding of leading through change. The course will focus particularly on how Christian virtues and convictions can both deepen and challenge disciplinary perspectives. Topics include ethical leadership, organizational sustainability, dynamics of power, policy reform, leading in diverse environments, and effective change management. Through a combination of study and practical application, students will develop their own theory of change rooted in Christian values and applied to contemporary issues in business and human services. Enrollment is restricted to continuing-studies students.

title: World Language and Culture: An Introductory Exploration
description: As needed. An introductory course in the study of a world language and cultures with an exploration of cultural differences and linguistic privilege. Enrollment is restricted to continuing-studies students.

title: Introduction to Human Services
description: This course will provide an overview of the field of human services, including historical development, foundational values, and ethical standards. The course explores the role and function of human service professionals working in public and private settings. Students will learn entry-level and professional skills needed in human services administration, social work, mental health, and supported employment as they explore their commitment to a human services career. The course will include an introduction to casework, group work, and community advocacy. A generalist-level analysis of professional practices, theoretical frameworks, and intervention strategies will be examined. Emphasis will be on working in diverse and multicultural contexts. Instruction will include lectures, discussions, experimental exercises, and small group experiences. Enrollment is restricted to continuing-studies students.

title: Social Problems and Policy
description: This course enables students to understand how social problems are socially constructed, with attention to how these problems are defined, developed, and arbitrated. This course will also examine how social policies are created in response to those identified problems. Specifically, students will examine how structural and institutional barriers have influenced, and continue to influence, social welfare policy and practices. Students are introduced to the history of social welfare policies, ideologies, and values that influence policy decisions. Students will evaluate and analyze policies, develop practical advocacy skills in relation to human rights and social, economic, environmental, and restorative justice, and empower at-risk populations. Enrollment is restricted to continuing-studies students. Prerequisite(s): PSYC 151 or SOC 151; SOWK 220.

title: Practice with Organizations and Communities
description: Students will develop competencies in advanced generalist practice with organizations and communities, with an emphasis on how social workers engage, assess, plan, implement, and evaluate change at the macro level. Students will examine the historical roots of social work in macro practice and the social gospel. Students will deepen their understanding of the profession’s ethical commitments to economic, social, environmental justice, and anti-oppressive models of trauma-informed community practice that build off individual strengths and community assets. Enrollment is restricted to continuing-studies students. Prerequisite(s): PSYC 151 or SOC 151; SOWK 220.

title: Genetics and Development Lab
description: Students use established laboratory methods to investigate inheritance patterns and introduce and assess the impact of genetic variations in widely used genetic model systems. Students will develop technical skills and practice experimental design, data analysis, and scientific communication. Corequisite(s): BIOL 321 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy
description: Alternate years. This course examines the structure of organ systems in a wide array of vertebrates (including humans) and the functional significance of anatomical differences. Variations in the integumentary, skeletal, muscular, respiratory, digestive, circulatory, urogenital, endocrine, and nervous systems are explored in a phylogenetic framework with some discussion of histology and developmental biology. Credit cannot be applied toward a biology major for both BIOL 205 and BIOL 323. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 160 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 323L .

title: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy Lab
description: This laboratory emphasizes gross anatomy and practical identification of anatomical structures. Students study basic vertebrate phylogenetic relationships and utilize multiple representative vertebrates to explore anatomical variations in different organ systems. Students gain hands-on experience dissecting biological tissues and develop proficiency in the proper use of anatomical language. Corequisite(s): BIOL 323 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Biotechnology
description: Alternate years. What is CRISPR-based genome editing and how is it different from recombinant DNA used to make genetically modified organisms? How do cell- and gene-based technologies work and how are they applied in medicine, agriculture, industry, forensics, and environmental bioremediation? What are the social, ethical, and religious implications? In reading assignments and discussions, students explore scientific, societal, and Christian perspectives of biotechnology, including biosafety, sustainability, patenting, and “playing God.” Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 325L .

title: Biotechnology Lab
description: Students use established laboratory methods to make recombinant and edited DNA molecules, make genetically modified cells, and assess the changes in phenotype and genotype. Students will develop technical skills and practice experimental design, data analysis, and scientific communication. Corequisite(s): BIOL 325 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Comparative Animal and Human Physiology
description: A study of the mechanical, physical, and biochemical functions of animals and human beings. Using basic cell and tissue activities as a starting point, this course considers how the various organs and organ systems operate to provide ways of getting, distributing, and utilizing nutrients; excreting waste; maintaining a near constant internal environment despite changes in the external environment; providing movement; allowing both rapid and slower communications between and among these systems; and reproducing the organism. Learning activities will focus on understanding physiology, and will include lectures, problem-solving, and class discussions of scientific papers. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 ; BIOL 206 or BIOL 231 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 331L .

title: Comparative Animal and Human Physiology Lab
description: Students use established laboratory methods to investigate different physiological systems. Students will develop technical skills and practice experimental design, data analysis, and scientific communication. Corequisite(s): BIOL 331 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Plant Physiology
description: Alternate years. How efficient are plants in converting light energy to chemical energy? How closely is the global food supply tied to energy or fresh water supplies? How do plants compete with other plants, animals, pathogens, or survive climate extremes when they are rooted in place? This course relates the form and function of plants across a continuum from the physiological to the ecological, from the perspective of an individual plant and that of a plant canopy. Students discover the unique ways in which plants respond to environmental stressors like water deficits or excesses, or by producing an astounding variety of strange chemicals or structures to fight pathogens and herbivores. Emphasis is placed on how humans can use plants to produce food using agroecological methods, to address food production capacity in impoverished areas, to sequester atmospheric carbon, or to restore contaminated land areas. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 ; BIOL 200 ; and BIOL 232 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 332L .

title: Plant Physiology Lab
description: Students use a variety of instruments including gas exchange, pressure bomb, porometry, fluorometry to evaluate physiological plant functions and conduct independent investigations using those tools. Corequisite(s): BIOL 332 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Immunology and Hematology
description: How does the human body defend against pathogens? How does our defense system distinguish between our own cells and foreign invaders? This study of immunology examines mechanisms underlying the intricate work of the defense network including the innate and adaptive immune systems. Practical topics such as vaccines, AIDS, allergy, transplantation, and autoimmunity also will be discussed. The course includes lectures, class discussions of scientific papers, and team work. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 333L .

title: Immunology and Hematology Lab
description: Students learn hematology concepts and practices, immunological methods and practices, and use established laboratory methods to do an independent project. Assessment involves lab reports, quizzes, presentations and writing a scientific paper. Corequisite(s): BIOL 333 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Neurobiology of Disease
description: How does an electrical signal propagate through your body in milliseconds? How do neurons and other cells in the central nervous system communicate to maintain homeostasis? How does our nervous system respond to disease and injury? In this course, students answer these questions by studying the structure and function of the nervous system on the cellular and molecular level from a biological perspective, including the in-depth mechanisms of homeostatic maintenance and disease in the central nervous system. Learning activities will focus on basic neurobiology content and specific diseases of interest to the students, and will include lectures, student presentations, and class discussions of scientific papers. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 334L .

title: Neurobiology of Disease Lab
description: The laboratory experience focuses on primary literature analysis of neurobiology research. The course may include interviews with principle investigators and field trips to regional neuroscience research laboratories. Corequisite(s): BIOL 334 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Cell Physiology
description: Alternate years. A study of the function of animal cells with emphasis on events occurring outside the nucleus. Major emphases include the structure of the cell membrane, functions and interrelationships of membrane transporters and ion channels, synthesis of proteins and targeting of vesicles through the secretory pathway, structure and function of cell surface receptors and their interactions with intracellular signaling pathways, mechanisms of cell motility, and interactions of cells with the extracellular matrix. Concepts will be discussed in the context of historical development, examination of experimental evidence and relationship to the function of tissues and organs. Lectures and problem-based discussions of the primary literature. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 335L .

title: Cell Physiology Lab
description: Students will use established laboratory methods to investigate cell physiological processes. Students will develop technical skills and practice experimental design, data analysis, and scientific communication. Corequisite(s): BIOL 335 . Lab fee: $170.

title: General Microbiology
description: Do bacteria and viruses always cause disease? Do the bacteria in our gut influence our health and behavior? Have other organisms formed mutualistic relationships with bacteria? Can bacteria survive being in outer space? In this course, students study the immense diversity of microbial life and their creative environmental adaptations. They will explore how bacteria interact with each other, their environment, and with other animals, both in health and in disease. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 ; CHEM 101 or CHEM 103 ; and CHEM 240 or CHEM 241 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 336L .

title: General Microbiology Lab
description: We will integrate lecture with laboratory practices like isolating and culturing bacteria, identifying bacteria using molecular and chemical means, finding virulence factors using hospital lab techniques, and making foods that require microbial fermentation. A large part of the integrated lecture/lab will be a laboratory-based project that students will conceive as teams. Corequisite(s): BIOL 336 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Animal Behavior
description: Alternate years. Why do birds sing and bees dance? Why do ravens yell and hyenas laugh? Why are prairie dogs promiscuous and macaws monogamous? This course explores the diverse—and sometimes bizarre—strategies and mechanisms that animals use to solve the same basic problems of life: getting food, avoiding predators, finding mates, raising offspring, and living in groups. Learning activities will focus on evaluating the proximate and ultimate explanations for animal behavior from ecological and evolutionary perspectives. Students will also explore classical case studies in animal behavior and discuss the ethical, societal, and theological implications of behavioral concepts. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 160 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 338L .

title: Animal Behavior Lab
description: Laboratory and field activities will focus on real-world assessment of animal behavior. Students will be introduced to observational and manipulative methods in animal ecology and behavior, including the construction of ethograms, choice chamber experiments, and the application of ecological field techniques in the context of behavioral studies. Students will also explore the behavior of Great Lakes animals through field observations, journaling, and independent research project activities. Corequisite(s): BIOL 338 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Entomology
description: Alternate years. Why are insects the most abundant and diverse animals on earth? What’s the difference between a dragonfly and a horse fly? What can fleas, mosquitoes, and lice teach us about human health and disease? Why are insects our friends and our foes? This course explores the bizarre biology and ecology of insects. Learning activities focus on understanding entomology from ecological and evolutionary perspectives. This course will also explore public health and veterinary perspectives of entomology and acarology. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 160 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 341L .

title: Entomology Lab
description: Through field and laboratory investigations, students will gain familiarity with the body plan, taxonomy, and ecology of major insect groups. Special attention is given to the identification and classification of insects and acarids in the Great Lakes region. Specific focus will be given to developing familiarity with field techniques used in public health entomology and acarology. Corequisite(s): BIOL 341 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Wildlife Biology and Conservation
description: Alternate years. The field of wildlife biology focuses on understanding the ecology, conservation, and management of animals and their habitats. This course will explore the ecology of animals, with emphasis given to fundamental topics needed to understand the conservation and management of game and non-game wildlife, including population ecology, habitat associations, and the role that animals play in ecosystems. Contemporary topics affecting the conservation and management of animals, including diseases, climate change, landscape modifications, and harvest will also be discussed. This course also provides an overview of pertinent policies affecting wildlife management. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 160 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 344L .

title: Wildlife Biology and Conservation Lab
description: Alternate years. Through field trips, students will learn to identify game and non-game animals, with special attention given to the identification of vertebrate animals in the Great Lakes region. Students will also develop proficiencies in ecological research and inventory methods used in habitat, population, and community assessment of vertebrates, particularly as they pertain to contemporary conservation and management issues. Students will also work in groups to complete a research project focused on evaluating aspects of animal ecology, wildlife management, and/or human-wildlife interactions. Corequisite(s): BIOL 344 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Ecosystem Ecology and Management
description: The lives of human beings and countless other creatures are sustained by the goods and services resulting from the proper functioning of earth’s ecosystems.
