As the human population places increasing pressure on these systems, the need for their careful stewardship and management grows. This course provides a detailed study of ecosystem structure and function, with special emphasis on local ecosystems, and the scientific basis for managing and restoring ecosystems. Specific topics include energy flow and nutrient cycling, biodiversity and endangered species management, conservation genetics, population dynamics, landscape ecology, and human dimensions of ecosystem management. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 160 and BIOL 161 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 345L .

title: Ecosystem Ecology and Management Lab
description: Students use established field and laboratory methods to conduct a semester-long project comprising a data-driven assessment of human impacts on and/or ecological characteristics of a local ecosystem. Students will develop technical skills and practice experimental design, data collection and recording, data analysis, and scientific communication. Corequisite(s): BIOL 345 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Plant Taxonomy
description: Alternate years. Identification, nomenclature, and classification of vascular plants. Emphasis is placed on an understanding of the evolutionary relationships among major groups of plants, as well as family traits for field recognition. Ecological allegiance to particular habitats will also be an important aspect of this class, as well as the many relationships that knit species together within their ecological communities. History of botanical nomenclature and ethnobotanical uses from Indigenous people to the present is also an important component of this class. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 160 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 346L .

title: Plant Taxonomy Lab
description: Students will engage in a series on hands-on activities that will promote the learning of botanical terminology associated with leaves, stems, flowers, fruits, as well as major plant groups including gymnosperms, wind-pollinated monocots, and tropical plants. Laboratory time will also be dedicated to a class project that will include field identification, use of botanical keys, and a floristic quality assessment (FQA). Through these various experiences, the students will develop technical skills, practical field approaches, and data analysis strategies that are typically used by the professional botanical community. Corequisite(s): BIOL 346 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Specific Advanced Topics
description: This course addresses a variety of advanced topics that are important in contemporary societies (e.g., sustainability, biodiversity, health vs disease, cellular and DNA technologies, and more). Lectures, discussions, readings, and laboratory/field studies provide students with advanced conceptual knowledge and practical experiences that develop important vocational skills. Course work centers around scientific literature, investigation, and communication. Prerequisite(s): varies by topic and audience; typically, BIOL 160 , BIOL 161 , or equivalent course where key concepts are introduced.

title: Special Topics in Biology Lab
description: Lab fee: $170.

title: Global Health, Environment, and Sustainability
description: Global health and food matters are best understood within their biological, ecological, and socio-economic contexts. This course explores how processes in these contexts contribute to health and disease, especially as they pertain to international and community development. Food will be utilized as an organizing theme with which to inspect the intimacy of relationships between environmental and human health in both local and global contexts. Globalization presents opportunities and challenges for health and food security and for ecosystem integrity. Development models that enhance these by strengthening human-environment interconnectedness, using responsible technologies, and developing just policies are upheld as exemplars. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 , BIOL 123 , BIOL 141 , BIOL 160 , or BIOL 161 .

title: Tropical Ecosystems: Conservation and Development in Belize
description: WI. Tropical ecosystems contain the highest concentration of Earth’s biodiversity. Under the pressures of human population growth and resource use, they are also experiencing the highest rates of biodiversity loss. How can successful conservation work occur such that the well-being of local people is not compromised or even promoted? How can human-centered development work be done in such a way that the natural ecosystem to which humans belong is not degraded? These fundamental questions will be engaged through daily field trips to a variety of tropical habitats in Belize—including coral reefs, mangrove swamps, rivers and streams, tropical rain forests, and mountain pinelands. Course participants will be hosted by local Belizean institutions, scientists, and private citizens involved in conservation and sustainability efforts. Course evaluation: daily journal, active participation in course activities and evening discussions, one written test. In preparation, students will attend three two-hour sessions during the fall semester and complete some assigned readings. Off-Campus Programs course fee applies.

title: Dutch Sustainability: Is Orange the New Green?
description: Alternate years. When faced with sustainability challenges, the Dutch have always innovated their way toward a more stable and resilient environment. Through orienting reading assignments and field excursions, students learn about this country’s richly varied history of cultural inclusion, land reclamation, water management, energy production, food production, and environmental preservation. These innovations have shaped Dutch society and culture in ways that earn their distinction as global leaders in redesigning their economic and infrastructure systems to meet today’s sustainability challenges. Online excursion guides prepare students for visits to places throughout the Netherlands that feature old and new innovations, places of historic and cultural significance, and conversations with local experts. Course assessment is based on reflective assignments and class discussions. Students can expect to learn some Dutch in this course, but knowing Dutch is not required, since many people in the Netherlands speak some English. Prerequisite(s): CORE 100 .

title: Cell Biology and Genetics for the Health Sciences
description: This course presents the structures, functions, and evolution of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells at the molecular, subcellular, and cellular levels. Fundamental concepts of genetics are studied including Mendelian genetics and molecular genetics. The course introduces basic historical, philosophical, and biblical frameworks for the study of biology. Applications of course concepts to contemporary issues in biology are considered. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 160 or equivalent. Corequisite(s): BIOL 141L .

title: Cell Biology and Genetics Lab
description: Laboratory exercises are designed to teach crucial lab skills while reinforcing key concepts in cellular and molecular biology. It provides students with the opportunity to further explore the concepts discussed in the lecture as well as the connections between scientific methods, evidence, and knowledge. Corequisite(s): BIOL 141 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Human Anatomy
description: This course examines the structure of human organ systems, including some histology and developmental biology. Major topics include the integumentary, skeletal, muscular, nervous, endocrine, cardiovascular, lymphatic, respiratory, digestive, urinary, and reproductive systems. Learning activities include lectures, active-learning activities, and exploration of clinical applications relevant to the system under study. Corequisite(s): BIOL 205L .

title: Human Anatomy Lab
description: This laboratory emphasizes gross anatomy and practical identification of anatomical structures. Students study the human skeleton in detail and dissect a representative mammal to explore other organ systems. Students gain hands-on experience dissecting biological tissues and develop proficiency in the proper use of anatomical language. Corequisite(s): BIOL 205 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Human Physiology
description: An introduction to the essential functions of the human body, including how tissues and organs operate and work together to help the body acquire, distribute, and utilize nutrients; move; eliminate waste; communicate between tissues and organs; and reproduce. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 ; CHEM 102 , CHEM 103 , or CHEM 160 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 206L .

title: Human Physiology Lab
description: Students use established laboratory methods to investigate basic physiological techniques in an investigative setting. Corequisite(s): BIOL 206 . Lab fee: $170.

title: Medical Microbiology
description: A study of microorganisms and their activities as they relate to human health and disease. Topics include significant events in the current and past history of microbial disease, as well as the classification, structure, and metabolism of microbes. These topics are discussed in the context of how they contribute to a beneficial symbiotic relationship between microbes and humans, as well as how they are a factor in pathogenicity. Diseases due to bacteria and viruses are emphasized; however, human fungal, protozoal, and multicellular eukaryotic diseases are also discussed. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 141 or BIOL 161 . Corequisite(s): BIOL 207L .

title: Medical Microbiology Lab
description: Students practice essential microbiological techniques such as sterile technique, simple and Gram staining, oil-immersion microscopy and both liquid and solid media cultivation methods. An emphasis is placed on choosing selective and differential media to isolate and identify specific microorganisms such as coliforms and Staphylococci/Streptococci. Biochemical testing of bacterial isolates is also emphasized, with students choosing a “pet” and then characterizing its physical appearance and metabolic capability. Culmination of the lab includes identification of unknown bacteria using student-generated dichotomous keys, and previously recorded physiological and metabolic data. Corequisite(s): BIOL 207 . Lab fee: $170.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Internship in Biology
description: This course is for students participating in an internship that emphasizes professional application of the concepts and principles learned as part of a biology program. A student has responsibilities in a laboratory, office, private firm, not-for-profit organization, or government agency. The student works on a specific project under the direct supervision of an employer-supervisor and/or faculty internship coordinator. On-campus internships are to be completed under an appropriate Calvin supervisor, while off-campus internships are to be completed under the supervision of the designated faculty internship coordinator. All students must maintain an internship journal and present an oral or written report summarizing the internship experience. For off-campus internships, students will also be evaluated by their employer-supervisor. Only one from BIOL 385, BIOL 390 , or BIOL 399 may be used to satisfy the requirements for the biology major. Prerequisite(s): instructor, advisor, and departmental approval.

title: Independent Study
description: This course provides the opportunity for a student to conduct library research, or under the direction of a faculty member, to study a subject not currently offered in the biology curriculum. Permission to enroll must be obtained from the department chair and the faculty member directing the project. Requirements will be determined by the supervising faculty member. Only one from BIOL 385 , BIOL 390, or BIOL 399 may be used to satisfy the requirements for the Biology major. Prerequisite(s): instructor permission.

title: Undergraduate Research
description: Students conduct laboratory, field, and/or literature-based research under the supervision of a faculty member. The project may be part of an ongoing research program of the supervising faculty member. A culminating paper on the project is required. Students taking the course for 4 credits are also encouraged to present a poster or seminar to the department. Permission to enroll must be obtained from the department chair and the faculty member directing the project. Only one from BIOL 385 , BIOL 390 , or BIOL 399 may be used to satisfy the requirements for the Biology major. Prerequisite(s): instructor permission.

title: Biology Seminar
description: Various vocational and research topics in biology and related disciplines are presented by visiting speakers, faculty, and students. Biology majors must complete two semesters of BIOL 295. The first semester should be when they are enrolled in BIOL 200 , and the second semester should be during the junior or senior year. Students of all levels are encouraged to attend biology seminars, even when they are not enrolled in BIOL 295.

title: Perspectives in Biology
description: This is a writing-intensive course that integrates interdisciplinary perspectives on contemporary challenges and enduring questions in biology. By first examining current literature from different fields and having candid discussions about current issues, students come to see how differing perspectives inform these challenges and questions. Students learn how to engage with primary literature through participation in class discussions and via dialogue associated with peer presentations. Skills in biological communication surrounding a specific topic are taught and assessed as students lead a discussion based on research papers, present a research talk, and then produce a written thesis paper. Students also develop a vocational articulation for ways they can contribute to scientific and societal resolutions of these challenges and questions. Prerequisite(s): senior status in a biologically oriented program or permission of the instructor.

title: Perspectives in Medicine
description: How do historical and philosophical perspectives affect the science and practice of medicine, particularly the methodology, results, and implications of current medical research? By studying the medical literature in this writing-intensive course, students explore societal and ethical issues in medicine, from the status of embryos to end-of-life questions. Skills in biological and interdisciplinary communication are taught and assessed through written and oral presentations. Students also develop a vocational perspective that can guide their own contributions to scientific and societal resolutions of complex contemporary challenges in medicine. Prerequisite(s): senior status in a biomedically oriented program, or permission of the instructor.

title: Business Foundations
description: A survey introduction to business in its economic and global contexts and its functional areas (including accounting, finance, human resources management, marketing, operations and supply chain, entrepreneurship, and business analytics), with reflection on the roles of the moral and ethical responsibilities of business in society. The course emphasizes an integrated Christian view of business, considering its societal context, disciplines, and the role of management, and allows students to grow in their ability to think critically and analytically. Not available to students pursuing a major offered by the School of Business.

title: Leadership in Kenya
description: Alternate years. This course focuses on how leaders in Kenya and East Africa develop businesses, provide health care, organize government and education, respond to crises, address poverty and issues of justice, promote community development and micro-finance, and conduct worship. Students hear lectures from Kenyan leaders and travel to site locations to see leadership in action. Students examine leadership and culture in both urban and rural areas, with an eye to the leadership and partnership role Americans may have in East Africa. Students will be required to read selected materials before departure, report on and lead discussions on them, take quizzes, write reflection papers, and journal daily. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Management and Organizational Behavior
description: This course aims to equip students with a deep understanding of individual and group behavior within organizations, and examines the role of organizational systems, structures, and processes in shaping behavior. By achieving the learning objectives, students will develop a solid foundation for understanding and effectively managing human behavior in organizational settings. This course attempts to help students develop an integrated understanding of management and organizational behavior based on God’s revelation in creation and His Word.

title: Project Management
description: Students are introduced to key project management concepts and competencies, including the fundamentals of project management encompassed in the Project Management Institute’s (PMI’s) Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK); Lean/Agile methodologies; and design thinking. Application of knowledge and development of skills and abilities are honed through case studies and simulations. Conceptual coverage is intended to contribute to students’ preparation to sit for the PMI Certified Associate in Project Management (PMI-CAPM) exam.

title: Nonprofit Management and Leadership
description: As needed. This course introduces the principles of effective management of nonprofit organizations with a focus on practices of local, national, and international NPOs and NGOs. It considers issues related to organization structure, mission/vision, functions of governing boards, grant-seeking and grant writing, fundraising, marketing of services, public relations, management of volunteers, and employee recruitment, training, and motivation. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Business Law
description: An introduction to American business law: Origins, development, legal institutions, and processes. The legal environment of business, Uniform Commercial Code and case law of business transactions, other topics selected from agency, property, partnership, corporation, regulatory, and administrative law. Prerequisite(s): junior or higher standing.

title: Negotiation Skills and Theory
description: Negotiation skills are crucial for interaction in today’s business world. In this course students are introduced to the theory and concepts for different negotiation approaches which are then reinforced through practical simulated negotiations. Covered topics include basic negotiation concepts (BATNA, reservation price, etc.) as well as critical discussion of different negotiation approaches such as principled negotiation championed in the popular book Getting to Yes. Students are graded on the basis of tests, class participation and engagement, and a mock negotiation. Prerequisite(s): junior or higher standing. Course fee: $39.

title: Business for Engineers
description: An overview of the aspects of business important to engineering. Selected topics from economics, accounting, finance, marketing, management, and business law are included. Prerequisite(s): ECON 191 , ECON 221 , ECON 222 , ECON 232 , or ECON 233 ; and junior or senior standing in the engineering program.

title: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite(s): permission of the department chair.

title: Business Internship
description: Internships involve a minimum of ten hours of work a week for ten weeks (or equivalent) in a professional setting with an approved employer-supervisor in a business or nonprofit organization. Academic work includes meetings with the professor, goal setting, a final paper, an assessment from the employer-supervisor, readings, seminars/workshops, and reflective journals. For this course to fulfill a major requirement, the internship must be in the student’s major discipline. Prerequisite(s): sophomore or higher standing, and approval of instructor.

title: Business Ethics
description: Prepares students to be agents of Shalom in business organizations. Familiarizes business students with three key knowledge areas that are important for both doing business ethically and encouraging others to do likewise: current legal stipulations for business conduct, normative frameworks for evaluating actions or policies, and systems and techniques for promoting ethical behavior and overcoming rationalizations for misbehavior. Develops skills in evaluating the legal and ethical ramifications of actions or policies, and in persuasive argumentation in support of ethical actions or policies, through case studies. Hones virtues of honesty, courage, charity, creativity, empathy, humility, stewardship, compassion, justice, faith, hope, and wisdom, through reflective written exercises and case studies. Prerequisite(s): BUS 201 ; and ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Strategic Management
description: An integrative study of strategic management. Students apply concepts from marketing, accounting, finance, management, and social theory to case analyses and team projects. The roles of shalom, worldviews, and ethical decision-making are emphasized. Prerequisite(s): ACCT 203 ; ACCT 204 ; BUS 201 ; ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 ; and MKTG 301 .

title: Business Capstone
description: This course is an experiential (project-based learning) course which is designed to have students draw upon and apply much of the knowledge and many of the skills and virtues (K, S, and V) developed in courses taken prior to the capstone in solving actual business problems for clients as members of student consulting teams. It will also require students to learn new frameworks, become familiar with industries and organizations, and to meet and to work with and for new people in compressed time frames. Students will also learn and develop a professional attitude and behaviors with which to serve clients. Prerequisite(s): BUS 392 (may be taken concurrently); BUS 393 (may be taken concurrently); FIN 301 or ENTR 304 ; and MKTG 301 .

title: Introduction to Management Information Systems
description: This course extends student knowledge in data preparation and visualization by offering hands-on expertise with workflow software, designing dashboards, and developing stories to explain data research observations. Students will apply concepts to given scenarios, providing explanations and recommendations through both written and oral communication. In addition, the course introduces common enterprise structures that support corporate information needs, including foundational concepts in information technology such as networking, relational databases, cloud resources, and data collection technologies (e.g., RFID, IoT). The course explores interorganizational systems like Electronic Data Interchange (EDI), blockchain, and related standards, while introducing students to ethical considerations in technology, emphasizing privacy, honesty, consent, and the concept of shalom in tech ethics. Prerequisite(s): DATA 102 and sophomore or higher standing, or permission of the instructor.

title: Business Enterprise Systems
description: Enterprise Systems provides students with a foundational understanding of enterprise information systems, focusing on ERP and CRM modules essential for business operations such as finance, supply chain, and manufacturing. Students gain hands-on experience with SQL, business process modeling, and data exchange standards, while exploring emerging technologies like blockchain. The course emphasizes ethical considerations around data privacy and transparency, preparing students to manage data and support decision-making within organizational systems. Prerequisite(s): CS 108 or DATA 102 , and a grade of at least a C in INFO 201 . Course fee: $15.

title: Business Analytics Management
description: This course looks at implementing and applying analytics through corporate governance, systems analysis, and decision-making models. After an introduction to enterprise architectures, students will learn how to facilitate discussions and activities to analyze existing business plans, decision methodologies, and processes to reveal sources of data for knowledge mining. Each student will experience a leadership role by facilitating a case study involving business value through analytics. Students will further explore the implications of shalom in technology ethics, as pertaining to artificial intelligence, and technology as an expression of the values of its creators Prerequisite(s): BUS 205 , DATA 202 , INFO 301 , and STAT 245 .

title: Business Analytics Project
description: This is an advanced, application-driven course that immerses students in real-world data analytics projects for external clients. Building on prior coursework, students collaborate to tackle complex tasks such as data cleansing, dashboard development, digital roadmap creation, and process mapping. Through hands-on projects, students refine their technical skills in data management, system integration, and analytics while learning to engage professionally with clients. Emphasizing ethical data handling and iterative development, it prepares students to deliver data-driven solutions and make strategic contributions in dynamic business environments. Prerequisite(s): INFO 302 .

title: Data Wrangling
description: 1. Collecting, managing and processing large data sets is critical to business analytics and data science. This course focuses on the core skills and concepts needed to pull data from a range of sources both inside and outside of organizations; to filter, transform, and combine data sets to prepare them for data cleaning and analysis; and construct quantitative summaries and basic visualizations. Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Predictive Analytics
description: 1. Businesses leverage increasingly large collections of data about people, products, and processes. Predictive analytics provides tools to discover patterns and anticipate trends in such data. This course introduces the foundational principles of predictive analytics and provides a survey of a wide range of predictive methods, both battle-tested classics and emerging high-capacity deep learning models. Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Data Visualization
description: 1. An introduction to the principles and practices of effective data visualization as an essential skill for learning from data and for communicating with others, both within and outside of an organization. Students will combine principles from statistics, psychology and computer science to design and create visualizations and use them to communicate with and about data to stakeholders and others. Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: CHEM 100
description: This is a general survey course designed for the non-science major and the elementary education student. The course explores the role of chemistry and its resulting technologies in the environment and contemporary society. It emphasizes the nature of scientific investigation, some historical developments in chemical theory, chemical periodicity and reactivity, and our daily interaction with synthetic materials and chemicals. The course is taught from a biblical worldview and addresses issues such as the validity and limitations of scientific knowledge, human responsibility in applying such knowledge in society, and the care and stewardship of natural resources.

title: The Molecular World
description: This is a general survey course designed for the non-science major and the elementary education student. The course explores the role of chemistry and its resulting technologies in the environment and contemporary society. It emphasizes the nature of scientific investigation, some historical developments in chemical theory, chemical periodicity and reactivity, and our daily interaction with synthetic materials and chemicals. The course is taught from a biblical worldview and addresses issues such as the validity and limitations of scientific knowledge, human responsibility in applying such knowledge in society, and the care and stewardship of natural resources.

title: General Chemistry I
description: This course is a study of the basic principles of chemistry, with emphasis on the laws of chemical combination; descriptive inorganic chemistry; thermochemistry; the gas, liquid, and solid states of matter; the periodic law; atomic structure; and chemical bonding. The course is taught from a biblical and reformed worldview and addresses issues such as the validity and limitations of scientific knowledge, the methodology of the physical sciences, human responsibility in applying such knowledge in society, and the care and stewardship of natural resources. Prerequisite(s): one year of high-school chemistry or permission of the instructor. Corequisite(s): CHEM 101L .

title: General Chemistry I Lab
description: This laboratory course focuses on learning key laboratory skills and using them knowledgeably to carry out chemical experiments that relate closely to the material of the CHEM 101 lecture. Corequisite(s): CHEM 101 . Lab fee: $195.

title: General Chemistry II
description: A continuation of CHEM 101 with emphasis on kinetics, chemical equilibria involving gases, weak acids and bases, and slightly soluble solids, free energy changes, electrochemistry, transition metal chemistry, descriptive chemistry, and nuclear chemistry. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 101 with a grade of C or better, or the equivalent. Corequisite(s): CHEM 102L .

title: General Chemistry II Lab
description: This laboratory course focuses on learning key laboratory skills and using them knowledgeably to carry out chemical experiments that relate closely to the material of the CHEM 102 lecture. Corequisite(s): CHEM 102 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Accelerated General Chemistry
description: A one-semester study of the basic principles of chemistry, this course is an alternative to the CHEM 101 -CHEM 102 sequence for students who plan to major in science and have a strong background in chemistry and/or mathematics. This course covers all of general chemistry in a single semester by focusing on the phaseology, chemical structure, energetics, and kinetics of chemical reactions. Additional topics include acid/base chemistry, electrochemistry, and nuclear chemistry. The final exam for this course is equivalent to that for CHEM 102 . Prerequisite(s): a strong background in high school chemistry or an AP Chemistry score of 4/5. Corequisite(s): CHEM 103L .

title: Accelerated General Chemistry Lab
description: This laboratory course focuses on learning key laboratory skills and using them knowledgeably to carry out chemical experiments that relate closely to the material of the CHEM 103 lecture. Corequisite(s): CHEM 103 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Culinary Medicine
description: Alternate years. Culinary medicine is an evidence-based field that combines nutrition and culinary knowledge in maintaining health and preventative care. This course will examine several common diets and the associated health benefits, and focus on the whole food, plant-based diet that is an ideal diet for both human and planetary health. Students will learn about dietary behavior changes and food chemistry as well as practice cooking skills that lead to a healthier diet. Through this course, students will see how food and cooking can be incorporated into healthcare and community goals. Course fee: $50.

title: Organic Chemistry for Educators
description: This survey course is specifically for the preparation of high school (7-12) science teachers as well as those who opt to specialize in chemistry education. The fundamental concepts of organic chemistry and biochemistry are presented with an emphasis on the chemical nature of biological systems. Topics such as structure, functional groups, and chemical reactivity are illustrated using common organic molecules, including enzymes, buffers, and cellular energy metabolism. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 101 and CHEM 102 , or equivalent.

title: Chemistry for the Health Sciences
description: This survey course is specifically designed for those planning for a health care major, including nursing or other allied health science careers that require a chemistry course. The fundamental concepts of general chemistry, organic chemistry, and biochemistry are presented with an emphasis on the chemical nature of biological systems. Topics such as molecular bonding and structure, equilibrium chemistry, and chemical reactivity are illustrated by acid/base reactions and redox reactions, presented in a biological context such as membranes, enzymes, buffers, and cellular energy metabolism. Issues regarding the ethics and stewardship of health will also be discussed. Prerequisite(s): high school chemistry. Corequisite(s): CHEM 160L .

title: Chemistry for the Health Sciences Lab
description: This laboratory course focuses on observing key concepts and basic laboratory skills that relate closely to the material of the CHEM 160 lecture. Corequisite(s): CHEM 160 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Chemistry, Policy, and the Future of Our Planet
description: Students interested in public health, public policy, or advocacy work should know the science behind chemical advances and natural phenomena so that they can make decisions that promote the sustainable flourishing of the planet. This course will provide students with chemical principles related to direct application of chemistry to the environment (pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers) as well as additional applications including drinking water, climate change, energy sources (combustion, solar, nuclear), batteries, and consumer products. Students will learn about past, current, and possible government policies (federal, state, local) that can be used to regulate and incentivize chemistry for flourishing. Lab fee: $50.

title: Water, Water, Water
description: Alternate years. There are many ways to understand water: it is a substance that can be studied chemically, it is a resource that can be studied politically and economically, and it is a symbol that can be studied philosophically. Students will learn about the chemical nature of water and how its molecular structure determines its ability to host so many important chemical reactions and processes. Throughout the course, students will also learn about the availability and right to water for all humans as they rely on water for survival, enjoyment, and significance. Course fee: $50.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Honors Chemistry
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will investigate a variety of contemporary topics and challenges within the field of chemistry through an interdisciplinary lens. Students will learn foundational chemistry concepts, develop an appreciation for the investigatory process of science as a value-laden collaborative enterprise, explore the reliability of scientific knowledge, and consider social and ethical aspects of scientific methodologies and findings. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Analytical Chemistry
description: Features a problem-solving approach that incorporates sampling, sample preparation, separation of analytes from interfering substances, measurement and data analysis interpretation. Quantitative analysis is presented in the context of analytical methods that include statistics of sample measurements (significance tests, outlier tests, linear regression), separation science (gas, liquid, and chromatography), optical spectroscopy (UV-visible, fluorescence, and atomic absorption spectroscopy), and electrochemistry (electrode potentials, and ion-selective electrodes). Highly recommended for 1st- and 2nd-year students, and not open to seniors except by permission. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 102 or CHEM 103 . Corequisite(s): CHEM 210L .

title: Analytical Chemistry Lab
description: Experiments applying analytical chemistry to art, nanotechnology, spectroscopy, gas- and liquid-based separations, and forensic science will be performed. Relevant statistical methods to data analysis will be performed. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 102L or CHEM 103L . Corequisite(s): CHEM 210 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Essential Inorganic Chemistry
description: This foundational course for 1st- and 2nd-year students covers the properties and trends of molecules derived from across the periodic table, with emphasis on the main group elements. Topics covered include periodicity, bonding, symmetry, and reactivity. Special attention will be given to visualization tools for molecular structures. Upon completion of the course, students will be prepared to critically compare and contrast molecular and biomolecular structures with chemical reactions presented in subsequent course work throughout the science division. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 240 or CHEM 241 with a grade of C or better, or approval of the instructor (can also be taken concurrently). Corequisite(s): CHEM 230L .

title: Essential Inorganic Chemistry Lab
description: Fundamental analytical and synthetic techniques associated with an inorganic chemistry laboratory will be learned. This includes the ability to safely run aqueous inorganic reactions and characterize products using a wide array of techniques (UV-Visible Absorbance, Magnetometry, Cyclic voltammetry, and Computational Chemistry). A lab notebook will be maintained, and completed experiments will be summarized in written lab reports. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 240L or CHEM 241L . Corequisite(s): CHEM 230 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Survey of Organic Chemistry
description: A study of organic compounds, reactions, and reaction mechanisms, emphasizing their biochemical significance. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 102 or CHEM 103 with a grade of C or better, or approval of the instructor. Corequisite(s): CHEM 240L .

title: Survey of Organic Chemistry Lab
description: Fundamental analytical and synthetic techniques associated with an organic chemistry laboratory will be learned. This includes the ability to safely run organic reactions, work up and purify synthesized products, and characterize them with data obtained via modern instrumentation such as IR and NMR spectrometers. A lab notebook will be maintained, and completed experiments will be summarized in written lab reports. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 102L or CHEM 103L . Corequisite(s): CHEM 240 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Organic Chemistry I
description: A detailed study of organic compounds, their synthesis, and reactions, presented within the framework of modern physicochemical theory, together with an introduction to modern methods of analysis and identification. Majors and minors enrolling in this course must also take CHEM 242 . Highly recommended for 2nd-year students, and not open to seniors except by permission. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 102 or CHEM 103 with a grade of C or better, or approval of the instructor. Corequisite(s): CHEM 241L .

title: Organic Chemistry I Lab
description: Introductory synthetic techniques associated with an organic chemistry laboratory will be learned. This includes the ability to safely run organic reactions and to work up and purify synthesized products. Introductory use of modern instrumentation such as IR and NMR spectrometers will complement benchtop techniques. A lab notebook will be maintained, and completed experiments will be summarized in written lab reports. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 102L or CHEM 103L . Corequisite(s): CHEM 241 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Physical Chemistry
description: A study of macroscopic properties of matter as described by chemical thermodynamics and kinetics. Major topics include the laws of thermodynamics and their application to pure substances, chemical reactions, solutions, physical and chemical equilibria, and reaction kinetics. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 210 or ENGR 209 ; MATH 171 or MATH 132 ; and a university physics course. Corequisite(s): CHEM 351L .

title: Physical Chemistry I Lab
description: Laboratory offering experience with fundamental thermodynamic properties (internal energy, enthalpy, entropy), measurement of fundamental physical properties, determination of molar mass, properties of mixtures and chemical kinetics, along with techniques for analysis of experimental data. Corequisite(s): CHEM 351 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Principles of Biochemistry
description: How does chemistry help us understand biological systems? This course is an introduction to the principles of biochemistry in which we focus on the structure and function of proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, and nucleic acids. The fundamentals of signaling and metabolism and their associated mechanisms of regulation will also be introduced. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 240 or CHEM 242 ; and BIOL 161 . Corequisite(s): BCHM 321L .

title: Principles of Biochemistry Lab
description: This lab will introduce modern biochemical separation and analytical techniques. Students will collect and analyze experimental data related to protein expression, purification, and characterization. A particular emphasis will be placed on learning to clearly explain biochemical results and their applications in a research setting. Corequisite(s): BCHM 321 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Metabolism and Metabolic Disease
description: Metabolism is the set of chemical reactions that occur in living organisms to produce energy and the molecules that are necessary to sustain life. This course will explore cellular metabolism with a focus on the relationships between key metabolic pathways and human diseases. The primary goal of this course is to explore the ways in which chemical principles play fundamental roles in biological systems and how changes to these systems contribute to disease phenotypes. Prerequisite(s): BCHM 321 . Corequisite(s): BCHM 322L .

title: Metabolism and Metabolic Disease Lab
description: In this literature lab, students will broaden their exposure to metabolism and metabolic diseases through weekly presentations and discussions of research data and primary literature. Students will learn how to engage effectively with the primary literature in the field of biochemistry. Corequisite(s): BCHM 322 .

title: Venom
description: Living cells and organisms must respond to their environment, which allows them to adapt to a variety of external conditions. We will use the language of chemistry (thermodynamics, kinetics, analysis, reactivity, and modeling) to explore systems of interactions and regulations within and between cells. Students will learn how signaling and regulation within complex biological systems leads to biological function, behavior, homeostasis, adaptation, and the emergence of new traits. We will then use these tools to examine the biochemistry of how animals, insects, plants, and microbes employ toxins to disrupt signaling pathways as a means of defense or attack. Prerequisite(s): BCHM 321 . Corequisite(s): BCHM 323L .

title: Venom Lab
description: This lab will expand students’ understanding of protein interactions and how they relate cellular responses to toxins such as venom. Students will engage with common biochemical techniques used to study signaling pathways and learn approaches to study the disruption of those pathways in model organisms. Corequisite(s): BCHM 323 . Lab fee: $100.

title: Proteins Gone Awry
description: Proteins play a multitude of roles in cell structure and function. To understand these roles, this class will go deeper into how the unique three-dimensional structures of proteins arise and influence their roles in catalysis, regulation, recognition, and information storage. Special attention will be paid to protein mutations. Students will develop an enhanced structural, thermodynamic, and dynamic understanding of biomacromolecules and their biological functions. Students will also explore how alternations in structure confer new biological properties on proteins. Prerequisite(s): BCHM 321 . Corequisite(s): BCHM 324L .

title: Proteins Gone Awry Lab
description: This lab will explore how changing environmental conditions impact a variety of protein structures and functions. The impact of environmental changes will be assessed by measuring properties such as protein folding or enzyme kinetics. Computational modeling will also be used to better visualize macromolecules and key elements of their stability and regulation. Corequisite(s): BCHM 324 . Lab fee: $100.

title: Organic Chemistry II
description: A continuation of CHEM 241 . Prerequisite(s): CHEM 241 with a grade of C or better, or approval of the instructor. Corequisite(s): CHEM 242L . Students completing a BA in chemistry or biochemistry may elect to take this course without completing CHEM 242L .

title: Organic Chemistry II Lab
description: A continuation of CHEM 241L . Corequisite(s): CHEM 242 . Lab fee: $195.

title: Forensics and Toxicology
description: Chemistry and chemical techniques play a pivotal role in the disciplines of forensic science and toxicology. In this course, students will learn how to apply presumptive and confirmatory tests for specific applications in forensic science. Students will then explore the chemistry of poisons at the trace element and molecular level, and the chemical and biochemical mechanisms of toxicity. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 210 . Corequisite(s): CHEM 311L .

title: Forensics and Toxicology Lab
description: In this lab, students will learn to differentiate between presumptive and confirmatory forensic tests. Students will engage in hands-on activities using GC-MS, FTIR, and X-ray fluorescence to analyze toxic substances and fibers. Advanced instrumental approaches and simulations will also be used to study poison-receptor binding and binding effects. Corequisite(s): CHEM 311 . Lab fee: $100.

title: Evolving Complexity
description: How do you create increasingly large and complex molecules? Central to answering this question is the ability to control a reaction’s mechanism, product distribution, or material properties. This course will focus on the synthesis of complicated molecules. Synthesis encompasses a variety of strategies, such as total synthesis, biosynthesis, and polymeric synthesis. Special attention will be paid to asymmetric control of traditional organic reactions, particularly using catalytic methods, as well as the growing application of catalysis and synthetic methods for the generation of high-performance polymers. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 240 or CHEM 242 . Corequisite(s): CHEM 341L .

title: Evolving Complexity Lab
description: In this lab, students will complete sequential, multi-step syntheses based on procedures found in the literature. All compounds prepared will be characterized using spectroscopic methods and other instrumental techniques. Organometallic catalysts will be made and evaluated for their application to complex connections and chiral induction. Special attention will be paid to the synthesis and use of polymers in complex transformations. Corequisite(s): CHEM 341 . Lab fee: $100.

title: The Quantum World
description: An understanding of the fundamentals of quantum mechanics is valuable for every chemistry and biochemistry student. Exploring foundational questions, this course emphasizes solving the Schrödinger equation to understand the ultimate sources of microscopic modes of motion, including translation, vibration, rotation, as well as electronic transitions. Students will cultivate an understanding of quantum chemistry, equipping them to unravel the intricacies of chemical bonding and molecular spectroscopy. This course opens the door to the mysteries of quantum phenomena and provides a platform for continued studies in chemistry, physics, or related fields. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 210 , CHEM 230 , CHEM 240 , or CHEM 242 ; and MATH 171 . Corequisite(s): CHEM 353L .

title: The Quantum World Lab
description: This lab offers a practical and hands-on approach to exploring experimental and computational applications of quantum chemistry, including molecular spectroscopy, electronic structure calculations, and the utilization of lasers in various experiments. Through these hands-on activities, students will gain experience in applying quantum chemical principles to real-world scenarios, preparing them for future studies and careers in the chemical and physical sciences. Corequisite(s): CHEM 353 . Lab fee: $100.

title: Chemistry and Sustainability: Life Cycle of an Electric Car
description: Industrial chemistry shapes our lives and impacts the environment in many substantial ways. Along with the amazing advances that result from materials technology, many processes also negatively impact the environment. This course will address selected topics from areas of chemistry that impact our climate, our habitat, and human health. Emphasis will be on the chemistry and thermodynamics of these processes with a focus not only on the production but also on the deconstruction to assess the overall sustainability of a marquee example: the electric car. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 210 , CHEM 230 , CHEM 240 , or CHEM 242 . Corequisite(s): CHEM 371L .

title: Chemistry and Sustainability Lab
description: In this lab, students will conduct experiments related to battery chemistry and electrochemical processes. Students will also explore aspects of sustainability, including atmospheric impacts, minimizing mining and maximizing recycling, to understand the environmental impact of technologies and how they may be made more sustainable. Corequisite(s): CHEM 371 . Lab fee: $100.

title: Molecules in the Spotlight: Nanoparticles
description: This course will introduce students to nanomaterials with a special focus on the synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles. Various applications of nanoparticles from cosmetics to targeted drug delivery in medicine to their potential toxicity will be introduced. A particular focus will be placed on understanding instrumental methods used to characterize the physical and chemical properties of nanoparticles with a special emphasis on using a UV-Vis spectrophotometer. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 210 . Corequisite(s): CHEM 372L .

title: Molecules in the Spotlight Lab
description: In this lab, students will perform hands-on experiments with the synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles. Analysis of the nanoparticles will be accomplished with various approaches, starting with UV-Vis spectroscopy. Students will explore the various components of a single-beam and dual-beam UV spectrometer and monitor the catalytic activity of nanoparticles by time-resolved UV-vis spectroscopy. Students will use additional instrumental techniques (FTIR, MP-AES, XRF) and visualization techniques (Atomic Force Microscopy, Image Analysis) to further characterize nanoparticles. Corequisite(s): CHEM 372 . Lab fee: $100.

title: Elements in Transition
description: The d-orbitals dominate the chemistry of the transition metals. Though limited in abundance, these elements with their special electronic structure can be found all over the planet and used in nature and by humans to do everything from catalyzing functional reactions to forming exquisite structures. Students in this course will go deeper into various aspects of metal chemistry. Areas for exploration are supramolecular chemistry, coordination chemistry, organometallic chemistry, materials science, and metals in biological systems and processes. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 230 . Corequisite(s): CHEM 373L .

title: Elements in Transition Lab
description: In this lab, students will study systems that include metal ions using (bio)synthetic, spectroscopic, and computational methods. These experiments will prepare students to make and characterize the wide variety of molecules and materials that include transition metals. Corequisite(s): CHEM 373 . Lab fee: $100.

title: Chemistry Seminar
description: A seminar devoted to an exploration of topics in current chemical research in both academic and industrial laboratories. To be taken a minimum of twice by chemistry and biochemistry BA students and three times by those pursuing a BS or ACS-Certified degree. Junior and senior chemistry majors are encouraged to attend.

title: Independent Study
description: Directed readings or projects. Admission by permission of the chair and instructor under whom the work will be done. To be enrolled in this course, the student must submit a completed research agreement form to the office of academic services and the department office.

title: Academic Year Research
description: Research on a project selected in consultation with a faculty member at Calvin University during the academic year. 45 hours per credit if taken for credit, or 45 hours per semester hour toward an ACS or honors chemistry degree if taken for zero credit. This course may be taken more than once. The student will be required to write a report and complete all tasks specified by the supervisor. To be enrolled in this course, the student must submit a completed research agreement form to the office of academic services and the department office.

title: Seminar Presentation
description: A research presentation is given in CHEM 295 . In anticipation of enrolling in this course, the student should notify the faculty advisor and the faculty member who organizes the CHEM 295 seminar course as soon as possible.

title: Writing a Formal Research Report
description: Students will complete a formal written report consistent with the requirements of their chemistry subdiscipline. The report will be written based on data collected during a research project or as a part of a 300-level chemistry lab. As part of the ACS degree, the report will be reviewed by a department committee of two additional chemistry faculty alongside the supervising faculty. Prerequisite(s): acquisition of scientific data that can be the basis for a formal lab report through CHEM 394 , CHEM 397 , or a 300-level chemistry lab. Students must have at least junior status.

title: Summer Research
description: This course indicates the completion of supervised research (~400 hours) during the summer related to chemistry or biochemistry. A student who has been accepted into a summer research program, either at Calvin or elsewhere, should register for this course during the summer in which they are completing the research. The student will be required to write a report and complete all tasks specified by their supervisor. This course may be completed more than once.

title: Major Field Test
description: A single test covering all subdisciplines that is administered to all students graduating with a chemistry or biochemistry major. Prerequisite(s): successful completion of all other courses required for a chemistry or biochemistry major.

title: The Science and Art of Modern Medicine
description: Students will explore the complex and dynamic landscape of modern medicine through the lenses of evidence-based practice, ethics, and emerging scientific frontiers. Students will examine the scientific and empirical foundations of diagnosis and treatment, analyze the impact of lifestyle and environmental factors on health, and examine the role of AI and statistical data in medical training. Through weekly case studies and discussions, students will grapple with critical ethical questions in healthcare, the challenges of equitable care, and the delicate task of medical communication with patients. By examining the intersection of science, ethics, and social responsibility, this course prepares students to understand medicine not only as a clinical practice but as a multidisciplinary field shaped by global, societal, and technological shifts. Students will be assessed through written, oral, and video presentations. Prerequisite(s): senior status in a biochemical or biological sciences program, or permission of the instructor.

title: Internship in Chemistry
description: Off-campus chemistry internships can be arranged for qualified students. Students work at least 60 hours per credit, under the supervision of an off-campus employer-supervisor and an internship coordinator. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship can be counted toward graduation requirements. Interns meet with their faculty coordinator regularly and submit a final written report summarizing their internship experience. The off-campus supervisor sends in an evaluation report on the work of the intern. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry and have received approval from the Department Chair. Applications can be initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department. To be enrolled in this course, the student must submit a completed and signed research agreement form to the office of academic services.

title: Elementary Chinese I
description: An introduction to Chinese language and culture, stressing both spoken and written Chinese. After one semester, students will be able to carry on simple conversations in (Mandarin) Chinese, read dialogues written in Chinese, and understand some fundamentals of Chinese social values and ways of thinking. Approximately 300 Chinese characters will be introduced.

title: Elementary Chinese II
description: A continuation of CHIN 101 . Continued study of Chinese grammar, with equal emphasis on improving conversational proficiency and on reading and writing Chinese. Another 300 Chinese characters will be introduced for reading and writing and as a medium for gaining insight into Chinese culture. Prerequisite(s): CHIN 101 or permission of the instructor.

title: Intermediate Chinese I
description: A continuation of CHIN 101 . Continued study of Chinese grammar, with equal emphasis on improving conversational proficiency and on reading and writing Chinese. Another 300 Chinese characters will be introduced for reading and writing and as a medium for gaining insight into Chinese culture. Prerequisite(s): CHIN 102 or permission of the instructor.

title: Intermediate Chinese II
description: A continuation of CHIN 201 . Completion of the study of basic Chinese grammar and further study of the Chinese writing system, with continued emphasis on both speaking and reading. Two hundred more characters are taught for reading comprehension and cultural understanding. Prerequisite(s): CHIN 201 or permission of the instructor.

title: Classical Literature
description: As needed. This is a study of the major works of Greek and Roman literature from Homer to Augustine. The course devotes attention to the origins and development of Greek epic, lyric, drama, and historiography, and to their transformation in the literature of Rome and the church fathers. Artistic and archaeological evidence supplements the study of the texts. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Classical Mythology
description: Alternate years. This is a study of the major themes in classical mythology via the literature and art of Greece and Rome. The course includes a study of major literary sources in translation and major art works of both cultures, with special attention to various interpretations of the myths and the works of art they have influenced in the development of Western culture. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum may be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Oral Rhetoric
description: What is one of the top skills all employers look for in future employees? Effective oral communication. Being able to speak well in public also will help you in other courses, student and community groups, and in your church. In this course you will learn the fundamental skills of oral rhetoric—how to create a message strategically adapted for a specific audience (for this semester, your fellow students in this class) and situation. You will also learn how to effectively deliver your speeches and how to be an engaged, thoughtful listener.

title: Visual Rhetoric
description: In this course, we will learn both how to “read” and create images that persuade others. We will study the strengths and weaknesses of both images and words; using that knowledge, we can better analyze and create messages that use both visual and written rhetoric. We also will examine the ethical responsibility of both viewers and creators of images so that we are truthful, respectful, and fair in our practices. Building on this knowledge, we will finish the course with students creating intentional, ethical persuasive messages adapted to a well-defined target audience.

title: Introduction to Film and Media
description: A study of film and other moving image media as art forms and cultural phenomena, including dramatic, visual, and sonic elements, theme and focus, acting, and directorial style. Topics covered include the materials and methods of media production, the major styles and genres of moving image media, and the relationship of film and television to American and world culture. Course work includes a mandatory weekly screening (lab) and readings in the history, theory, and criticism of film and television. Corequisite(s): COMM 145L .

title: Introduction to Film and Media Lab
description: Corequisite lab course for COMM 145 . Corequisite(s): COMM 145 .

title: Communicating with Digital Media
description: An introduction to the principles and practice of communicating a message to an audience through digital images (still pictures, moving pictures, and graphics) and digital sound (voice, music, ambient sound, and sound effects). Students will learn the fundamental techniques of preproduction planning, camera use, lighting, sound, and editing in order to communicate their ideas effectively, artistically, and ethically. Students also will learn to communicate their messages through digital channels, especially the Internet. The course will enable students interested in social media, public relations, advertising, journalism, corporate training, sales, e-learning, publishing, worship, and the arts to realize ideas through sound and image. Students intending to take advanced Media Production courses must take COMM 190 .

title: Media Production I
description: An introductory course in film-style production. Instruction includes sound and image capture, editing, pre-production planning, and lighting. Students will produce a series of exercises and a short film. Equipment is provided. This course is a prerequisite for 200- and 300-level film and media production courses.

title: Advanced Oral Rhetoric
description: Through careful study and practice of the principles of effective, ethical, and eloquent oral rhetoric, students will become excellent communicators and will appreciate excellent oral communication. This course teaches students the composition and presentation of various types of speeches, building on the student learning and experiences of COMM 101 so that students become exemplary speech writers and speakers, adapting to various audiences and speaking situations. Prerequisite(s): COMM 101 or equivalent.

title: New Media
description: This course offers students an advanced understanding of new media technologies, especially the ways in which new media have influenced human communication practices. Students will investigate online communities, virtual environments, new media technologies, digital communication strategies, and a variety of contemporary issues in the computerization of communication in work, home, church and public discourse. Students will explore in-depth social media and video games and will learn how to create effective, ethical social media content strategies.

title: Calvin Media Company
description: Students learn basic media production skills by contributing to the creation of a film, radio, and/or television production in the context of an advanced student project, a client project, or under the supervision of a staff and/or faculty advisor. Students may participate more than one semester, but no more than four semester hours may be applied toward major or graduation requirements. Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.

title: Screenwriting
description: An introduction to the content, styles, structure, and format of screenplays. The course emphasizes the role of the screenplay as text in screen storytelling, the styles of writing used, and the technical requirements for screenplays used to focus the work of directors, actors, camera, and sound technicians, editors and mixers in creating a media product. Prerequisite(s): COMM 145 , COMM 190 , and ENGL 101 ; or permission of the instructor.

title: Audio Storytelling
description: This course introduces basic audio principles for filmmaking and podcasting, including interview and field recording techniques, and basic mixing, editing, and effects. This course is a prerequisite for COMM 290 .

title: Camera Production
description: An introduction to the theory and practice of studio-based video production. Various program formats are discussed and evaluated in light of particular communication principles and needs. Students gain experience with stationary video cameras, recorders, switchers, and related technologies. Performance for the camera, studio lighting, audio recording, and mixing principles are analyzed and demonstrated. Prerequisite(s): COMM 190 .

title: Live and Studio Audio Production
description: This course introduces students to multitrack studio recording and front-of-house mixing techniques, including the use of advanced consoles and microphone setups. Prerequisite(s): COMM 249 .

title: Screen Storytelling: Theory and Criticism
description: This course focuses on the theory and criticism of film and media storytelling, both fiction and nonfiction. Students critically engage with academic writing and criticism published in magazines, newspapers, and other media outlets with a focus on the relation and practice of theory and criticism.

title: Documentary Film and Television
description: Alternate years. This course offers an examination of the history, aesthetics, ethics, and cultural and institutional functions of documentary film and television.

title: Communication and Conflict Resolution
description: An introduction to the theory and practice of communication and conflict resolution. Students will investigate the dynamics of conflict, theories of communication relevant to conflict resolution, conflict resolution processes and strategies. Students will learn skills that will enable them to assume leadership roles in the resolution of conflict, whether in the workplace, in the church, in political forums or at the international level. This knowledge can be applied in a variety of contexts: friendships, small groups, families, church, workplace, and community.

title: Leadership Communication for Organizations
description: This course examines both the theoretical and applied dimensions of leadership, focusing on the communicative aspects of leaders and leadership. Course content covers models of leadership, leadership styles, factors that impact the perceptions of leadership, leadership ethics, and many approaches to writing and speaking as a leader.

title: Public Relations and Communication Practice
description: In this course students will examine how and why organizations use public relations to influence various publics. The course emphasizes the historical development of public relations as well as current issues in these industries. We will cover the tools of communication and the numerous publics involved.

title: Advertising and Communication Strategies
description: In this course students will examine how and why organizations use Advertising as a discipline to build and promote brands. The course emphasizes the professional tools and strategies used in the industry to employ best practices in effective and ethical mass communication.

title: Strategic Sports Communication
description: This course covers the fundamentals of sports communication theory, research, and practice, enabling students to communicate well in a variety of sports environments. The course covers organizational and leadership communication in sports, sports and mass media and social media, sports and public relations and crisis communication, and sports communication and society. The course also teaches ethical and legal issues in sports communication practice. The final project involves creating an effective media or social media presence for a sports team.

title: Media Production II
description: An intermediate-level course in digital filmmaking. The course includes further development of technical and creative skills, with special emphasis on the on-set world of independent fiction filmmaking. The goal of the course is to prepare students for COMM 351 , which may be taken as either Documentary or Fiction. The course also introduces students to the process by which films are produced, the aesthetic and ethical challenges that this process demands, and how Christians working in the media should respond to such demands. Prerequisite(s): COMM 145 , COMM 190 , and COMM 249 . Corequisite(s): COMM 290L

title: Media Communication II Lab
description: Lab section for COMM 290 . Corequisite(s): COMM 290 .

title: Persuasion and Propaganda
description: This course examines the theory and practice of persuasive communication. Topics include persuasion theory and research; ethics of persuasion; recognizing, employing, and resisting persuasive strategies; and the role of propaganda in society. Examples for analysis are taken from religion, advertising, political campaigns, social movements, and democratic and totalitarian propaganda.

title: Argumentation and Advocacy
description: Through careful study and practice of informal logic and rhetoric, students will become effective advocates, opponents, and decision makers in any argument context. The course is a study and application of basic principles of argumentation and advocacy. This course focuses on the dynamics of oral argument-ethical dimensions, use of language, informal logic, use of evidence and appeals, structure, and interactions with other arguments. Through analysis and practice, students will learn not only how to argue within academic contexts but also how to apply argumentative reasoning to everyday communication.

title: Directing for the Screen
description: Alternate years. An introduction to the practice and theory of directing. Through readings, critical analysis of scripts, discussions, performance exercises, and critique of live and filmed performance, students develop an understanding of the directing process from the inception of the script to the final product. Students create a full directorial analysis of a script and produce several finished scenes, applying rehearsal techniques, working with actors and learning to enhance their own productions through careful criticism and thoughtful assessment of the art of directing.

title: Advanced Calvin Media Company
description: Experienced students contribute specific media production skills to the creation of a film, radio, and/or television production in the context of an advanced student project or under the supervision of a staff and/or faculty advisor. Students may participate more than one semester, but no more than four semester hours may be applied toward major or graduation requirements. Requires proposal and permission of instructor for approved projects only. Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Media and Society
description: A study of the role of diverse forms of media in society and an examination of critical and cultural perspectives on media. The course examines the media as a source of influential narratives and offers an understanding of the relationship of media to democracy, capitalism, technology, audiences, media institutions, and economics.

title: Internship in Communication
description: In this weekly seminar course, students reflect on how to work, relate, and communicate effectively in professional settings. Academic work includes weekly seminar participation, readings, journals, a presentation, and a professional portfolio. Grading is based on these requirements as well as the internship supervisor’s evaluation. Students must intern in a professional setting (for-profit or non-profit) a minimum of 10 hours each week throughout the semester they are enrolled in the course. Before the semester begins, students should find an internship that fits with their professional interests and will provide them with opportunities for new learning under the supervision of an expert. In order to engage the various levels of learning that an internship affords, we require students to intern off-campus and prefer that they work on-site at an organization rather than telecommuting. Prerequisite(s): junior or senior status, and a 2.5 GPA.

title: Media Production III
description: The intensive study and production of video in a particular style or genre. Thorough investigation of creative, ethical, and technical requirements will culminate in student productions of short films. Offered as fiction every spring semester, and as documentary in alternate fall semesters. Prerequisite(s): COMM 290 .

title: Advanced Project in Media Production
description: Teams of students complete department-approved media production projects over the course of two semesters (2 credit hours per semester, total 4 credit hours). This capstone experience gives students the opportunity to apply concepts and techniques acquired in prerequisite courses by developing and producing an independent media project. Students in this course lead a team that may include students participating via COMM 322 or COMM 222 for one credit hour in one or both semesters. (Note: this course must be taken in consecutive semesters.) Prerequisite(s): a grade of B or higher in COMM 351 and permission of the instructor.

title: Health Communication Theory and Practice
description: This course introduces students to the broad and complex field of health communication through the study of multi-disciplinary research, theory, and health communication practice in interpersonal, small group, organizational, and mass-mediated contexts. Through analyzing crucial contemporary health issues, ethical dilemmas, case studies, and creating a health intervention campaign, students explore the centrality of communication for increasing health literacy, decreasing unhealthy behavior, and closing the health care inequity gap.

title: Small Group and Organizational Communication
description: Alternating years. This course is designed to guide class members through the issues and research literature related to communication within and from organizations and small groups. We focus on approaches, theories, and research findings concerning conceptions of organizations, various traditions in the study of organizations, metaphors for organizational communication, culture and climate within organizations, group processes, leadership, socialization/assimilation/membership negotiation, power, motivation/performance, organizational innovation and change, team-based structures and alternative forms of organizing, and strategic organizational communication. The unit of analysis undergirding the course is the actions of individuals or groups within organizations, especially actors’ messages and symbolic interactions, as well as the behavior of entire organizations or sets of organizations. Although organizations are such an ever-present, taken-for-granted aspect of our lives, you may not have developed a full understanding of them. For this reason, this course includes activities and assignments designed to enhance appreciation and analysis of organizations and organizational communication. The course also addresses competencies needed to communicate effectively in organizations and those skills useful for aiding others in organizations to attain personal and organizational goals.

title: Topics in Film and Media History
description: In-depth study of a major period, movement, national cinema, development, genre, director, or producer in film and media history. An exploration of film and media as a complex phenomenon, an art form, and technology-based medium of communication in the context of culture, technology, society, and economics. Each year’s offering alternates between an emphasis on the history of Hollywood film and an emphasis on the history of global cinemas. This course may be repeated as long as the topic is unique.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Independent Study
description: Independent study of topics of interest to particular students, under the supervision of a member of the department. Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.

title: Special Topics in Communication
description: Topic, readings, and assignments will be announced prior to the year offered. Designed for students from various majors. Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.

title: Communication, Technology, and Society
