description: This course focuses on the intersection of communication, technology, and society. Students will investigate the history and functions of relevant communication technologies, theories of communicative practice, the ethics of communication technologies, the personal and social implications of communicating via technology, and current developments in communication technologies.

title: Advanced Communication Study
description: A focused study of selected topics in a discipline of communication (film, media, rhetoric, or theatre) that builds upon previous communication coursework, methods, and theories. Coursework involves lecture, discussion, seminar presentations, and the preparation of a major research paper or project. Prerequisite(s): two advanced courses within the department, and junior or senior status.

title: Basics of Media Production
description: This eight-week course will train students in the basic skills of audiovisual media design. Students will work hands-on with the essential technology and software to begin building the necessary skillsets to become fluent and engaging multimedia content producers.

title: Media Production Studio
description: A media production studio course which supports and facilitates student completion of media production work assigned in any of four corequisite courses: COMM 510 , COMM 520 , COMM 521 , and COMM 522 . One section of this course will be offered per term, and students must enroll in it each term they enroll in one or more of the four corequisites listed above.

title: Storytelling across Media Platforms
description: A study of the principles of storytelling integrating theory, critique, and hands-on experience as a way of learning best practices and understanding what makes for effective multimedia storytelling. Students will learn to become intentional about leveraging the strengths of different media to communicate synergistically in ways that single-medium stories cannot and to grasp the crucial role of perspectives in storytelling and audience reception. Prerequisite(s): COMM 500 or equivalent. Corequisite(s): COMM 501 .

title: Audience Research and Analytics
description: Audience research is significant for media organizations to find target consumers and formulate their communication strategies. This course intends to provide useful knowledge of audience research. It covers the current audience research methodologies and theories, the ratings industry and analysis processes. The major subjects of this course include sampling methods, data collection methods, quantitative methods, qualitative methods, the theories of audience behaviors, gross measures, cumulative measures, online audience research, and global audiences.

title: Communication Ethics
description: 1. Students will learn about their ethical responsibilities as professional communicators. They will investigate the principles on which those obligations and responsibilities are based—including social and cultural values, Christian virtues, and professional standards. In addition, they will learn to exercise moral and ethical reasoning when confronted with challenging situations in their vocation.

title: Communication Law
description: 2. Students will learn about their legal responsibilities as professional communicators. They will investigate the principles on which those obligations and responsibilities are based, including professional standards. In addition, they will learn to exercise moral and ethical reasoning when confronted with challenging situations in their vocation.

title: Advanced Public Relations
description: This course introduces students to the strategic planning process, communication strategies, and message creation involved in public relations. Students will learn how to develop, implement and evaluate public relations campaigns by examining case studies and creating an actual campaign. This course also focuses on the use of social media and other new media channels, examining how they can be employed to better serve the organization’s communication and relationship building needs. Students must enroll in COMM 501 to create the class multimedia project. Prerequisite(s): COMM 500 or equivalent. Corequisite(s): COMM 501 .

title: Advanced Advertising
description: This course explores advertising as an institution in society and as a communication process. Designed as a comprehensive view of the subject, the course includes such topics as advertising history, regulation, communication theory and practice, the role of advertising in the marketing mix, the organization of the advertising agency, marketing/advertising research, and the creative uses of various advertising media. Students will assess strategy and participate in the formulation of an advertising campaign. Students must enroll in COMM 501 to create the class multimedia campaign. Prerequisite(s): COMM 500 or equivalent. Corequisite(s): COMM 501 .

title: Multimedia Journalism
description: Multimedia journalism skills are critical in today’s newsrooms as well as in journalism-adjacent settings such as public relations and advocacy. This course will provide instruction and application in the tools and techniques of journalism production across non-text platforms. Using audio, video, web development, photography, and more, this course will cover journalistic fundamentals such as story development, reporting techniques, and editing. Students must enroll in COMM 501 to create the class multimedia project. Prerequisite(s): COMM 500 or equivalent. Corequisite(s): COMM 501 .

title: Master's Project Proposal
description: The COMM 539-COMM 540 sequence is a culmination of program learning that focuses on the creation, development, and completion of an independent final project for inclusion in student portfolios. In this course, students will explore possible projects related to applied communication careers, and through that research and exploration, develop a plan for a thorough, significant, individual final project, which will be completed in COMM 540 . Prerequisite(s): COMM 500 (or equivalent), COMM 510 , and COMM 511 .

title: Master's Project
description: The COMM 539 -COMM 540 sequence is a culmination of program learning that focuses on the creation, development, and completion of an independent final project for inclusion in student portfolios. In this course, each student works with a faculty adviser throughout the process to complete their project proposed in COMM 539 , gaining further expertise and demonstrating professional competence in strategic communication and multimedia design.

title: Skylight Media Agency
description: This course provides students with applied agency experience in public relations, advertising, and/or multimedia journalism, using a variety of media and platforms to create content for real clients. Prerequisite(s): COMM 500 (or equivalent), COMM 510 , COMM 511 , COMM 512 , COMM 520 , COMM 521 , and COMM 522 . Corequisite(s): COMM 551 .

title: Skylight Production Studio
description: A media production studio course which supports and facilitates student completion of media production work assigned in COMM 550 . Prerequisite(s): COMM 500 (or equivalent), COMM 510 , COMM 511 , COMM 520 , COMM 521 , and COMM 522 . Corequisite(s): COMM 550 .

title: Honors Rhetoric
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will address communication practices as problem-solving forms embedded within social contexts. While topics will vary from year to year, all iterations will pay particular attention to the modes—that is, the styles or postures—that circulate across the attention economies of modern societies, from digital platforms to everyday physical spaces. The interdisciplinary component will attend to how communication practices and modes are structured by conversations in other disciplines. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Creating Interactive Web Media
description: An introduction to the creation of interactive media for the World Wide Web. Coverage includes markup language, stylesheets, page layout and design principles, scripting, animation, multimedia and their representations, World Wide Web history and structure, social and ethical issues. Lab fee: $20.

title: Applied Computing
description: An introduction to problem solving and program design for engineering students. Coverage includes algorithmic thinking, problem decomposition, types and expressions, functions and parameter passing, control structures, I/O, simple data structures, and classes (including the use of inheritance). Corequisite(s): CS 104L .

title: Applied Computing Lab
description: Corequisite(s): CS 104 . Lab fee: $60.

title: Introduction to Scientific Computation and Modeling
description: An introduction to computing as a tool for science, emphasizing programming as a methodology for problem solving, quantitative data analysis, and simulation in science and mathematics. This includes in silico modeling of natural phenomena, precise specification of a problem, design of its algorithmic solution, testing, debugging, and maintaining software, using scripting to increase scientific productivity, and the use of existing scientific software libraries. A secondary emphasis is the discussion of breadth topics, including historical, theoretical, ethical and biblical perspectives on computing as a discipline. This course provides an alternative to CS 108 , providing an introduction to computing focusing on scientific examples and applications. Corequisite(s): CS 106L .

title: introduction to Scientific Computation and Modeling Lab
description: Corequisite(s): CS 106 . Lab fee: $120.

title: Introduction to Computing
description: An introduction to computing as a problem-solving discipline. A primary emphasis is on programming as a methodology for problem solving, including: the precise specification of a problem, the design of its solution, the encoding of that solution, and the testing, debugging and maintenance of programs. A secondary emphasis is the discussion of topics from the breadth of computing including historical, theoretical, ethical and biblical perspectives on computing as a discipline. Corequisite(s): CS 108L .

title: Introduction to Computing Lab
description: Corequisite(s): CS 108 . Lab fee: $120.

title: Introduction to Data Structures
description: A continuation of CS 104 , CS 106 , or CS 108 , using C++ classes to introduce and implement the elementary data structures including lists, stacks, queues and trees. Advanced programming techniques such as indirection, inheritance, and templates are introduced, along with an emphasis on algorithm analysis, efficiency, and good programming style. Prerequisite(s): CS 104 , CS 106 , CS 108 , or permission of the instructor. Corequisite(s): CS 112L .

title: Introduction to Data Structures Lab
description: Corequisite(s): CS 112 . Lab fee: $120.

title: Introductory Computing Seminar
description: This seminar explores a range of current topics in computing, including topics in research and practice. Students intending to major in a computing-related field must take this course three times in their freshman and sophomore years. Prerequisite(s): freshman or sophomore standing.

title: Data Structures and Algorithms
description: A systematic study of algorithms and their application to more advanced data structures, including trees, heaps, hash tables, and graphs. Algorithms and data structures are analyzed in their use of both time and space, and the choice of data structure in problem solving is studied. Techniques for algorithm design are introduced. Theoretical issues, such as optimality, best- and worst-case performance, and limitations of algorithms are studied, as well as implementation issues. Prerequisite(s): CS 112 . Lab fee: $20.

title: Programming Language Concepts
description: Design principles and implementation issues of contemporary programming languages. Topics covered include programming paradigms; the syntax and semantics of programming language constructs, including those that support concurrent, parallel, and distributed processing; translation of high-level languages to machine language; formal languages and the automata that recognize them. Several different languages are introduced and examined to illustrate these topics. Prerequisite(s): CS 112 . Lab fee: $20.

title: Operating Systems and Networking
description: An introduction to the major concepts modern operating systems must address. Topics include operating system structure, processes and threads, inter-process communication and synchronization, scheduling, main and secondary memory management, file systems, networking, client-server systems, distributed systems. Prerequisite(s): CS 112 and either ENGR 220 or ENGR 304 , which may be taken concurrently. Lab fee: $20.

title: Software Engineering
description: A survey of software engineering principles including software project management, system and requirements analysis, the design and implementation of software and information systems, design patterns, software quality assurance and testing, and software maintenance. Prerequisite(s): CS 112 and at least junior standing. Lab fee: $20.

title: Computing Seminar
description: This seminar explores a range of current topics in computing, including topics in research and practice. It is a continuation of CS 195 . Department majors must take this course three times during their junior and senior years. Prerequisite(s): junior or senior standing.

title: Special Topics in Computer Science
description: Select years. Advanced study of selected topics of current interest in computer science. Topics vary by year. Consult the instructor or the department website for the specific topic the current offering. This course may be repeated for credit if the special topics differ. Prerequisite(s): varying; see department website. Lab fee: $20.

title: Logic, Computability, and Complexity
description: Alternate years. An introduction to first-order logic, computability and computational complexity. Topics covered include soundness and completeness of a formal proof system, computability and non-computability, and computational complexity with an emphasis on NP-completeness. Crosslisted as MATH 312 . Prerequisite(s): MATH 255 ; or MATH 251 and MATH 252 . Course fee: $20.

title: Advanced Computer Architecture
description: Select years. Principles of computer design, instruction set design principles, instruction-level parallelism, cache principles, and multiprocessor systems. Lab fee: $10.

title: Embedded Systems and the Internet of Things
description: Alternate years. An introduction to topics in embedded systems and the Internet of Things (IoT) including hardware and software considerations for special-purpose computing applications that interact with the physical world. Hardware topics include microcontrollers, I/O interfacing, sensors, and actuators. Software topics include scheduling and real-time considerations, IoT network protocols, the Web of things, and embedded programming. Additional topics include discussions of related social and ethical issues such as security, privacy, reliability, and the impact of automation. Lectures will be combined with hands-on lab exercises and a final project. Prerequisite(s): CS 112 (may be taken concurrently), and ENGR 204 or ENGR 220 , or permission of the instructor. Lab fee: $155.

title: Advanced Computer Networks
description: Alternate years. This course investigates advanced topics in the field of computer networking. Students will explore the implementation of TCP, IPv6, routing protocols, software-defined networking, and other advanced topics. Issues of justice and a reformed Christian perspective on network access will be explored. Prerequisite(s): CS 232 or permission of the instructor. Lab fee: $10.

title: Web Development
description: Alternate years. An introduction to software development for websites using common platforms and frameworks. In addition to development, topics include common vulnerabilities and means of defending against them, web user interfaces and usability, and practical, legal, and ethical issues associated with building and administering websites. Prerequisite(s): CS 112 . Lab fee: $20.

title: System Administration: Infrastructure
description: Alternate years. This course provides a holistic introduction to the support of organizational information technology computing and networking infrastructure. It covers computer hardware and servers, designing and maintaining networks, virtualization, and performing basic security configuration. Students work with open source and commercial platforms. Students apply these skills through hands-on system implementation labs and team projects. Prerequisite(s): CS 112 . Lab fee: $10.

title: System Administration: Cloud Services
description: Alternate years. This course provides a holistic introduction to the support of organizational information technology cloud computing and services. It covers cloud computing platforms, services, and their use in business information technology administration. Students work with open source and commercial platforms. Students apply these skills through multiple system implementation labs and team projects. Prerequisite(s): CS 112 . Lab fee: $10.

title: Database Management Systems
description: An introduction to the structures necessary to implement a database management system. Topics include data models (including hierarchical, network and relational data models), normal forms for data relations, data description languages, query facilities. An introduction to existing database management systems is given. Prerequisite(s): CS 262 or DATA 202 . Lab fee: $10.

title: Computer Security
description: An introduction to the principles of computing security. Topics include encryption, protocols, security models, trusted systems, program security, network security, and legal and ethical issues. Prerequisite(s): junior standing, and CS 232 or CS 332 (either may be taken concurrently). Lab fee: $135.

title: Computer Graphics
description: Alternate years. An introduction to interactive 2D and 3D computer graphics techniques including geometric transformations, lighting, shading, texture mapping, and hidden surface removal. Programming projects with graphics libraries such as WebGL and JavaScript. Prerequisite(s): CS 212 or CS 214 . Lab fee: $10.

title: High Performance Computing
description: Alternate years. A study of architectures, algorithms and programming techniques that help minimize the execution times of computer programs that solve particular problems. Topics include high performance computer architectures, parallel programming techniques for distributed and shared-memory multiprocessors, code optimization and hands-on experience using the Calvin University supercomputer. Prerequisite(s): CS 112 and junior standing, or permission of instructor. Lab fee: $10.

title: Artificial Intelligence
description: An introduction to artificial intelligence. Topics include problem solving, knowledge representation, planning, machine learning, natural language processing, and robotics. Students will be introduced to programming techniques from AI such as heuristic search, expert systems, and neural networks, as well as to AI’s philosophical, psychological, and religious context. Prerequisite(s): CS 212 . Lab fee: $10.

title: Machine Learning
description: An introduction to machine learning. Topics include supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning, with applications to image processing and natural language processing. Students will be introduced to ML’s philosophical, psychological, and religious context. Prerequisite(s): CS 212 . Lab fee: $10.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Perspectives on Computing
description: This course addresses social, ethical, legal and professional issues that arise in computer science from a reformed, Christian perspective. Social issues concerning the computerization of society include privacy, security, the digital divide and changes in the way people receive information and relate with others. Ethical discussion starts with a survey of ethical theories and covers professional, ethical and legal issues in areas including intellectual property, privacy, liability and professional codes of conduct. In addition, some foundational issues are covered, including materialist vs. Christian view of what it means to be a person. Prerequisite(s): last year of a computing-related program.

title: Independent Study
description: Independent study of topics of interest to particular students under supervision of a member of the department staff. Open to qualified students with permission of the department chair.

title: Senior Project in Computing
description: This is the first course of a two-semester sequence, in which the student will complete a department-approved computing project. This capstone experience will give students the opportunity to apply concepts and techniques learned in the classroom by developing a significant computing application. The first semester will typically focus on any necessary library research, design and prototyping, implementation and wiring should normally be done in the second semester. The student will submit regular progress reports to a supervising faculty member and submit a preliminary report on the project’s status for evaluation by a departmental committee. Prerequisite(s): senior class standing.

title: Senior Project in Computing II
description: A continuation of CS 396 . The student will submit regular progress reports to a supervising faculty member and submit a final report for evaluation by a departmental committee. Prerequisite(s): CS 396 .

title: Honors Computer Science
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-hour HNRS course, this course will investigate a variety of contemporary topics and challenges within the field of computer science using an interdisciplinary lens. Students will learn foundational computer science concepts and consider social and ethical aspects of computational methods and applications. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 . Course fee: $10.

title: Foundations of Data Science and Analytics
description: An integrated view of the use of desktop applications to access, manage, and analyze data typically found in a corporate environment. This includes spreadsheet and database technologies. Students also investigate the ethical considerations of data availability and analysis along with career options in the fields of information technology and data science. Not open to those who have completed DATA 202 . Lab fee: $10.

title: Exploratory Data Science and Analytics
description: An introduction to data science and analytics, including the management of data from multiple, heterogeneous sources typically found in a corporate environment. Students will gain an understanding of how to manage and analyze large volumes of data using data modeling and visualization software tools. Students also investigate the ethical considerations of data availability and analysis along with career options in the fields of data science and analytics. Not open to those who have completed DATA 202 . Prerequisite(s): DATA 102 . Lab fee: $10.

title: Predictive Analytics
description: A conceptual and practical introduction data preparation, visualization, and predictive analytics. Students will use programming to construct generalizable workflows to acquire, filter, transform, and combine data sets from various sources; to construct quantitative summaries and basic visualizations; and to apply a range of modeling tools to label and predict data. Students will also discuss ethical and social considerations of data collection and data-driven systems. Prerequisite(s): CS 104 , CS 106 , or CS 108 . A minimum grade of C in the chosen course is required. Lab fee: $20.

title: Visualizing Data and Models
description: An introduction to principles and applications for visualizing data and models. Students will learn how to design static and interactive visualizations that accurately, effectively, and aesthetically display information about data and models. Visualizations will be created using multiple visualization tools. Prerequisite(s): DATA 202 or STAT 245 (or higher), or permission of the instructor. Lab fee: $10.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Topics in Data Science
description: Advanced study of selected topics in data science. Consult instructor for course information. This course may be repeated for credit provided the topic is different. Prerequisite(s): DATA 202 or permission of the instructor. Some topics may have additional requirements. Course fee: $20.

title: Independent Study
description: Independent study of topics of interest to particular students under supervision of a member of the department staff. Open to qualified students with permission of the department chair.

title: Senior Project in Data Science
description: This is the first course of a two-semester sequence, in which the student will complete a department-approved data science project. This capstone experience will give students the opportunity to apply concepts and techniques learned in the classroom by developing a significant data science analysis. The student will submit regular progress reports to a faculty mentor and submit a preliminary report on the project’s status for evaluation by a departmental committee. Prerequisite(s): senior class standing.

title: Senior Project in Data Science II
description: A continuation of DATA 396 . The student will submit regular progress reports to a faculty mentor and submit a final report for evaluation by a departmental committee. Prerequisite(s): DATA 396 .

title: Elementary Dutch I
description: An introductory course in the comprehension and use of spoken and written Dutch and an exposure to the people and culture of the Netherlands and Flanders, Belgium.

title: Elementary Dutch II
description: A continuation of DUTC 101 .

title: Intermediate Dutch I
description: Further development of skills in speaking, listening, reading, and writing Dutch. Includes systematic grammar review and the introduction to finer points of grammar and idiomatic use of the language. Cultural topics are explored through film and short literary texts. Prerequisite(s): DUTC 102 or permission of the instructor.

title: Intermediate Dutch II
description: A continuation of DUTC 201 . Further development of skills in speaking, listening, reading, and writing Dutch. Ongoing mastery of grammar and idiomatic use of the language. Cultural topics are explored through film and short literary texts. Prerequisite(s): DUTC 201 or permission of the instructor.

title: Introduction to Economics
description: This course investigates how people and firms in market economies make economic decisions. Students will explore the environmental and societal implications of economic growth, unemployment, and inflation. Furthermore, Christian views concerning justice, freedom, stewardship, and the nature of human beings and society are applied to economic analysis and issues.

title: Principles of Microeconomics
description: This course involves a study of the institutions of mixed-market economies, including their role in resource allocation, the determination of prices & outputs, and income distribution. Topics include the role of the government in the economy and environmental impact of economic activity. Prerequisite(s): ECON 191 .

title: Principles of Macroeconomics
description: A study and evaluation of the determination of national income, including analysis of consumer spending and saving patterns, business investment, government spending, taxation, monetary policy, unemployment, and inflation. The course includes an introduction to international trade and finance. Prerequisite(s): ECON 191 .

title: Urban Development Economics
description: Alternate years. An introduction to the forces behind the economic growth and development of urban areas around the world. The class examines how economists measure the quality of life of urban areas and what the likely economic features of city and suburban life will be in the coming decades. Students critique urban economic policies by examining how they affect resilience, sustainability, and prosperity. Students also explore to what extent Christians might affirm or object to the way in which urban economic forces and public policies generate economic growth, affect ecological systems, and distribute goods and services across race, social class, and future generations. Prerequisite(s): ECON 191 , ECON 221 , ECON 222 , or permission of the instructor.

title: Environmental Economics
description: Alternate years. A study of environmental problems in relationship to Christian stewardship, sustainability, economic efficiency, and justice. Topics include balancing economic activity and environmental impact; measurement of the costs and benefits of environmental policies; and design and evaluation of public policies and business practices to address these problems. Prerequisite(s): a grade of C or better in ECON 191 .

title: Economics of Energy and Sustainability
description: A discussion of economics with detailed focus on energy and sustainability issues. Students will explore interactions among economic, social, natural, and technological systems through the lens of sustainability; including global energy resource scarcity and historical patterns of economic growth and how they impact individuals and society through local and global economic systems. Topics include definitions of sustainability, economic systems, and energy markets: energy production and consumption systems, Biblical and ethical perspectives on consumption and production of goods and energy, and efficiency and equity of resource allocation.

title: Regional Economies of the World
description: This course examines the factors contributing to the rise and fall of nations. The course begins with a study of the role of factors such as demography, geography, distribution of income, control of resources, control of inflation, growth policy, political elements, trade patterns, culture, and institutions, focusing on the economies of low- and middle-income countries. This course also discusses the role of institutions (both political and social) in the success and failure of economies. Typically, this course will focus on one of the following regions: East Asia, the Middle East, Sub-Saharan Africa, or Latin America. Prerequisite(s): a grade of C or better in ECON 191 .

title: Health Economics and Health Policy
description: Alternate years. An introduction to economics in the context of a study of health economics and health policy, with detailed focus on the US health care system. The intent of the course is to develop an understanding of economic principles that can be used with other criteria to evaluate the historical and future direction of the US health care system. Topics include efficiency and equity of resource allocation, ethical perspectives on health care access, history and current direction of US and international health care policy, and the development and evolution of insurance, hospital and health care provider markets. This course is recommended for students seeking a professional career in health care management, human resources, medicine, mental health professions, nursing, public health or public policy. Prerequisite(s): a grade of C or better in ECON 191 .

title: Introductory Econometrics
description: This course is an introduction to quantitative analysis. Topics include the nature of quantitative data, simple and multivariate regression, regression with categorical data, and time series. Students will learn to use quantitative analysis to make and evaluate empirical claims in government, business, and nonprofit contexts. Crosslisted as POLS 253 . Prerequisite(s): ECON 191 or POLS 151 . Additionally, DATA 102 is recommended.

title: Intermediate Microeconomics
description: An intermediate-level study of microeconomic theory including applications to managerial decision-making in such areas as market and risk analysis, demand forecasting, production and cost analysis, product pricing, profit planning, and consumer theory. Goals of firms and the use of economic theory in achieving them are examined and evaluated. Calculus concepts used in the course will be taught as part of the course. Prerequisite(s): DATA 102 ; ECON 221 ; and either STAT 143 , STAT 243 , STAT 343 , ECON 243 , POLS 253 , SOC 255 , or PSYC 255 . Additionally, MATH 171 is recommended.

title: Intermediate Macroeconomics
description: An intermediate-level study of macroeconomic theory emphasizing modeling and analysis of general business activity and the implications of changing business conditions for business planning and public policy. Computer lab work is used to understand the implications of economic policy. Prerequisite(s): ECON 222 and DATA 102 .

title: Money and Financial Markets
description: Alternate years. A study of the principles of money, banking, and credit with emphasis on monetary theory and policy and their role in domestic and international economics. Prerequisite(s): ECON 221 and ECON 222 ; and one from STAT 143 , STAT 243 , STAT 343 , POLS 253 , PSYC 255 , or SOC 255 . In addition, DATA 102 and DATA 103 are recommended.

title: Human Resource Economics
description: Alternate years. A study of labor markets and their relationship to the economy as a whole, including labor-force participation, human-capital formation, wage theory, discrimination, unemployment, income distribution, labor unions, and related public policies. Prerequisite(s): ECON 191 , ECON 221 , and ECON 222 . Not offered in 2025-26.

title: World Poverty and Economic Development
description: Alternate years. A study of the characteristics of poor nations in many regions of the world, and of factors that cause and influence economic development within countries. After examining conditions within poor nations, students analyze theories of economic growth and economic development. Problems, possibilities, and policies are analyzed in each of these topic areas. Prerequisite(s): ECON 191 , ECON 221 , and ECON 222 .

title: International Trade and Finance
description: Alternate years. A study of international economic relations, stressing the fundamentals of international trade and international finance theories, the balance of payments, problems of international disequilibrium, trade barriers, and efforts to promote international economic stability and growth. Prerequisite(s): ECON 191 , ECON 221 , and ECON 222 .

title: Government Finance and Public Policy
description: Alternate years. A study of the economic effects of government spending and taxation on resource allocation and on the distribution of income. Students analyze the economic role of government, and current policy issues and the political process regarding taxation and government spending. Prerequisite(s): ECON 191 , ECON 221 , and ECON 222 .

title: Applied Econometrics
description: Alternative years This course builds on applied econometric methods and introduces advanced econometric methods. Emphasis on evaluating the quality of available information, developing theory-directed models, conducting original research, and interpreting and critically evaluating the published work of others. Topics include the classical linear regression model, heteroskedastic and autocorrelated disturbance models, logistical regression models, specification testing, simultaneous-equations and time-series models. Since econometrics is about making and evaluating empirical claims, the course considers the philosophical and theological assumptions the lie behind social research. Crosslisted as POLS 353 . Prerequisite(s): ECON 243 or POLS 253 .

title: Advanced Topics in Economics
description: As needed. This course provides a deeper, more comprehensive understanding of economic thought and/or microeconomic and macroeconomic theories and applications. Topics vary. Prerequisite(s): ECON 325 and ECON 326 , or permission of the instructor.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite(s): permission of the department chair.

title: Honors Economics
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will address economic structures within the context of social systems. Students will be introduced to observational research methods and develop analytical skills for engaging human behavior and institutions as shaped by market forces and economic factors. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Enhanced Written Rhetoric I
description: The first part of a year-long enhanced course sequence in written rhetoric. See the complete sequence description under ENGL 102 . Enrollment in English 100/ENGL 102 is by special arrangement with the English Department and the Center for Student Success.

title: Written Rhetoric
description: A course in which students write several academic essays in which they practice rhetorical strategies, research-based argumentation, and methods of composing effective prose. In the process of writing these essays, students consider language as a means of discovering truth about God, the world, and themselves, and they explore its potential to communicate truth and, thereby, to transform culture.

title: Enhanced Written Rhetoric II
description: The second part of a year-long, enhanced course sequence in Written Rhetoric. Students enrolled in ENGL 100 /ENGL 102 write expository essays, focusing particularly on how to conduct academic research, producing research-based argumentation. In the process of writing these essays and mastering conventions of language, students consider language as a means of discovering truth about God, the world, and themselves; and they explore its potential to communicate truth and, thereby, to transform culture. Prerequisite(s): ENGL 100 .

title: Writing Studio
description: Writing Studio offers students extra support in academic writing in a small group tutoring context. The focus of instruction is the students’ own writing from other courses. Instructors and tutors help students understand writing assignments—reflect upon specific guidelines, goals, and contexts—and provide support through the drafting, revision, and editing phases. Course may be repeated up to three times for elective credit; graded credit/no credit. Prerequisite(s): permission of the rhetoric director.

title: Introduction to Global Literature
description: An overview of literatures from around the world. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a time period or specific region.

title: Special Topics
description: An introductory examination of literary topics chosen by the instructor.

title: Introduction to Early British Literature
description: An introductory examination of British literature from the medieval period through 1660. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a specific time period within this broader range.

title: Introduction to Later British Literature
description: An introductory examination of British literature from 1660 to the present. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a specific time period within this broader range.

title: Introduction to American Literature
description: An introductory examination of American literature. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a specific time period within this broader range.

title: Introduction to Genre
description: An introductory examination of literary genre. The course may focus on the characteristics of a single genre, such as poetry, novel, plays, etc., or of multiple genres.

title: Major Text
description: As needed. An intensive reading of a single literary text in its historical, literary, and critical contexts.

title: Introduction to Journalism
description: An introduction to reporting for news media, using Associated Press guidelines, to write for digital and print publications. This course focuses on methods of news gathering, interviewing, and research with particular emphasis on reporting about current affairs. Students analyze trends and discuss ethical issues in contemporary journalism across a variety of platforms, but their primary focus is on the writing and editing of news.

title: Business Writing
description: A course introducing students to the kinds of writing, presentations, and social media options used in business-related fields. Students practice composing the types of professional communication that they are likely to craft on the job. The class is conducted as a workshop; students consult with each other and with the instructor. Each student submits several projects. The class also includes a group report (with written, multimedia, and oral portions), in-class writing, and the use of presentation software. Prerequisite(s): ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Literature of Faith
description: As needed. A course examining the foundations of Christianity through its literary dimensions. Building on Foundations of Christianity I, the course uses literature to help students understand more deeply the nature of God, humanity, and the world. Prerequisite(s): Foundations of Christianity I.

title: The Craft of Writing
description: An introductory creative writing course. Students write in a variety of genres, including poetry, fiction, and nonfiction. Students read and analyze models for each genre, engage in peer review, and practice revision strategies to create a portfolio of finished work. Students explore a Christian perspective on literary art and the writing life. This course prepares for more advanced work in creative writing. Prerequisite(s): ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Introduction to Linguistics
description: A study of some of the more interesting and important characteristics of language, with particular attention given to the processes of language acquisition; to patterns and effects of linguistic change through time; to variations in language from region to region, social class to social class, and gender to gender; and to the assumptions informing the study of various grammars.

title: English Syntax
description: A course that reviews the fundamentals of English grammar and examines the possibilities and limitations of teaching grammar in the ESL classroom. Students must research or practice the teaching of some of this grammatical material. Prerequisite(s): ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Ways of Reading
description: An intermediate course that introduces students to theoretical and theological approaches to reading, examining the assumptions and questions that people use to understand a written text. Special attention is paid to ways in which Christians have read both their own foundational text (the Bible) and also secular literature.

title: Advanced Studies in Global Literature
description: A focused study of literature that crosses borders. This course may forefront writing from a discrete nation or examine texts belonging to a global, cosmopolitan movement, such as postcolonialism.

title: Advanced Special Topics
description: A focused study of a literary topic chosen by the instructor.

title: Advanced Studies in Early British Literature
description: A focused study of British literatures from the medieval period to the Restoration. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a specific time period within this broader range.

title: Advanced Studies in Later British Literature
description: A focused study of British literatures from the Restoration to the present. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a specific time period within this broader range.

title: Advanced Studies in American Literature
description: A focused study of American literature. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a specific time period within this broader range.

title: Advanced Studies in Children's and Adolescent Literature
description: A focused study of children’s and adolescent literature. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a time period or specific region.

title: Advanced Studies in Genre
description: A focused, advanced study of a medium or literary genre. The course may focus on the characteristics of a single genre, such as poetry, novel, plays, etc, or of multiple genres.

title: Advanced Studies in a Major Author
description: A focused study of a major literary figure.

title: Academic and Professional Writing
description: A course in rhetoric and composition designed for students who wish to prepare for writing in their professions or in graduate school. Students enhance their abilities to create and edit effective writing in the genres that they will encounter as professionals.

title: Feature Journalism
description: A course in the art of writing feature stories for digital publications, newspapers, and magazines. Students research, write, and edit several substantial articles for different audiences, paying particular attention to matters of strategy and style as called for by those audiences. Topics range from profiles of people to articles about science, history, religion, art, or politics. Although the primary focus of the course is writing, students do explore the possibilities of multimedia journalism.

title: Writing in Digital Environments
description: A course that engages students in writing rhetorically effective digital texts. Students will apply rhetorical, aesthetic, and technical principles as they write extensively in a variety of genres such as social platforms, chat apps, short-form video, and niche newsletters. Special attention will be paid to questions of authorship and copyright when writing in digital environments. Prerequisite(s): ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Special Topics in Advanced Professional Writing
description: A focused study of professional writing in a particular subgenre or topic area.

title: Teaching of Writing
description: A course in the theory and practice of teaching composition in middle and high school writing and language arts programs. Extensive reading complements frequent writing about and practice in all elements involved in teaching writing. Majors and minors in English secondary education programs must take this course before enrolling in EDUC 346 .

title: Creative Writing: Nonfiction
description: A course in the principles and practice of creative nonfiction. Students will examine a variety of models and engage in extensive practice of the genre. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer. Prerequisite(s): ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Creative Writing: Poetry
description: A course in the principles and composition of poetry. Students will engage in extensive practice. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer. Prerequisite(s): Prerequisite: ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Creative Writing: Fiction
description: A course in the principles and composition of fiction. Students will engage in extensive practice. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer.

title: Special Topics in Creative Writing
description: A focused study of creative writing in a particular subgenre or topic area. Prerequisite(s): ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Creative Writing Intensive
description: An intensive writing course, typically led by Calvin’s writer-in-residence. Students will engage in extensive practice. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer. Students can repeat the course up to four times. Prerequisite(s): ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Writing for Children and Young Adults
description: A course in the principles and composition of writing for children and young adults. Students will engage in extensive practice. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer. Prerequisite(s): ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: History of the English Language
description: An analysis of the changes that have occurred throughout the history of the English language, based on an intensive study of selected British and American texts.

title: Sociolinguistics and Issues in Language Education
description: A course involving two major activities: (1) an examination of selected topics that have arisen in recent sociolinguistic research, particularly those topics centering on questions about how standard and nonstandard languages and dialects appear to affect people’s educational success; and (2) an evaluation of how these topics should affect approaches to language education, particularly approaches to teaching English as a Second Language (ESL). Prerequisite(s): ENGL 101 or ENGL 102 .

title: Stylistics and Discourse Analysis
description: A course that reviews significant grammatical terms; analyzes how words can be combined into longer constructions in English; examines the kinds of meanings–such as agency, modality, and solidarity–that those constructions can convey; and discusses how patterns of clauses conveying these various kinds of meaning within texts can be related to textual contexts.

title: Special Topics in Linguistics
description: As needed. A focused study of linguistics in a particular field or topic.

title: Internship
description: A course requiring students to work ten hours per week in a job related to English studies. This practicum asks students to reflect on vocation broadly and to apply theoretical, technical, and ethical principles to their work. Students will work with the Career Center to secure a suitable position. Prerequisite(s): junior or senior status, a 2.0 university and departmental GPA, and permission of the advisor.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite(s): permission of the department chair.

title: Senior Seminar
description: An advanced special topics course in which students approach a contemporary challenge or enduring question, selected by the instructor, through language and literacy studies and other disciplines. The course fulfills a requirement in the English major but is open and accessible to students in all majors. Prerequisite(s): CORE 100 , Foundations of Christianity I, and permission of the department chair.

title: Honors Creative Writing
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will emphasize creative writing (whether nonfiction, fiction, or poetry) as a form of problem-solving, embedded within larger social contexts. Particular attention will be paid to genre conventions and audience expectations. The interdisciplinary component will attend to how writing not only expresses ideas but gives shape to them along the way. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Honors Literature
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will engage questions about the meaning of human life and experience in dialogue with literary texts and traditions. While readings will vary from year to year, in all iterations students will hone skills of close textual analysis, cultural and ideological discernment, and expository writing. Genre conventions and social context will be primary concerns. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Introduction to Education
description: This course invites students to explore the discipline of education and the teaching profession. Students will experience various types of schools and other educational settings through visits, interviews, and virtual connections with elementary and secondary students and staff locally and around the world. Students will reflect on these experiences in writing, group discussions, chats, video, and other platforms. The course provides the initial framework for subsequent education courses and clinical experiences, introducing students to primary issues and components of schools as well as engaging them in Christian practices for teaching in various settings.

title: Literacy Instruction for Beginning Readers
description: This initial course in the three-course literacy sequence focuses on understanding current research underlying key concepts such as phonics, phonological awareness, concepts of print, and reading fluency. These basic concepts are learned within the overarching context of all literacy instruction being focused on thinking, understanding and engagement. Teacher candidates deepen their understanding of these concepts through a 20-hour practicum with primary grade students in a linguistically diverse school. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 ; and EDUC 241 (may be taken concurrently).

title: Music and Art in the Elementary Classroom
description: This is a required course for the elementary teacher candidate. It covers seven weeks of music education methods and seven weeks of visual arts methods. Integration of music and art with other subject areas will be stressed. Students will explore the creative process through vocal and instrumental music, visual arts production, and lesson planning. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 (may be taken concurrently).

title: Vocabulary, Writing, and Comprehension Instruction
description: Candidates learn how to design and enact a range of instructional strategies and routines to support students in becoming skillful and engaged readers across subject areas. Candidates also learn the principles and strategies for effective vocabulary instruction and how to assess writing. This course includes a 20-hour practicum where candidates create lessons and assessments for the teaching of reading comprehension and writing. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 ; and EDUC 241 (may be taken concurrently).

title: Foundations of Early Childhood Education
description: Even years. This course addresses theories of child development and applications within the natural or preschool learning environments. Students will explore foundations of early childhood education practices, including observational research techniques, classroom or natural environment observation of children from birth through kindergarten, and writing developmental assessment reports. Twenty hours of field experience outside of the classroom are required. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 (may be taken concurrently).

title: Developmentally Appropriate Practice with Young Children
description: Work with young children requires specialized knowledge of the field of early childhood education. This course will equip students with knowledge and skills for developmentally appropriate practice for young children, including culturally responsive perspectives and pedagogical strategies addressing the importance of play in learning, social-emotional development, early literacy, and early mathematics. Ten hours of observation in a preschool setting will be required. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 (may be taken concurrently).

title: The Social Context of Education
description: This course guides students in an examination of the social context of schooling, including the interaction and impact of social structures and systems on the educational experiences of individuals and groups. Particular attention is given to the study of race, class, and gender and how social science helps us understand their impact on schools, society, and learners. A biblically-guided understanding of justice helps shape this critical analysis. This course includes a 12-hour project involving field work and centered on schools, communities, and families.

title: Inclusive Teaching: Ability, Language, and Multicultural Education
description: This course provides insight into learners with diverse ability and linguistic background. It includes study of the role of culture in language development and academic achievement; second language development theories for classroom organization and pedagogy; characteristics of students with identified disability; and the history of special education, individualized planning, and pedagogy. A Christian view of persons is developed to counteract deficit thinking, recognize the gifts of all students, and identify human and linguistic difference as asset. Twelve hours will be spent outside of class in observation of K-12 school programs. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 or permission of the instructor. Course fee: $215.

title: Teaching and Learning Lab
description: Students will actively explore the core knowledge, practices and dispositions of teaching and learning through examination of model teaching, enactment of practice teaching in small groups, and reflective discussion. The course will focus on what it means to live out Christian faith commitments and practices in a variety of settings. This includes consideration of who teaches and is taught, what is taught, how and in what context we teach, and the complex ways in which these ideas interact and compete in PK-12 classrooms. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 , EDUC 240 , and EDUC 241 , or permission of the instructor.

title: The Christian Teacher
description: This course will examine multiple frameworks for understanding how Christian commitments can inform teacher identity and formation and guide professional practice. The course will include attention to how the Bible, with its diversity of genres, functions as an educational text, as well as to exemplars of Christian engagement with education and key facets of teacher and student vocation. A range of faith-informed practices will be examined as they apply to professional practice in educational settings. Prerequisite(s): a Foundations of Christianity I Core course.

title: Social Studies Inquiry
description: Students consider how to teach the social studies through inquiry, with a special emphasis on children Pre-K through grade 6. Knowledge development will focus primarily on the geographic, sociocultural, global, and political threads of the social studies. The inquiry process will be modeled with an exploration of a global region. Participants will develop their skills in core teaching practices. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 243 (may be taken concurrently) and any 200-level history class taken for Humanities Core.

title: Curriculum, Instruction, and Content Area Literacy
description: Students will develop an increased understanding of the complex issues surrounding learning theory and its impact on instruction in diverse educational contexts. Students will explore how an understanding of the learner, the curriculum, and the context shape instructional practice. They will learn how to engage in a pedagogical cycle that includes planning, implementation, evaluation, and reflection with a focus on meeting the needs of all learners. Students will also examine the nature and function of literacy in the secondary content curriculum. Specifically, this course will examine the reading and writing skills and practices that support the ways of knowing and doing characteristic of secondary school subject areas. All of these areas will be examined through the lens of a reformed Christian perspective. An extensive practicum will assist students in linking theory and practice in a classroom setting. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 , EDUC 240 , EDUC 241 , and EDUC 243 . Corequisite(s): EDUC 308 .

title: Internship I
description: This internship provides field-based learning through a part-time placement in a grade 5-12 classroom. With the supervision of a faculty member and a master teacher, interns develop their understanding and performance of the knowledge, skills and dispositions expected of 5th- to 12th-grade educators. Individual observations, mentoring, and coursework aide interns in developing as professionals. Varied frameworks and tools are used throughout the internship to assess readiness for the professional field. A grade of C or higher along with the recommendation of the course instructor are required to continue in the education program. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 , EDUC 240 , EDUC 241 , and EDUC 243 . Corequisite(s): EDUC 307 .

title: Teaching Religion to Children and Adolescents
description: A study of perspectives, content, methods, and materials in teaching religion to children and adolescents. This includes pedagogy appropriate for public and non-public schools and evaluation of methods and materials.

title: Assessment in Early Childhood and Special Education
description: A study of the foundational concepts and basic terminology needed for administering developmentally appropriate assessment. Skill will be developed in thoughtfully creating, selecting, administering, and interpreting formal and informal assessments. Norm-referenced, criterion-referenced, curriculum-based, and play-based assessment will be addressed for the purpose of developing Individualized Education Programs (IEPs), Individualized Family Service Programs (IFSPs), and Section 504 plans. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 241 and EDUC 243 , or permission of the instructor. Corequisite(s): EDUC 330 or EDUC 343 .

title: Extending and Deepening Literacy Instruction: Internship I
description: Candidates learn how to teach engaging literacy lessons and design instructional strategies that support students in becoming skillful and engaged readers and writers across subject areas. Candidates further develop their understanding of creating equitable classroom cultures; their capacity to design literacy programs that reflect their knowledge of curriculum, assessment, and instruction; and their knowledge, skill, and commitment to equitable and justice-oriented practices. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 , EDUC 115 , EDUC 215 ,​ EDUC 240 , EDUC 241 , and EDUC 243 . Corequisite(s): EDUC 350 , MATH 324 , and SCES 310 .

title: Curriculum and Instruction: Cognitive Impairment
description: A study of the various curricula, instructional materials, and teaching methods appropriate for learners who have cognitive impairment. Research-based general principles of instruction are reviewed as well as specific methods for teaching daily living, communication, employment, community living, recreation/leisure, faith formation, and functional academic skills. Strategies are learned for generating curriculum, evaluating published curricula, and developing individualized education programs. Includes a practicum of two half-days per week in local school programs serving students with cognitive impairment. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 241 and EDUC 243 , or permission of the instructor. Corequisite(s): EDUC 310 .

title: Introduction to Cognitive Impairment: Birth through School Age
description: A comprehensive study of the characteristics of infants and children who have cognitive impairment, intellectual or developmental disability, or developmental delay. Common causes, medical and school-based definitional issues, assessment, eligibility for special education, and interventions will be discussed. While special attention is given to supports for children with cognitive impairment as learners, the course examines functioning across a variety of settings besides the school, such as the church, home, and neighborhood. A Christian view of persons, community, and discipleship, along with the concepts of inclusion, social role valorization, and self-determination are integrating elements in the course. Seven hours of observation in a local school or early childhood program is required for this course. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 , EDUC 241 , or permission of the instructor.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Impairment: Transition to Adulthood
description: A comprehensive study of the characteristics of persons who have intellectual disability. Historical and contemporary perspectives on intellectual disability will be explored, as will common causes, definitional issues, and interventions. The course examines the transition to adulthood in a variety of settings besides the school, such as the church, workplace, and neighborhood. A Christian view of persons, community, and discipleship, along with the concepts of normalization, social role valorization, and self-determination are integrating elements in the course. Seven hours of observation in a transition or adult services program is required for this course. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 and EDUC 241 , or permission of the instructor.

title: Infant, Toddler, and Preschool Curriculum
description: Odd years. This course provides an exploration of the major approaches to development of a curriculum for infants, toddlers, and preschool-age children (birth to age six), the underlying assumptions of each approach, and the appropriateness of each approach for children. Special attention is given to supporting the development of early literacy and numeracy. This course includes a 6-hour per week field placement during the PK-12 school day. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 115 , EDUC 236 , EDUC 238 , EDUC 243 , MATH 221 , and SCES 110 , or permission of the instructor.

title: Family Engagement, Relationships, and Collaboration
description: Odd years. This course examines the knowledge and skills required to become a collaborative educator who identifies as a Christian early childhood professional, can administer programs, understands and works alongside children and families from diverse backgrounds, can recognize and report child abuse and neglect, is a strong advocate for children and families, and is a reflective practitioner committed to life-long learning. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 236 and EDUC 238 , or permission of the instructor.

title: Early Childhood Education: Preschool Field Experience
description: A field experience in a preschool setting that meets state requirements. Provides for analysis of teaching methods, materials, and classroom organization as they relate to the early childhood setting. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 236 , EDUC 238 , EDUC 337 , EDUC 339 , and PSYC 270 . Corequisite(s): EDUC 310 .

title: Internship II: Student Teaching
description: This internship provides field-based learning through a full-time placement in a grade K-12 classroom. With the supervision of faculty members and master teachers, candidates refine their understanding and performance of the knowledge, skills and dispositions expected of educators. Individual observations, mentoring, and coursework aid candidates in developing as professionals. Varied frameworks and tools are used throughout the internship to assess readiness for the professional field. Prerequisite(s): an overall GPA of 2.5, Internship I (EDUC 308 ; or EDUC 330 ; or EDUC 315 , EDUC 350 , MATH 324 , and SCES 310 ), and recommendation of the Internship I supervisors. Corequisite(s): EDUC 359 .

title: Directed Teaching: Cognitive Impairment
description: Full-time, supervised student teaching in a school program serving students with cognitive impairment. A minimum of ten weeks, including at least 360 clock hours of observation and participation, is required. Includes a biweekly seminar, which engages students in critical reflection on their experience in applying theory to practice in the student teaching context. Prerequisite(s): Completion of all special education major courses and the recommendation of the EDUC 330 supervisor.

title: Teaching Social Studies in Elementary Grades: Internship I
description: Students consider social studies content and pedagogy for children from Pre-K through grade 6. Knowledge development will focus primarily on the political and economic threads of the social studies. The inquiry process and other social studies instructional strategies will be developed with an emphasis on finding quality sources (including children’s and adolescent literature) for children’s exploration of social studies content and issues in the social studies. Through classroom peer teaching and a practicum, participants further develop and demonstrate core teaching practices in their practicum settings. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 , EDUC 240 , EDUC 241 , EDUC 243 , and EDUC 250 . Corequisite(s): EDUC 315 , MATH 324 , and SCES 310 .

title: Student Teaching Seminar
description: Taking an interdisciplinary perspective, students will consider the question, “What contributes to flourishing in learning communities?,” particularly when faced with a contemporary challenge. Pulling from experiences in their full-time internship in a P-12 classroom, previous program coursework, research, and personal inquiries, students will select a challenge that transpires in their assigned placement. They will consider how self, context and the core aspects of teaching (pedagogy, curriculum, assessment, and classroom management) along with a Reformed Christian worldview inform their response and engage practice in ways that foster greater flourishing for all. Prerequisite(s): an overall GPA of 2.5, Internship I (EDUC 308 ; or EDUC 330 ; or EDUC 315 , EDUC 350 , MATH 324 , and SCES 310 ), and recommendation of the Internship I supervisors. Corequisite(s): EDUC 346 .

title: Internship in Education
description: Students work in a position related to schooling and/or the support of individuals who have identified disabilities. Taken as part of an education major or special education studies minor, the internship will provide students an opportunity to consolidate their study of teaching, learning, and support for children and families. Students will work with the School of Education faculty and/or the Career Center to secure a suitable position. Prerequisite(s): a 2.0 university and departmental GPA, and permission of the advisor and of the on-site advisor.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite(s): permission of the department chair.

title: Philosophy of Education
description: Students examine education in its context as a life practice. It involves inquiry into and critique of the philosophical assumptions, historical developments, and social settings that shape the beliefs and practices informing schools as social institutions and education as a cultural practice. Throughout the course, students are developing their own faith-based philosophy of education. Prerequisite(s): junior or senior standing, EDUC 240 , and Internship I (EDUC 308 ; or EDUC 315 , EDUC 350 , MATH 324 , and SCES 310 ).

title: Curriculum, Instruction, and Content Area Literacy
description: Students will examine the nature and function of literacy in the secondary content curriculum. Specifically, this course will examine the reading and writing skills and practices that support the ways of knowing and doing characteristic of secondary school subject areas. All of these areas will be examined through the lens of a reformed Christian perspective. An extensive practicum (EDUC 508 ) will assist students in linking theory and practice in a classroom setting. Students will complete a project tailored to their disciplinary interests. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 , EDUC 240 , and EDUC 243 . Corequisite(s): EDUC 508 .

title: Internship I
description: This internship provides field-based learning through a part-time placement in a grade 6-12 classroom. With the supervision of a faculty member and a master teacher, interns develop their understanding and performance of the knowledge, skills, and dispositions expected of 6th- to 12th-grade educators. Individual observations, mentoring, and coursework aide interns in developing as professionals. Varied frameworks and tools are used throughout the internship to assess readiness for the professional field. Students will complete a project tailored to their disciplinary interests. Prerequisite(s): EDUC 103 , EDUC 240 , and EDUC 243 . Corequisite(s): EDUC 507 .

title: Framing Questions, Global Forces, Constraining Structures
description: This course will center on fundamental questions at the intersection of education, justice, and human flourishing. We will examine key issues surrounding the nature of a good society, the ways in which the global community affects education, and how schooling gets structured by politics and economics. This course will use the faith-based frames of justice and hope in connection with shalom and the kingdom of God to investigate formal education in light of its political, economic, social, and religious contexts. Students will investigate foundational questions around teaching, learning, curriculum, and language as well as structural issues of social class, gender, ability, and race. The aim is for students to articulate their own idea of the purpose of school framed in their own faith-based perspective. The course will leave space for students to explore specific interests and issues.

title: Educational Research and Evaluation
description: This course engages students in understanding and examining the theories, methods, and paradigmatic frames of educational research through a biblical lens. In addition, the course prepares students to use data appropriately to support educational and organizational decision-making. Students will learn how to read and critique qualitative and quantitative educational research and will learn how to use research and assessment data to make decisions related to the work of P-12 schools.

title: Leading Educational Communities: Communication
description: Because communication is at the heart of teaching, learning and leading, the Graduate Studies Program prepares professional educators to understand and analyze discourse as it shapes educational activity. Teaching and learning communications are shaped and made meaningful by culture, language, mode and circumstance; as well as ideology and power. Abilities to analyze communication as discursive, prepares participants to examine educational activity settings, assess them for equitable participation and design them for more effective and just educational practice.

title: Reshaping Curriculum, Teaching, and Learning
description: The dynamic relationship between curriculum as content and as process, between what is to be learned and the instructional practices used to organize and mediate it for students, is at the heart of educational practice. This course focuses on the theory and practice of curriculum and pedagogy, examined in terms of both the perspectives that shape them and the ways in which they serve or fail to serve all learners. Issues addressed include the concept, purpose, and social context of curriculum; the historical perspectives that influence current and future directions; the relationship between curriculum and instruction; and the connection between perspectival commitments, curriculum, and instruction. The course will also address issues and practices related to assessment and instructional technology. Readings, discussions, interaction with practitioners, investigation, and application will form important activities in the development of an understanding of and personal perspective on curriculum and instruction.

title: Introduction to School Leadership
description: Alternate years. A study of leadership theory and practice relating to building school communities that promote learning for all students. This introductory course in school leadership will focus on: organizational and leadership theory, establishing a school mission, collaborative problem-solving and community building, decision-making skills and procedures, and personal leadership qualities. Special emphasis will be given to exploring biblical principles which guide Christian leaders in school settings.

title: Professional Development and Supervision
description: Alternate years. A study of the theory and practice related to the professional development of teachers and administrators at both the elementary and secondary levels. This course focuses on ways in which school leaders can structure professional development opportunities that promote student learning and school improvement. The course includes a study of adult learning theory, collaborative learning models, mentoring and coaching, formal and informal teacher assessment, and recruitment, induction, and retention of new teachers. Special emphasis will be given to biblical principles which help shape professional communities in schools.

title: School Business Management
description: Alternate years. In this course students will study principles and methods of planning and fiscal management that are based on a biblical model of stewardship.
