Common themes of developing a Christian philosophy, understanding the history of a discipline, the nature of inquiry and understanding, and human-environment relationships provide structure to the course. Students are grouped by majors in breakout sessions where discussion reaches deeper into disciplinary knowledge. Students will lead sessions for the whole class on interesting issues, problems or controversies within their discipline. The course format encourages each student to think deeply about their own discipline and build mutual communication with students in related disciplines. Prerequisite(s): senior standing in a major in geology, geography, environmental studies or environmental science; or permission of the instructor.

title: Honors Geography
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will address dynamics of human communities as they interact with natural environments. Students will be introduced to observational research methods and develop analytical skills for engaging geographical regions through integrated place studies and landscape interpretation. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Geographic Information Systems and Cartography
description: 1. This course provides an introduction to geographic information systems (GIS) and the art and science of cartography—or, as the field is increasingly termed, geographic visualization. It introduces concepts of spatial analysis (what is spatial analysis, what are methods of spatial analysis, and how does one practically conduct spatial analysis) and the elements of graphic design, particularly as applied to thematic mapping and analytical cartography with qualitative and quantitative data types. Concepts in lecture and laboratory utilize the state-of-the-art ArcGIS suite of software throughout the semester, and students will learn how to use this software for analysis and cartographic production. Also, students will learn how to communicate with a map considering the audience and the social context, various techniques of graphic design and written communication, and the map as a metaphor for reality. Finally, students learn how to “listen” to a map through a series of exercises on how to evaluate and understand maps.

title: Advanced Geographic Information Systems
description: This course introduces advanced themes in geographic information systems (GIS), including spatial database design, spatial algorithms, and implementation and design. Advanced GIS applications include designs for community development and service tailored to individual students’ major field of study. Prerequisite(s): GEO 560 , with a grade of C or better.

title: Remote Sensing of Earth
description: This course provides an introduction to remote sensing of Earth. During the semester students engage in the physics and technique aspects of photogrammetry and satellite imagery, along with application of drone technology, for the study of physical and human created landscapes on Earth. This course includes a laboratory component during the normal course hours and drone homework as integral learning methods. Topics covered in this course range from aerial photography to analysis of 3D models of terrain. Multiple themes of application will be discussed. Crosslisted as GEO 362 .

title: Spatial Demographics
description: This course provides an introduction to demography and geographical analysis. Specific attention is given to the study of social, economic, and health statistics as they change over time and space, which illustrate the changing structure of human populations. Readings in demographic research and a GIS-based semester project will comprise the second half of the course. Prerequisite(s): GEO 560 .

title: Applied Spatial Statistics
description: The availability of geospatial data has increased substantially over the last several decades. It is critical that GIS practitioners understand the tools used for manipulating, visualizing, and analyzing geospatial data. This course provides students with introductions to applied spatial data analysis and statistical problem solving in geography. Coursework will emphasize statistical approaches, spatial pattern and attribute analyses, and data visualization techniques. Through laboratory exercises and projects, students will gain experience with applied spatial analyses by evaluating real-world datasets. This course also introduces students to open source GIS using program R.

title: Business Location Intelligence
description: This course explores the exciting world of business spatial analytics and location-based services. Topics include gravity modeling, suitability analysis for potential market location, social and economic population analysis, and business and facilities saturation. Students will complete a GIS-based project for a local nonprofit business during the semester as a service-learning project. GEO 230 - The Global Economy and Transforming Regions is not required but is recommended. Prerequisite(s): GEO 560 .

title: Geospatial Programming and Data Management
description: This course provides students with foundational knowledge in Python and Map Objects programming for GIS. Students will learn the Python programming language. Emphasis will be in ESRI model builder, scripting for ArcToolBox, and custom design workflows using Map Objects. Geospatial data management best practices, ArcGIS Server, and geodatabase design will be explored. Students will construct a custom GIS solution for a public or private business. No previous programming experience is necessary but is recommended. Prerequisite(s): GEO 560 .

title: Special Topics in GIS
description: This course explores various special topics in GIS. Topics could include urban and regional GIS, geospatial homeland security, web mapping, smartphone map app development, natural resource GIS management, or other. Prerequisite(s): GEO 560 .

title: Earth Systems
description: This course is an introductory study of physical systems and processes that shape the surface of Earth. Topics include: 1) the physical nature of Earth’s surface based on materials (rocks and minerals), plate tectonics, and the processes that create landforms; 2) the roles and movements of water in the atmosphere, oceans, surface water, and groundwater; and 3) weather components, storms, and climate systems. Understanding of Earth systems is applied to concepts of stewardship and human interactions with Earth’s environments. Not open to students who have completed GEO 151 or GEO 153 . Corequisite(s): GEO 120L .

title: Earth Systems Lab
description: Students learn from an array of hands-on activities that span Earth systems topics and geoscience professions. Topics include mineral and rock identification, topographic maps, water resources, natural hazards such as earthquakes, Earth-sun relationships, temperature patterns, local weather, and climate patterns. Corequisite(s): GEO 120 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Year Research in Earth Sciences: Dunes
description: First-semester Calvin students are immersed in undergraduate research experiences focused on Lake Michigan coastal dunes. Classes cover topics ranging from the contemporary understanding of Great Lakes coastal dune forms and processes to human interactions with coastal dunes to the practices of science. After students have a foundation of knowledge about dunes and science, teams of students investigate contemporary research questions about Michigan dunes. Student research activities are supported by upper-level student research mentors. Corequisite(s): GEO 181L .

title: FYRES Lab
description: This laboratory course engages students in hands-on dune research experiences, with many activities taking place at Lake Michigan dune sites. Student activities are supported by upper-level student research mentors. Directed experiences at dune sites early in the semester give students experience in dune environments, dune research methods, data analysis, and the process of scientific inquiry. Then teams of students implement investigations focused on Michigan dunes, including designing their study, collecting field data, analyzing the results, and drawing conclusions. Each team communicates their study results in a conference-style research poster and oral presentation at the end of the semester. Corequisite(s): GEO 181 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Oceanography
description: This survey course includes: the history of marine exploration, the nature of the ocean floor, including submarine volcanoes, oceanic crust, sea-floor spreading, and marine sediments, coastal geomorphic processes, the properties of seawater, the nature of tides and currents, ecological marine biogeography, including marine plankton, deep-water biota, coral reef communities, estuarine and intertidal marine communities, and stewardship of marine resources. Prerequisite(s): high school chemistry. Corequisite(s): GEO 251L .

title: Oceanography Lab
description: An introductory oceanography lab course that covers the interpretation and use of seafloor maps, analysis of plate tectonics process and how they contribute to seafloor formation, features, and processes; observations, measurements, and interpretation of seawater and atmospheric data; the recognition and interpretation of climate variability and El Nino; the classification of marine organisms by taxonomy, ecological niche, and feeding. This course has required field trips. Prerequisite(s): high school chemistry. Corequisite(s): GEO 251 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Geomorphology
description: Geomorphology is the study of landforms, including their nature, processes and history. This course examines the processes and landforms produced by the action of water (streams, coasts), wind, gravity (mass movements), ice, weathering, and crustal processes. For different environments, students will learn to recognize landforms, understand landform evolution, and identify the influences of relevant variables. A semester-long research project provides hands-on experience with geomorphic investigation, interpretation, and communication. Prerequisite(s): GEO 120 , GEO 151 , or GEO 153 . Corequisite(s): GEO 252L .

title: Geomorphology Lab
description: Students learn from hands-on activities that span a variety of geomorphology topics and methods, including field studies; lab investigations; map and aerial photograph interpretation; data collection, analysis, and interpretation. Students will develop technical skills and apply geomorphic understanding to solving real-world problems. Prerequisite(s): GEO 120 , GEO 151 , or GEO 153 . Corequisite(s): GEO 252 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Field Study
description: This course offers a field-based, regionally specific study of a designated topic in environmental studies, geology, human geography, or physical geography. The course is repeatable for different areas of field study. Course fee: varies with study location.

title: Coastal Geomorphology
description: Odd years. This course examines the nature and development of coastal landforms and the processes responsible for changes in the coastal zone. Topics include waves, currents, tides, wind, changing sea levels, and the coastal environments of beaches, dunes, estuaries, and rocky coasts. Coastal land use and hazards, shoreline protection, and coastal stewardship will be discussed. Great Lakes coasts are emphasized. Prerequisite(s): GEO 252 . Corequisite(s): GEO 323 is recommended.

title: Coastal Geomorphology Methods
description: Odd years. This course gives students hands-on experience with methods for investigating coastal geomorphology. Students will collect field data at coastal sites, analyse collected samples with lab equipment, model coastal processes in lab simulations, work with online datasets, and do computer analysis of data. There will be several field trips outside of class time during the semester. Students must be concurrently enrolled in GEO 322 , because that course provides background knowledge for understanding methods and interpreting results. Prerequisite(s): GEO 252 . Corequisite(s): GEO 322 . Lab fee: $125.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Internship in Geography and Geology
description: This course is for students working in an internship involving professional application of the concepts and principles learned as part of the geography or geology programs. A student is placed in a government agency, a private firm, or a not-for-profit organization to work in an area such as geographic information systems, geologic mapping, subsurface investigations, museum operations, or urban and regional planning. On-campus interns work under the direct supervision of an appropriate Calvin supervisor. Off-campus interns work under the direct supervision of an employee of the outside agency or firm with additional oversight from the department’s designated faculty internship coordinator. Interns must maintain an internship journal and complete a written report summarizing their internship experience. The credit hours vary with the number of hours worked. Prerequisite(s): senior standing or permission of the instructor.

title: Independent Study
description: By arrangement. Independent study (reading and research) of a topic that does not otherwise exist in the catalog, under the supervision of a member of the department. Prerequisite(s): permission of the department.

title: Introduction to Geology
description: This course is a study of the materials and processes of Earth. Topics include minerals and rocks, Earth’s interior and surface structure, surface processes producing landforms, geological time and principles for interpreting Earth history, mineral resources and fossil fuels, and geological hazards such as earthquakes, volcanoes, floods, landslides, and groundwater pollution. Not open to students who have completed GEO 120 or GEO 153 . Corequisite(s): GEO 151L .

title: Introduction to Geology Lab
description: Students will study rocks and minerals, learn the interpretation of topographic and geologic maps, and conduct exercises in the basic procedures of geologic investigations. Corequisite(s): GEO 151 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Historical Geology
description: Historical geology is a discipline that uses the principles and methods of geology to reconstruct the geological history of Earth. This course studies the vastness of geologic time and investigates changes in Earth, gradual and sudden, over this deep time. Preserved evidence of past geologic events and history of life is discussed; this includes interpreting fossil records and rock records to better understand events that took place in the past. Topics include the origin of Earth and its moon, the origin of continents and ocean basins, the creation of mountain ranges through history, the formation of major sedimentary deposits, and Earth’s climate history. Prerequisite(s): GEO 120 , GEO 151 , or GEO 153 . Corequisite(s): GEO 152L .

title: Historical Geology Lab
description: Students use rock and mineral collections to learn to name an array of rocks that represent the crust. Students learn to read and interpret geologic maps from a variety of geologic settings. Students develop technical skills, practice data analysis, and engage in scientific communication. Prerequisite(s): GEO 120 , GEO 151 , or GEO 153 . Corequisite(s): GEO 152 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Great Lakes Geology
description: As needed. This course in geology is based in the Great Lakes region of the United States. Our home-base is the Calvin University campus, with day and overnight field trips to locations with superb field exposures for a variety of geology topics and Earth materials. We plan to visit all five Great Lakes with field trip stops in Michigan (lower and upper peninsulas), Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New York. This course emphasizes outdoor, field-based investigation and learning. Students will be introduced to the breadth of geological study leading to responsible Christian appreciation and stewardship of Earth. Topics include rocks and minerals, landforms and Earth surface processes, weather and climate, natural hazards, and natural resources. As a graded course, quizzes and exams will cover course content. Students will be required to complete assignments, make an identified rock and mineral collection, and document visits to different locations with a field notebook.

title: Structural Geology and Tectonics
description: Even years. This course is a tectonic analysis of common geological structures such as folds, faults, joints, and foliations. The course examines how these structures are formed from stresses within Earth. Students will learn about mapping techniques and how to interpret information from geological maps and cross sections. Understanding tectonic events and locations in Earth history provides a context for interpreting individual geological structures. Prerequisite(s): GEO 120 , GEO 151 , or GEO 153 . Corequisite(s): GEO 212L .

title: Structural Geology and Tectonics Lab
description: Even years. This laboratory provides students with hands-on experience in identifying and analyzing tectonic structures from a variety of evidence, including geological maps, cross-sections, visual information (such as photographs and satellite data), field data, and virtual field excursions. Students will be introduced to mapping techniques, including methods of constructing geological maps and cross sections. Prerequisite(s): GEO 120 , GEO 151 , or GEO 153 . Corequisite(s): GEO 212 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Mineralogy
description: A study of the structure and chemical makeup of Earth materials. The composition, crystal symmetry, and geologic occurrence of minerals are discussed along with mineral structures, chemistry, mineral associations, and mineral genesis. Prerequisite(s): GEO 120 , GEO 151 , or GEO 153 ; and CHEM 101 (may be taken concurrently). Corequisite(s): GEO 215L .

title: Mineralogy Lab
description: Students examine mineral samples in hand sample and thin section. Students also learn to use petrographic microscopes. Labs emphasize crystal morphology and mineral identification. Prerequisite(s): GEO 120 , GEO 151 , or GEO 153 ; and CHEM 101 (may be taken concurrently). Corequisite(s): GEO 215 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Geochemistry
description: Even years. This survey course looks at Earth’s major geochemical systems with particular attention to water and rock systems. We will examine the major topics of cosmochemistry, isotope geochemistry, mineral chemistry, and aqueous geochemistry. We will use these topics to understand the formation of the elements in the solar system, Earth’s geochemical composition and differentiation, the age of rocks, global geochemical cycles, and the surface environment. No laboratory. Prerequisite(s): GEO 215 ; or CHEM 102 and GEO 151 .

title: Special Topics in Environmental Geology
description: As needed. Use of geologic methods and interpretations in understanding and resolving geologic problems relating to the environment. Emphasis will be on the specific environmental topic and may include energy resources, mineral resources, or water resources and the associated environmental issues of site assessment. Topics may also address natural hazards and the environmental impacts. May be repeated with a different focus. Prerequisite(s): GEO 252 .

title: Paleontology
description: Even years. A study of the organisms that once lived on the Earth. Includes an examination of the processes of preservation and methods of discovering the structure, habitat, and relationship of those organisms, and a review of their distribution and life history. A broad spectrum of organisms is studied with emphasis on invertebrate animals. Also listed as BIOL 313 . Prerequisite(s): GEO 152 or BIOL 160 and BIOL 161 . Corequisite(s): GEO 313L .

title: Paleontology Lab
description: Even years. Students learn from close observation, examination, and drawing many fossil specimens over the semester. Labs focus on the characteristics of approximately 20 phyla of macroscopic plants and animals, as well as others that are traditionally classified as “microfossils.” Crosslisted as BIOL 313L . Corequisite(s): BIOL 313 or GEO 313 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
description: Odd years. This course addresses the origin, emplacement, occurrence, and tectonic context of igneous and metamorphic rocks. Mineral and rock compositions and chemistry, textures, classifications, and phase relationships are studied. The principles of optical mineralogy are emphasized. Prerequisite(s): GEO 215 and GEO 215L . Corequisite(s): GEO 316L .

title: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology Lab
description: Odd years. This laboratory provides students with hands-on experience in igneous and metamorphic petrology, with an emphasis on the principles of optical mineralogy. Students will use the petrographic microscope to examine rocks and minerals in thin section. Students will examine hand samples for rock and mineral descriptions and genetic interpretations. Prerequisite(s): GEO 215 and GEO 215L . Corequisite(s): GEO 316 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Sedimentation and Stratigraphy
description: Even years. Sedimentology is the study of sediment, particularly focusing on how it is transported, and deposited. Stratigraphy emphasizes the analysis of sedimentary strata, the layers of sedimentary (and some volcanic) rocks that cover about 3/4 of Earth’s surface. Sedimentary rocks illuminate many of the details of Earth’s history: effects of sea level change, global climate, tectonic processes, and geochemical cycles are all recorded in the sedimentary strata of Earth. This course will cover basics of fluid flow and sediment transport, sedimentary structures and textures, and diagenesis of sediments. We will study ancient depositional environments with particular attention to modern depositional analogs. Prerequisite(s): GEO 152 and GEO 215 (both may be taken concurrently). Corequisite(s): GEO 317L .

title: Sedimentation and Stratigraphy Lab
description: Students use sedimentary rock collections (hand samples and thin-sections) to interpret the genesis of sedimentary rocks. Students study graphical techniques for depicting the geometries of layered sedimentary rocks in outcrop and subsurface. Students will develop technical skills, practice data analysis, and engage in scientific communication. This course has required field trips. Prerequisite(s): GEO 152 and GEO 215 (both may be taken concurrently). Corequisite(s): GEO 317 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Hydrogeology
description: Odd years. This is an upper-level, pre-professional course, providing preparation in fundamental principles and practical applications of groundwater occurrence, flow, quality, extraction, and remediation. The course examines significant water resource and pollution issues in urban and developing areas. The course also addresses needs for clean and adequate water supplies in poor and remote areas of the world. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 101 ; and GEO 252 , ENGR 306 , or ENGR 320 . MATH 132 or MATH 171 is strongly recommended. Corequisite(s): GEO 325L .

title: Hydrogeology Lab
description: Odd years. The hydrogeology laboratory gives students hands-on and field experience with the methods used for investigating groundwater presence, assessing groundwater problems, and creating remediation plans. Prerequisite(s): CHEM 101 ; and GEO 252 , ENGR 306 , or ENGR 320 . MATH 132 or MATH 171 is strongly recommended. Corequisite(s): GEO 325 . Lab fee: $125.

title: Geology Field Methods
description: As needed. Geology Field Methods teaches basic field observation, identification, and mapping skills for students in geology, geography, and environmental programs. On-campus sessions will accompany the scheduled field study. We visit superb exposures of many varieties of rocks, as well as outstanding examples of geologic structures. We examine a variety of natural resources and study the environmental impacts of their use. After a study of the regional stratigraphy, a mapping project focuses on rock deformation and teaches field mapping techniques. Most of the class time will be in the field. This course may be offered as 1, 2, or 4 hours, depending on the field location and timing. A fee applies. Prerequisite(s): junior or senior standing, or permission of the instructor.

title: Geology as Vocation
description: Odd years. This course examines jobs in the geosciences and considers job and graduate school options for students after graduation. Topics include seeking to discover God’s call, career options, and necessary qualifications. Students will get to know geoscientists in various pathways through visiting presenters, a field trip, and personal interviews. They will prepare for grad school and the job market after Calvin by completing resumes/CV and cover letters, meeting with a career coach, and practicing skills. Course is graded pass/fail. Prerequisite(s): junior or senior standing, or permission of the instructor.

title: Research in Geology, Geography, and Environment
description: By arrangement. An investigation of an interesting question in geology, geography, environmental science or environmental studies, using appropriate research methods (field, laboratory, library, GIS, etc.). Research results are presented in a seminar. Prerequisite(s): permission of the department.

title: Honors Geology and Earth Science
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will investigate a variety of contemporary topics and challenges within the fields of geology and earth science through an interdisciplinary lens. Students will learn foundational geological concepts, develop an appreciation for the investigatory process of science as a value-laden collaborative enterprise, explore the reliability of scientific knowledge, and consider social and ethical aspects of scientific methodologies and findings. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Elementary German I
description: An introductory course in the German language and cultures that includes an investigation of German-speaking countries and training in intercultural skills. The course serves as the first course in a sequence for students with no prior knowledge of German. Students taking GERM 101 continue with GERM 102 in the spring followed by GERM 201 the next fall and GERM 202 the following spring.

title: Elementary German II
description: This course focuses on further development of skills in speaking, listening, reading, and writing German. This includes investigation of cultural topics, German history, and a study of a variety of texts. Prerequisite(s): GERM 101 .

title: Intermediate German I
description: Further development of skills in speaking, listening, reading, and writing German. This course includes systematic grammar review, cultural topics, and study of a variety of short texts. Prerequisite(s): GERM 101 or placement test.

title: Intermediate German II
description: Continuation of GERM 201 . This course offers an overview of German-speaking Europe and its cultural history. Prerequisite(s): Prerequisite: GERM 201 .

title: Advanced German Language and Culture
description: This course is designed to build your German language skills and to expand your knowledge of German culture. We explore key issues in contemporary German society. Course activities and assignments develop listening comprehension and promote fluency and accuracy in speaking and writing German on an everyday discourse level. We will review and learn grammar structures and regularly practice them orally and in writing over the course of the semester. You will meet regularly with the German foreign language teaching assistant outside of class for conversation on course-related topics. We will develop our ability to understand, evaluate, and value aspects of our own and other cultures. In this course and in the classroom, we will strive to recognize and honor all human beings as fellow image-bearers of God. Prerequisite(s): GERM 202 or equivalent.

title: German Cultures and Intercultural Studies
description: As needed. This course focuses on cultural learning, intercultural skill building, and cultural intelligence. Through exploration of German cultures, cultural comparisons and reflections on cultural identities, students build their capacity for engaging well across cultural lines. Key themes include factors of identity and an introduction to cultural studies. Course texts range from Jugendliteratur (young adult literature), newspaper articles, film, and poetry. Texts on cultures and cultural learning in English may also be assigned. Students are expected to progress in all German language skills, as well as their abilities to interact effectively and sensitively across cultural boundaries. Prerequisite(s): GERM 202 or equivalent.

title: Topics in German Literature
description: This course focuses on reading text, primarily the literary text. Since it is an entryway to upper-level study, we also spend time on skill development and vocabulary acquisition. Students are introduced to significant literary texts in German from a range of periods; major works are read in their entirety. Attention is given to the particular demands of reading each genre, allowing the course to serve both as an introduction to significant works and also as an introduction to the processes and skills of interpreting literary texts in German. Students learn how to describe and evaluate the aesthetic dimension of a literary work such as its genre, its style, its dramatic structure, its narrative perspective, or its use of metaphors and symbols. Students read, analyze, and discuss texts in their historical and cultural setting. Attention is given to discerning and articulating the world-and-life view informing each text through close reading, and also to the virtues of hospitality, care and attentiveness bound up with such close reading. Students learn to discover and articulate how each author in his or her period presents questions such as the nature of the human person, the nature of good and evil, and the presence or absence of redemptive forces in the world. The course provides students the opportunity to develop their oral and written communication skills. They will give oral plot summaries, write reflection papers in German and English, and do creative writing activities. The course is conducted mainly in German. Prerequisite(s): GERM 202 or equivalent.

title: Advanced German Culture II
description: This course offers a study of various eras and cultural themes of German-speaking Europe and does so at a more advanced level than in the prerequisite courses. Students encounter authentic material such as text (in a variety of genres), film, and various audio and visual media ranging from literature to the visual and audial arts. Attention is paid to visual and rhetorical culture, and students gain valuable experience reading, observing, or even performing and interpreting cultural artifacts. Attention is also paid to the implicit worldviews, assumptions, and goals of the texts and artifacts. This course will also pay attention to advanced grammar and give practice in certain genres of writing. Prerequisite(s): GERM 301 , GERM 302 , or GERM 303 .

title: German Studies Abroad
description: May intensive. Discover the cultural riches of Berlin, one of the most exciting capitals of Europe, as you learn or improve your German over three weeks in May. Students take morning classes at the world-renowned Goethe Institute one half of the day and exploring the German capital in the afternoon and evening. Lodging in Berlin is normally in private homes organized by the Goethe Institute. At the end of the course, students spend a few days exploring other cities or regions of Germany. Course goals include growth in intercultural sensitivity, gains in mastery of German, and increased understanding of various religious, political, and cultural phenomena of Germany. Students will be assessed on their participation in the Goethe Institute courses, director-led excursions, and the submission of analytic journal entries focusing on cultural issues.

title: Special Topics
description: This course offers the opportunity for focused study of a specific work, topic, or authors in a seminar setting. It includes intensive discussion in German of both primary and secondary texts. This course may be repeated with a different topic focus. Prerequisite(s): GERM 202 or permission of the instructor.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Prerequisites: Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Community Emergency and Incident Response
description: This medically based course is an introduction to knowledge, skills, strategies, and current best practices associated with preventing, responding, and managing emergency situations within groups and communities. Students will learn the roles and responsibilities of individuals and teams who respond to fires, hazardous materials, terrorists, active shooters, communicable diseases, weather-related emergencies, and earthquakes. Government and non-government-based response teams will be reviewed. Students will learn how communities can utilize houses of worship, congregations, and staff members to prepare for and respond to emergencies. This experiential course will primarily utilize in-class demonstration, guided rehearsal, skills practice, and scenario-based learning. The course will also utilize weekly readings, videos, quizzes, and presentations. Students will be formally assessed through a scenario-based practical assessment and through a written exam.

title: Individual Emergency and Incident Response
description: This medically based course is an introduction to knowledge, skills, strategies, and current best practices associated with preventing, responding, and managing incidents that require basic first aid, patient care, and communication with/transitioning to advanced medical care. Students will gain training in the Patient Assessment System, certification in CPR, and employment of AEDs. Environmental and outdoor medical situations will be covered. This experiential course will primarily utilize in-class demonstration, guided rehearsal, skills practice, and scenario-based learning. The course will also utilize weekly readings, videos, quizzes, and presentations. Students will be formally assessed through a scenario-based practical assessment and through a written exam. Course fee: $130.

title: Nutrition
description: This course will provide the student with a basic understanding of human nutrition. Special emphasis will be placed on the role of food and nutrients in sustaining optimal health. Specific topics of study will include nutrition as it relates to athletic performance, the onset of diseases, and obesity. This course is limited to kinesiology majors, nursing majors, and students in the pre-health programs. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 , BIOL 141 , or BIOL 161 . Course fee: $120.

title: Basic Health Concepts
description: Alternate years. This course is designed to provide students with basic health content. Topics to be discussed include a Christian perspective on health and wellness, mental health and stress, physical fitness, sexuality and reproduction, addictive behaviors, and aging and death. This introductory course is designed to prepare health education majors and minors with a wide variety of personal health education content include the following: a reformed perspective on health, risk factors for lifestyle diseases, personal health and fitness, injury prevention, personal nutrition and weight loss, and sexual health. Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 or permission of the instructor.

title: Administration and Methods
description: Alternate years. This course is designed to provide experiences that will enable the student to develop methodology, management, administrative, and instructional skills required to plan and implement a contemporary health education program in school settings.

title: History of the West and the World I
description: A survey of world history from the late Paleolithic to the beginnings of European overseas expansion (c. 1500 CE), highlighting the development of agrarian societies, the evolution of the world’s major religious and cultural traditions, human migration and intercultural encounters, and impulses from these as seen in gender and class relations, technological exchange, and political and economic interchange and conflict.

title: History of the West and the World II
description: A survey of world history from the onset of European overseas expansion (c. 1500 CE) to the present, highlighting developments and problems in social, political and cultural history that have continuing relevance in today’s world, such as cultural change and exchange, imperialism and colonization, industrialization, political reform and revolution, the interplay between religion and society, class and gender relations, and the causes and forms of human conflict. Attention will be paid to both “western” and “non-western” cultures and to the dynamic and often violent relations between cultures.

title: Explorations in World History
description: This course introduces students to world history through focused study of a particular topic or theme, chosen by the instructor of each section. Possible topics include: Slavery in World History; the History of Food; Health and Medicine in History; Science and Technology in History; Plagues and Pandemics; Big History. Every theme will span different world regions and/or time periods. Students will view the topic in distinct cultural, political, and social contexts, in both Western and non-Western world regions, and will also examine the historical processes of change and continuity.

title: Honors History
description: As needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will engage questions about the meaning of human life and experience through historical texts and traditions. While themes and readings will vary from year to year, in all iterations students will hone skills of careful reasoning and cultural and ideological discernment. Weighing evidence, evaluating sources, and accounting for both continuity and change will be central priorities. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Modern Middle East
description: As needed. This course focuses on the history of the Middle East from the early twentieth century to the present, emphasizing the tension between this region’s deep roots as the “cradle of civilization” and birthplace of the Abrahamic faith traditions and the more recent attempts at state-building initiated by European colonial powers after World War I. Drawing upon primary source materials and recent scholarship, the course will trace developments that include the creation of modern Arab nation-states, Zionism and the creation of the modern state of Israel, Pan-Arab movements, US military interventions and foreign policy, the Arab Spring, and regional interfaith and conflict resolution efforts.

title: Africa and the World
description: This course covers specific themes in African history from ancient civilization to the contemporary period. Special attention will be given to Africa’s relation to the Mediterranean world, Africa’s contribution to the development of the Christian church, Islam in Africa, slavery and slave trades, the African diaspora, imperialism, colonialism, anti-colonialism, nationalism, and post-independence challenges. This course seeks to place Africa within a number of global contexts, asserting that far from being the “Dark Continent,” Africa was a major crossroads of civilizations throughout history.

title: East Asia to 1800
description: As needed. The history of East Asian civilizations from early times until the early modern period. Emphasis is on China and Japan, but Korea is also included. Primary objectives are for students to grasp the essential patterns of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean social structures, political systems, cultural values, and religious and ethical norms as they developed from the late traditional period through to 1800, and also to appreciate the similarities and differences among these civilizations. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Seminar in United States History
description: This seminar takes a broad, student-centered learning approach in order to survey the history of the United States as it evolved from its Native American roots and first African and European populations into an independent political unit with an industrial economy and an urban society that ultimately emerged as a global power in the mid-twentieth century. The course will emphasize several interlocking themes: colonial roots and cultural and political divergence; the costs and benefits of expansion; industrialization and immigration; American leadership in the twentieth century; and the challenges of the twenty-first century. Emphasis will be given to teaching these topics at the elementary and secondary-school level.

title: Native American History
description: As needed. This course explores regional Native American chiefdoms and states in the centuries before European contact; the impact of horses on the Great Plains; trade between Europeans and Americans; Christian missions in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries; the “Indian Wars” in the American West, 1840s–1890s; efforts to assimilate Native Americans in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries; and campaigns by Native Americans to promote their civil rights and tribal sovereignty in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. The course is national in scope, but focuses especially on the American West, with comparisons to indigenous peoples throughout the Americas, Africa, and Australia.

title: Early America
description: As needed. A study of the region that became the United States in a trans-Atlantic context, from the first European settlements through the Napoleonic wars. We will treat colonial America as a cluster of distinct socio-cultural regions: plantation Virginia, Caribbean Carolina, Puritan New England, commercial mid-Atlantic, and the Scots-Irish backcountry. These regions converged to sustain a successful war against the British, but almost fell apart again during the first decades of independence. We will pay special attention to the unexpected dynamics of the Revolutionary War and to the Constitution as establishing an arena of combat rather than a set of settled answers. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: America from Republic to Empire
description: As needed. An examination of United States history after independence as the nation expanded, industrialized, and came to dominate the Western hemisphere. Special attention is given to the nation’s foundations, western expansion, and slavery; the Civil War and Reconstruction; the Progressive response to industrialization; and the United States’ overseas expansion and participation in World War I. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Recent America
description: As needed. An examination of United States history from the 1920s to the present, focusing on the ways in which recent history shapes contemporary American culture, politics, economics, and religion. Topics include the “Roaring Twenties” and the Great Depression, WWII, Cold War America and Vietnam, the Civil Rights Movement and the Rights Revolution, conservative politics and religion, a post-industrial economy, and the role of the state at home and abroad. Special attention is given to changing configurations of race, religion, ethnicity, and gender in American social relations, and to the intersections of cultural history with political and economic history. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: American History
description: A survey of African-American history from West African societies to contemporary times. Highlights include the creation of a slave society in British North America, African-American intellectual traditions, the African-American church, and social and political movements for freedom, with a special emphasis on the substance and symbolism of the Obama years.

title: Women and Gender in US History
description: Alternate years. A study of the history of women and gender in American history. The course examines the social construction of femininity and masculinity; intersections of race, class and gender; changing understandings of sexuality; the history of feminism; and the relationship between Christianity and feminism. The course provides an introduction to significant questions and methodologies in women’s history and gender studies and equips students to approach contemporary issues related to women and gender. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: US Military History
description: As needed. This course studies the military as an American institution from the colonial period through the “War on Terror.” The course covers colonial wars and the major wars the United States has fought, along with special occupations and engagements such as the occupations of Haiti and the Dominican Republic, and the invasion of Grenada. The course will also examine the various social, economic, and political factors influencing the development of the American military. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: American Economic and Business History
description: As needed. A study of American economic history from colonial times to the present, emphasizing the foundations of the American economy, the dynamics behind American economic expansion, the history of American business, the social costs and benefits of industrialization and modernization, the impact of various economic policies, and the nature of the economic changes of the 21st century. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: England
description: Alternate years. A survey of English history including the Anglo-Saxon background; the medieval intellectual, religious, and constitutional developments; the Tudor and Stuart religious and political revolutions; the emergence of Great Britain as a world power; and the growth of social, economic, and political institutions in the modern period.

title: Ancient Mediterranean
description: Alternate years. A study of the political, social, cultural, religious, and economic developments of the ancient Mediterranean world, from the late Neolithic to the beginning of Late Antiquity. Rather than focus primarily on Greece and Rome, the course situates these ancient societies within the wider context of Egypt, Mesopotamia, and the Ancient Near East, for a broader understanding of the interconnected nature of the ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern worlds.

Alternate years. In the wake of the Roman Empire, three distinct political cultures emerged from the disintegration of the Roman Empire: the Byzantine Empire, the Islamic commonwealth, and Christian Western Europe. This course will study the emergence of these areas, their interactions, and how they incorporated their Hellenistic legacies. Special attention is given to the rise of Islam, the Christianization of Western Europe, the role of monasticism in East and West, and the way each civilization integrated its Roman-Hellenistic heritage into its institutions and culture. Not offered in 2025-26.

Alternate years. A treatment of one of the most formative periods in the development of European culture and institutions, when strong monarchies emerged out of feudalism and a new religious vitality transformed Christian spirituality. These impulses are traced through the rise of schools and universities, the Crusades, and the role of the papacy as a unifying political force in Western Christendom, concluding with the late-medieval economic and demographic crisis and the break-up of the medieval worldview in Renaissance Italy.

Alternate years. A study of Europe’s Protestant Reformation, its roots in late medieval Christian culture, and its expression in the writings of theologians such as Martin Luther and John Calvin and others from the Reformed, Anabaptist, and Anglican traditions, as well as the parallel Catholic Reformation of the same era. Through primary and secondary-source readings and historical role-playing games, students will examine the interplay between religion, politics, and social relations among Protestants and Catholics in this tumultuous period and consider its relevance for our own times.

title: Modern Europe
description: As needed. A survey of Europe from the French Revolution (1789) to the present. Using 1945 as a pivotal year, the course examines the major social, economic, cultural, and political trends that dominated the continent and inspired the two world wars: nationalism, industrialization, militarization, secularization, protest movements, and imperialism. The balance of the course examines the changes and continuities that have characterized the post-war period: economic integration, the Cold War and its aftermath, immigration, decolonization, the tension between European unity and national identities, as well as the burden of Europe’s past. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Playing Game
description: As needed. This course introduces students to historical thinking through an immersive “Reacting to the Past” role-playing game. Each course centers on a game from the Reacting Consortium library that reenacts a deliberative assembly at some turning point in history. The first 2-3 weeks introduce the historical context, and the appropriate research, writing, and public speaking skills. Students represent historical characters, read primary sources to understand conflicting points of view, debate contested issues in the voices of their characters, and work together to implement solutions to historical challenges. Not offered in 2025-26.
course_number: Reacting to the Past: History Role

title: War and Society
description: As needed. This is not a military history course. Instead, the course examines the social and cultural contexts of warfare from a global and comparative perspective. Case studies are drawn from different conflicts during the 20th century in different world regions, such as Austria-Hungarian World War I, Japan after World War II, post-colonial West Africa, and the recent wars of the United States. By examining the histories of individual states during particular conflicts, students will seek to understand why governments and societies move toward military action and how states, societies, and individuals are affected by war. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Environmental History
description: An introduction to environmental history, the course gives particular attention to North America and in each unit makes global comparisons or examines transnational trends. Key topics include the methods of environmental history, sustainability ideas and practices, pre-human natural history, the relationship between hunter-gatherers and the environment, the development of agriculture, the ecological impact of European colonization globally, the consequences of the industrial revolution and urbanization, the emergence of environmental movements, changing cultural patterns in conceptualizing nature and humanity’s place in it, and the relationship between religious traditions, especially Christianity, and environmental issues. Not offered in spring 2026.

title: Introduction to Archaeology
description: An introduction to the study of the human past through the material evidence that has been left behind. Archaeology will be introduced as a historical and anthropological endeavor that seeks to document the past and create new histories through the critical and contextual evaluation of both material and documentary sources. The course emphasizes the global history of archaeology, archaeological theory and methods, interpretation, site conservation, relevant legal frameworks, and the ways archaeology serves as a bridge between historical disciplines and the arts, humanities, social sciences, and natural sciences. Upon completion, students will be prepared to participate in archaeological field work. The course serves as a prerequisite for HIST 380 . Crosslisted as IDIS 240 .

title: Public History
description: “Public history” refers to historical work done in non-academic fields. Students will explore the varied aspects of public history through field trips to local museums, historical societies, and historic preservation sites, and meetings with representatives from these and other fields of public history. They will also learn about the varieties of public history through readings and classroom lectures, create their own historical exhibits for display in a public setting on or off the Calvin campus, and explore the varied career opportunities related to public history. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Research Methods of History
description: An introduction to historical sources, bibliography, and research techniques, giving particular attention to the different genres of history writing, critical historical thinking and the role of perspective and worldview, the mechanics of professional notation, critical use of print and electronic research data bases, organizing and writing research essays, and the vocation of the historian. Intended as preparation for 300-level courses. History majors and minors should take this course as early as possible.

title: Studies in Middle Eastern History
description: As needed. An in-depth analysis of a particular topic or period within the history of the Middle East. Calling upon the rich variety of sources from antiquity to the present, the course practices historical analysis on interdisciplinary materials from the region. Possible topics may include Ancient Mesopotamian Literature and Science, Religion and Society in the First Millennium, Pre-Islamic Arabia, the Islamic Golden Age, Ottoman Tanzimat Reforms, US-Middle East Relations, the Arab Spring, or other relevant topics tied to faculty research specializations. Topics for coming semesters are advertised by the Historical Studies Department. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Modern China
description: As needed. An in-depth, comprehensive treatment of Chinese history from the Qing Dynasty, about 1650, to the present. In addition to the basics of political, social, and economic history, the course will stress intellectual and religious currents, including the role of Christianity. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Studies in US Religious and Intellectual History
description: As needed. This course examines the role of ideas, beliefs, and values in US history, focusing topically on dominant and dissenting systems of thought and conviction that have been particularly important in US history. The course will analyze both elite and popular materials from across the full range of public expression—from state papers to protest publications, the arts, journalism, religion, literature, and the academy—to understand how these have both shaped and responded to the key historical forces of their times. Topics for upcoming semesters are advertised by the Historical Studies Department. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: American Social and Cultural History
description: As needed. A study of the development of American society from colonial times to the present organized around the themes of power, consumption, material culture, and the social construction of space. Attention will be given to the ways in which new sources, methods, and theoretical frameworks open up new topics and questions in American history, including the changing meaning of the American landscape, the development of suburbia, the rise of consumerism and the mass media, popular religion and the creation of sacred space, and the hidden ways in which power is exercised. Class, gender, and race will be categories of inquiry and analysis. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Climate and Sustainability in the American West
description: Alternate years. This course explores climate change and sustainability in the modern American West. It begins with the deep history of the geographical, geological, and climatological forces that continue to shape the region today and an examination of indigenous societies that used irrigation in the centuries before contact with Europeans. It focuses on the modern era and contemporary West. Topics include comparisons between past and present megadroughts; conflicts over natural resources, notably water rights; dam building and the creation of a “hydraulic civilization” in the twentieth century; environmental and social justice challenges associated with climate change and the Anthropocene more broadly; and concepts such as conservation, preservation, and sustainability and how they intersect with the history of the region. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Studies in Ancient and Medieval Europe
description: As needed. Offers an in-depth analysis of a particular topic or period within ancient and/or medieval Europe. Calling upon the rich variety of sources in ancient and/or medieval European culture and society, it practices historical analysis on interdisciplinary materials. Possible topics include the Greek polis, the Roman Empire of Augustus, Late Antiquity, Jews and Christians in the Middle Ages, Sex and Society in the Middle Ages, the Bible in the Middle Ages, and the Crusades. Topics for upcoming semesters are advertised by the Historical Studies department. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Studies in Early Modern and Modern Europe
description: As needed. This course focuses on a particular period or movement in European history within either the early modern period (c. 1500-1789) or the modern period (since 1789). The specific content will vary from year to year. Past topics have included the Italian Renaissance, the Counter-Reformation, international Calvinism, imperial Spain, nationalism and communism in Eastern Europe. Topics for upcoming semesters are advertised by the Historical Studies Department. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: The Use and Abuse of the Medieval Past
description: As needed. This seminar explores the ways in which the Middle Ages have been presented, from the nineteenth century to the present day, in the service of a range of political agendas, from Victorian nation-building to wars of conquest, alt-right extremism, neo-paganism, and the neo-medieval religious radicalism of today in both the Christian and the Muslim world.

title: Studies of Modern Empires
description: As needed. The course examines the changing nature of empires and imperialism between the 15th and 20th centuries. It considers the influence of factors such as environment, religion, demography, race, technology, economic institutions, politics, and war on the creation of empires, the conduct of those who led them and were affected by them, and on their ultimate demise. While the particular empires examined will vary from one semester to the next, the broad underlying theme will be the evolution of empires and imperialism, from the land-based and overseas “gunpowder” empires of the early modern era to the “high imperialism” of the 19th century to the Cold War and globalization in the 20th century. Topics for upcoming semesters are advertised by the Historical Studies department. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Studies in the History of Women and Gender
description: As needed. An introduction to topics in the history of women and to the use of gender as a category of historical analysis. This course examines experiences unique to women, as well as the social history of male-female interactions (in such institutions as the family, the church, and the political sphere) and the changing perceptions of masculinity and femininity in various historical contexts. Depending on the instructor, the course will focus either on early modern Europe (c. 1500-1800) or modern North America. Topics for upcoming semesters are announced by the Historical Studies department. This course serves as an elective in both history and gender studies. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Field Work in Archaeology
description: (May), alternate years. Offered in conjunction with field work done by Calvin faculty or qualified field schools of other universities. An off-campus, on-site introduction to archaeological field work designed to expose the student to the methodologies involved in stratigraphic excavation, typological and comparative analysis of artifacts, the use of material remains in the writing of cultural history, and the preservation and presentation of sites. Field school enrollment and placement is overseen by the Archaeology Program Coordinator. Crosslisted as IDIS 340 . Prerequisite(s): HIST 280 /IDIS 240 and permission of the instructor.

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Independent Study
description: Contingent on instructor approval, students may complete an independent study on a topic of their choice. Honors Scholars majoring in History must complete HIST 390 as preparation for HNRS 399 (Honors Thesis), which will be a continuation of the research they began in HIST 390. (Note: both HIST 390 and HNRS 399 require the prior agreement of a faculty mentor.)

title: History Internship
description: A specialized class in which students engage in experiential learning at a historical institution or site in other appropriate fields of work, as approved by the Historical Studies Department. Prior to enrolling, students must secure a semester-long internship and submit a description of their planned activities and educational objectives. In order to pass, students must also receive a favorable review from their internship site supervisor, attend regular meetings with the Calvin faculty mentor, and complete an internship journal and reflective essay. Semester hours awarded will depend on weekly workload, with a minimum of 45 total hours worked for the internship employer/supervisor for each semester hour earned (90 hours for 2 semester hours, 180 hours for 4 semester hours). This does not include time spent on meetings with Calvin faculty mentor and written work. Prerequisite(s): HIST 294 ; junior or senior status; 3.0 GPA or permission of the instructor.

title: Historiographical Perspectives
description: The capstone in the history major, this course examines the history of historical writing and the historian’s vocation, primarily in the Western tradition. Emphasis is on reading and discussion of significant texts and issues in Western historical writing in past and present times. We will consider such questions as: What is history? How should it be studied, taught, and written? What purposes does it serve? Students will evaluate a variety of Christian and non-Christian perspectives on these questions and be challenged to articulate their own answers.

title: Human Resource Management
description: An introduction to human resource functions along with principles and issues involved in managing an organization’s human capital. Emphasis is placed on the modern-day importance of human resource management and focuses on the formulation and implementation of strategies that help companies achieve a sustained competitive advantage. Emphasis is also placed on respect, integrity and the inherit dignity of human beings and how business can create opportunities for individuals to express their vocation in the performance of God-glorifying work. The course will introduce a framework for integrated talent management and will include the study of talent acquisition, compensation and rewards management, organized labor, career succession, performance management, learning management and leadership development, employee engagement and retention, and redeployment. Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in BUS 201 . Course fee: $50.

title: The Psychology of Work
description: A consideration of psychological concepts and research related to human action in work situations, particularly in organizations. The principles of industrial and organizational psychology and human resource management are applied to current topics including organizational identity, psychometrics for screening and selection, employee socialization, performance measurement and management, and employee attitudes and behaviors. The relationship of psychological theory and practice are analyzed through case studies of organizational experiences. Crosslisted as PSYC 305 . Prerequisite(s): BUS 201 or PSYC 151 , and STAT 143 (or equivalent).

title: Special Topics in Human Resource Management
description: Human Resource Management is an expanding and ever-changing area of study. We will offer a series of courses on a rotating basis that will allow students more advanced study in the specific areas of interest. Anticipated special-topics courses are likely to include Compensation and Reward Systems, Negotiation and Labor Relations, Diversity and Inclusion in the Workplace, Talent Acquisition and Measurement, Talent Development and Management, and Organizational Development and Change. Prerequisite(s): HRM 301 and HRM 305

title: External Practicum
description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online. Prerequisite(s): Prerequisites: Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

title: Community and Commitments
description: Community and Commitments serves as an introduction to the Reformed theological tradition and Calvin University’s educational framework. Topics include an exploration of Reformed Christian commitments to justice, intercultural learning, and sustainability and a compelling invitation to a Christian liberal arts education which equips students for vocation and citizenship. This reading- and discussion-based course helps students develop and practice skills required to succeed as a university student.

title: Campus Global Regions and Cultures
description: As needed. This course will fulfill the Core tag category for Global Regions and Cultures. Students in this course will apply the methods of an academic discipline to examine an aspect of contemporary life from a specific global perspective. In addition to formal readings and lectures, students will intentionally engage in high-impact activities and will complete guided reflections and an analytical assignment based on those activities.

title: Special Topics in Diversity, Equity, Inclusion & Belonging
description: Offered as needed. This course examines a particular theme or topic directly related to the goals of promoting diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging. Past examples have included Minority Voices in Science; Christian-Muslim Interfaith Dialogue; Black Lives Matter; and Race in America. This course is pass/fail. Prerequisite(s): CORE 100 .

title: Foundations in Biblical Literature and Theology
description: This course provides an introduction to the Bible, both Old and New Testaments. The goal of the course is to equip students to interpret biblical writings in a rigorous and sophisticated manner, with attention to the historical context (author, audience, purpose) of each text as well as the theological, ethical, and spiritual questions—about the nature of God, humanity, morality, and evil—that each text raises. This class will explore the spiritual richness and theological depth of the Bible but will also wrestle with some of the difficult issues raised by the text. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 110 .

title: Honors Community and Commitments
description: As a point of entry for both Calvin’s Core curriculum and the Honors Scholars program, this course introduces the institutional project of thinking deeply, with eyes always toward justice and renewal. Taught alongside a second course in the Calvin Core, this course emphasizes Calvin’s Reformed theological foundations and its attendant commitments to justice, intercultural learning, and sustainability through the lens of a particular discipline.

title: Intermediate Studies in Biblical Literature and Theology
description: This course will build upon the knowledge and analytical skill gained in HNRS 103 . Due to the interdisciplinary nature of the analysis and interpretation of scripture and theological texts, this course may be taught from a theological, literary, philosophical, or historical perspective. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 103 .

title: Honors Colloquium
description: An advanced exploration of a topic, practice, or theme that is interdisciplinary in nature. Students from various disciplines will engage ideas employing knowledge, methodologies, and insights from diverse areas of study. This course will fulfill an upper-level interdisciplinary course requirement for honors students. Students that are not participating in the honors program may register for the course with instructor permission. This course may be repeated.

title: Preparation for the Honors Thesis
description: An introduction to literature-based research methods used by scholars in various disciplines. Students will practice research methods, generate a research question, and develop an honors thesis project timeline. Students will also engage with senior honors student mentors.

title: Prompte: Honors Capstone
description: Taking for its title one of Calvin’s key intellectual virtues, this course will serve as a capstone for the Honors Scholars Program, emphasizing prompte as a disposition of earnest commitment. At the close of students’ Calvin experience, the course will bring together key themes of the Honors program: interdisciplinarity, intellectual virtues such as humility and risk-taking, habits of life-long learning, and vocational discernment. Students will explain the outcomes of their theses or creative projects for a general audience, connecting their work to real-world stakes of why such work matters. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 299 .

title: Honors Thesis
description: A substantial independent research or creative project within a student’s major field(s) of study conducted under the direction of a faculty mentor. Required for students graduating with honors. Before enrolling in this course, students must secure the approval of an honors advisor and a faculty advisor willing to mentor the proposed Honors research or creative project. This course may be repeated. Prerequisite(s): HNRS 299 .

title: Oral Rhetoric for Engineers
description: A study of the principles of oral rhetoric, with emphasis on developing student competency in preparing and delivering effective speeches. The emphasis is on basic speech design for engineers communicating their creation and refinement of ideas to peers, managers, subordinates, venture capitalists, and to the public at large.

title: Introduction to Health Professions
description: Students considering a health-related pre-professional program and a career in health care are introduced to various health professions, as well as the required preparation for these careers, to help them identify career path(s) they may want to pursue. Students consider Christian perspectives on health professions, evaluate ethical dilemmas, and engage in discussions about current issues in the health-care field. Students also receive certifications that prepare them for shadowing and volunteer experiences.

title: Introduction to Ecological and Environmental Professions
description: Students considering careers related to ecology, conservation, and environmental biology are introduced to the variety of professions and avenues for employment by practitioners of those fields, as well as the required preparation for pursuing these careers. Students explore graduate education and the prospects for employment after receiving an undergraduate degree. Students consider Christian perspectives on creation care, evaluate ethical dilemmas, and engage in discussions about current issues. This course has another goal that is harder to measure, namely building a sense of community among students in the Environmental Science and Environmental Health and Conservation majors, which are housed in two different departments. Think of it as your orientation group for these environmental majors.

title: Sustainability Action Workshop
description: In this course, students will work in small groups, paired with a community organization, to address a sustainability-related challenge. In addition to this real-world project work, students will meet weekly to share progress, brainstorm solutions, and gain practical sustainability leadership and action skills. Corequisite(s): enrollment in the Sustainability Fellows Cohort.

title: Awareness Abroad
description: WI. This course will focus on gaining a deeper understanding of oneself within a cross-cultural context in Puerto Rico. It will be especially relevant for those entering the helping professions, where it’s imperative to know oneself in order to care well for others and to engage in healthy and sustainable ways in God’s kingdom work. The purpose is to help students with self-reflection within a cross-cultural context. The learning will be accomplished through readings, guest lecturers, personality assessments, personal intercultural development plans, group processing and discussions, journaling and engagement in cross-cultural activities, and experiences in both rural and urban settings.
course_number: Who Am I? Helping Professionals Grow Self

title: Career Readiness in Community
description: This course is designed for students interested in a structured approach to developing career readiness skills alongside a community of peers, whether they are headed for the work world or graduate school upon graduation. Utilizing classroom discussions, activities, readings, and Calvin LifeWork modules, students will finish the course with a stronger understanding of the concept of vocation, an increased ability to articulate their strengths and experiences to potential employers and grad schools and equipped to bridge the gap between classroom learning and application in industry. Course content is applicable to all majors.

title: Introduction to Sustainability Challenges
description: Stainability seeks to serve the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. This course examines the challenges to that goal in each of the three areas of sustainability: economic, societal, and environmental. Topics include the biblical basis for sustainability, global energy consumption and carbon emissions, application areas for sustainability, and personal and collective actions.

title: Reconciliation, Servitude, Leadership: John M. Perkins Leadership Fellows
description: With John Perkins as a role model and guide, this course will address the intersection of race, poverty, justice, the church, reconciliation, and Christian leadership in America. To this end, we will reflect on the Civil Rights movement, the life and work of John Perkins, and the nature and mission of the church in America (and the world). Also, this course contributes to Calvin’s John Perkins Leadership Fellows Program, which seeks to help students to become leaders that can address “big issues, such as poverty, injustice, racism and materialism” (taken from the JPLFP from Calvin’s website).

title: Crossing Cultures
description: This course equips students to engage in relationships with people from a cultural background different from their own. Students who’ve grown up in different cultures will be paired to reflect and share from their different backgrounds. Together, these students will build skills in cross cultural communication through weekly discussions, class activities, and course assignments. This course has limited enrollment by application.

title: Transcultural Caring for the Health Professional
description: This interdisciplinary course examines culture care in a variety of settings from a Christian perspective, implementing broad cultural and structural dimensions to explore the “global community” in which we live today. The major focus of the course will be to increase student understanding and knowledge in the area of transcultural care by providing an opportunity for the student to be directly involved in a culture other than their own. Students will explore a variety of theoretical perspectives related to culture care and be able to implement this knowledge in the real world around them. Finally, students will explore transformative culture care that considers justice, reconciliation, and engagement in diverse cultures.

title: Classical and Medieval Palaeography
description: As needed. This course offers a practical introduction to reading Late Antique, Medieval, and Humanist Latin and vernacular script, from c. AD 200 until c. AD 1500. We will master reading these scripts, while learning about their historical development and the production of written texts before the invention of the printing press. The script types studied in this course will range from square capital, cursive, uncial and half-uncial, Carolingian minuscule, Anglo-Saxon script, and the various forms of Gothic and Humanist script, while the texts we read will include Classical and Patristic texts, vernacular texts, and especially the Latin Bible. Not offered in 2025-26.

title: Introduction to the United States Health Care System
description: This course introduces students to important concepts for their individual and professional understanding of health systems and health outcomes.
